  • What are the biotic and abiotic stresses on trees? Explain the responses of trees to these stresses.

  • Write scientific names of four major tree species in each of southern tropical semi evergreen forest and northern tropical wet evergreen forest.
  • Discuss the different forest types found along tidal swamp forest with their species composition. Give a note on how Rhizophora racemosa is managed in mangrove forest of Sundarbans.

  • Write the different types of tropical deciduous forest with suitable examples.

  • Explain the techniques for upgradation and hardening of the seedlings of Lagerstroemia lanceolata.
  • How are nurseries classified in India? What is clonal nursery? Explain the nursery techniques for Casuarina equisetifolia.

1. Silviculture - General :

General Silvicultural Principles : ecological and physiological factors influencing vegetation,

natural and artificial regeneration of forests; methods of propagation, grafting techniques; site

factors; nursery and planting techniques-nursery beds, polybags and maintenance, water

budgeting, grading and hardening of seedlings; special approaches; establishment and

tending.

Definitions
  • Buttracing

    Buttresses are the outgrowth at the base of the stem, usually vertical, and connected the base of the stem with roots more strongly. Common in wet and moist tropical species, for example - Bombax, Pterocarpus, Artocarpus, Terminalia myriocarpa, sterculia.

  • Felling cycle

    The time that elapses between successive main fellings on the same area.

  • Flag tree

    constant wind → one side of the tree stops growing → giving it a flag-like appearance

  • forest

    Forest is an area set aside for the production of timber and other forest produce or to get other indirect benefits from it.

    Forest is an cultivated land occupied by natural vegetation with a close or partially closed canopy, which provides shelter to the world life

    Forest is any land area that has been declared as a forest under any central or state or local laws.

  • Forestry

    The theory and practice of all that constitutes the creation, conservation, and scientific management of forest and utilization of their resources.

  • Forking

    When the stem has more than one leader.

  • Hardening off

    The natural process by plants become adapted to drought, cold or heat gradually by exposing them to the particular stress. This term is also used for preparing seedlings in a forest nursery or greenhouse for planting out by gradually reducing watering, shed, and or shelter, resulting in hardening of plant.

  • Hardiness

    The ability of plants to survive under adverse weather conditions like cold, heat, drought, flooding, or wind is called hardiness.

  • Harvesting
    • Remover of trees and other forest products in a sustainable manner
  • Herbs

    Plants whose stems are always green and tender, and is usually not more than 1 m.

  • Heterosis

    biological phenomenon where the offspring of two or more parents with different genetic bases have superior traits compared to their parents

Increment

  • Increment is the quantitative increase in size in a specified time interval due to growth.
  • Includes diameter, height, basal area

  • Inventory
    • Measuring and mapping forest resources
      • Types and sizes of trees
      • Amount of biomass
      • Distribution of different species
  • Micro climate

    local climate of area that differs from the general climate

    Factors – altitude, aspect, slope, drainage, vegetation

  • Periodic block

    Parts of a forest set aside for regeneration or specific treatment for specific period of time.

    • Number of periodic blocks = (rotation period)/(regeneration period)
    • Figure
    • Types
      • Fixed or permanent

        Retain territorial identity at each working plan revision

      • Floating
        • No pre-determined limit on the size of block or period
        • Boundaries are changed at each revision of working plan
  • Phenology

    Seasonal changes in the plant that is flowering, fruiting, leave shedding, etc.

  • Pollard

    Decapitation of a tree at a certain height above ground level to obtain a flash of shoots. Height is usually above the height to which browsing animals can reach.

  • Regeneration period

    Time to regenerate the whole of a periodic block.

    • Factors that affect length of regeneration period
      • Frequency of good seed year - frequent – shorter
      • Light requirement – light demander require shorter regeneration period
      • Climatic factors - Extremely low temperature, deficient rainfall – longer
      • Soil conditions
      • Competition from weed growth
      • Grazing and browsing
      • Fire
  • Rotation period
    • the time it takes to grow trees from establishment to harvest
    • Regeneration→Rotation PeriodFinal Felling\ce{Regeneration ->[Rotation Period]Final Felling}RegenerationRotation Period​Final Felling﻿
    • for regular forest crop only
    • for uneven or irregular trees → “exploitable age” or “Utilizable age”
  • Silvics

    study of life history and general characteristics of forest trees

  • Silviculture
    • science and practice of managing forest crop
    • activities that promote growth and health of forest such as planting, tending, pruning, thinning, pest and disease control
  • Site quality

    Site quality is the relative productive capacity of a site for a particular species or group of species.

  • Stand: Group of trees that are relatively homogeneous in composition, age class distribution, structure growing on a site of uniform quality
  • Stem

    = bole = trunk

  • Shrub

    Perennial plants larger than herbs and usually below 4 m in height.

Thinning

Felling made in an immature stand – removing diseased, damaged, slow growing trees to improve growth and form of remaining trees – without permanently breaking canopy.

Applicable —

  • Pure and even age crop
  • Beyond the sapling stage and up to the beginning of regeneration period

  • Tree

    Woody perennial plant having a single well defined step or drunk, a more or less defined formed crown of foliage, the height of at least 4 m.

  • Working plan
    • Plan that outlines goals, strategies and actions for managing forest
Formulae

Andre’s formula

n1,n2,n3n_1,n_2,n_3n1​,n2​,n3​﻿: number of trees of different diameter class

p,q,rp,q,rp,q,r﻿: true age of diameter class

xxx﻿: corresponding age to diameter class

Compound interest formula

vvv﻿: initial volume

VVV﻿: volume after nnn﻿ years

  • Mean annual increment

    rrr﻿ = rotation Period

    YrY_rYr​﻿ = final yield

    ∑V\sum{V}∑V﻿ = volume of thinning at various ages

Pressler’s formula

nnn﻿: number of years (growing time period)

kkk﻿: quality at the end of growing period

k′k'k′﻿: quality at the initial point of growing period

Schneider’s formula

DDD﻿: DBH

nnn﻿: number of rings counted by increment borer

Forest Classification
  • purpose
    • Standardised system for identifying describing and mapping different types of forest based on their characteristics such as tree species, composition, canopy structure and ecological function used in decision-making processes for conservation, management, administration, research, land planning and record keeping
    • Identifying areas of high biodiversity or ecological significance for conservation and sustainable management
    • Developing sustainable management plans tailored to specific needs of the forest ecosystem
  • Basis
    • age - even, regular or uneven
    • Method of regeneration
      • high forest - seeds
      • coppice - vegetative methods
      • Natural
      • Man-made
    • Composition - pure 80% of same as species, mixed
    • Ownership government communal private panchayat
    • Function or objectives protection, Nashville Forest village Forest tree land
    • Legality or statutory - reserved (Indian forest act 1927 chapter 2), village (chapter 3) hi, protected, and un-classed

    Growing stock

    • overstocked
      • volume of growing stock > volume needed as per yield table
      • Due to presence of over-mature trees
    • normal stocked
      • growing space efficiently occupied by vegetation
    • understocked
      • growing space not efficiently occupied by vegetation

    • Geographical / climatic / ecological
      • Tropical
      • Mountain subtropical
      • mountain temperate
      • sub-alpine
      • alpine
      • Champion and Seth - 16
    • Dynamics - successional stage, climax, post-climax

Need to revisit for classification?

  • Current classification is based on British era forest classification.
    • First time in 1936 by Sir HG champion.
    • Revised in 1968 by Champion and Seth.
  • Meanwhile, India's Forest have undergone change
    • Shifting towards drier condition
    • Global warming and climate change
    • Ecological change
    • Introduction of exotics
    • Rise of plantation forestry
    • Emergence of legal framework - e.g. “Go” and “No-Go” areas
  • So, ICFRE is working on a new classification
    • 10 groups instead of 16
    • 44 subtypes
Forestry Classifications
  • intensity
    • intensive - maximum production per area
    • extensive - multipurpose trees
  • objective
    • protection
    • production
    • social
Silviculture study objectives
  • control crop composition
  • quality and quantity of timber
  • reduce rotation period
  • afforestation, reforestation, site protection
  • exotic introduction
  • man-made forests
Site Factors
  • Climate factors
    • Solar radiation, rainfall, wind speed, air temperature
    • Adverse local weather
  • Location

    Remote – market, labour, connectivity

  • Edaphic factors
    • Soil organic matter, mycorrhiza, water logging, salinity, soil texture, soil structure
    • Sub surface hardpan
  • Topographic or physiographic
    • Altitude, latitude, slope, exposure
  • Biotic factors
    • Insect or pest attack
    • invasion of exotics
    • grazing and browsing by wild and domestic animals
    • human interference
  • Technical and economic factor
    • Available technology
    • Fund for projects
    • Skilled workforce
    • Market demand
  • Socio-economic impact
    • Impact on tribal economy
    • Naxal or militancy issues
Site-specific planning
  1. Comprehensive knowledge of the local climate, soils, topography, vegetation, and administrative abilities, infrastructure
  1. Identify the areas’ challenges and issues
  1. Participation of all stakeholders - in the planning process by identifying and ensuring the requirements of local tribal community as well as conservation needs of forest and wild life
  1. sustainable management of forest and natural resources
  1. Identify areas for forest harvesting
  1. Ensure proper and equitable returns to stakeholders based on sustained productivity
Precision Silviculture
  • It is site specific silviculture prescription with modern digital technique.
  • Site preparation, identification of suitable species, number of seedlings, quality of material, etc. → is precisely matched to site’s soil and weather condition.
  • It includes - GPS, ground sensor, information management system
  • Cropping input like fertilizer, water, etc. is applied with site specific condition.
  • Therefore, precision forestry analyses spatial and temporal variability based on nature and environment.

Site quality

Importance
  1. Prediction of growth and yield with the help of yield tables - which given information by quality classes.
  1. Understand interaction between species and site conditions for development of sustainable management practices.

Determination

Direct measurement

Indirect measurement
  1. Soil characteristics and topographical factors
  1. Indicator species
  1. Growth rate of the species
  1. Growing stock per unit area

Site index

average height of the dominant and co-dominant trees on the site at a given age (base age)
Issues
  1. Species specific - maybe poor indicator of sites index for other species
  1. Well-defined height - Useful for conifers, not for hard-wood species with rounded spreading crown
  1. “Site trees” must be free from past disturbance, injury, or damage
Height as criteria

Height

  • increases only up to a certain age ⇒ doesn’t require age
  • easier to measure
  • independent of tree density

Diameter

  • continuously increases with age ⇒ requires age
  • Bamboo → slow diameter growth

Climate factors

solar radiation

  • shade bearer → can sustain under shade for any period of time
Importance
  • metabolic reactions
  • chlorophyll synthesis
  • transpiration
  • germination
  • photoperiodism – relative lengths of light and dark periods induce flowering, and fruiting
  • composition and distribution of species - shed bearer and shade demander species
  • stratification of forest community
  • Check weed growth
Types of forestLight demanderShare bearerShade demander
Tropical wet evergreen forestDiptetrocarpus spp.Artocarpus spp.Mesua ferrea
Tropical moist deciduous forestShorea robusta, Tectona grandis, Dalbergia sissoo, Adina cordifolia, Bombax ceibaToona ciliateSchleichera oleosa, Syzygium cumini, Mallotus phillippinensis
Mountain Temperate Sub-tropical forestPinus roxburghii, Quercus incanaOther Quercus spp.Rhododendron
Mountain Temperate ForestPinus wallichiana, Populus ciliateDeodar (Cedrus deodara), Picea smithianaAbies pindrow (Silver fir), Taxus baccata
Air temperature
  • Optimum temperature for germination
  • Rate of photosynthesis and transpiration
  • Enzymatic and microbial activity → decomposition and release of nutrients
  • Pollen grains – quality and quantity both fall with temperature
Soil temperature
  • Water absorption increase 27°C - 35°C then decreases, once as the plasma membrane permeability is affected
  • Root growth
  • Soil microbe activity
Effects of high temperature
  • Rate of photosynthesis decreases, rate of respiration increases – shortage of food reserves
  • Starved Plant becomes susceptible to insect, pest and pathogen attack
  • Early flowering and fruiting - seeds of poor quality
  • Sunburn and sun scald in seedlings
  • Coagulation of protoplasm protein
  • Changes in tree phenology
  • shifting forest, vegetation towards poles or hillside
  • changing forest composition and structure
  • devaluation of forest resources, and deforestation
Effects of low temperature - frost

Frost means the chilling of air below the freezing point.

  • Freezing of water in intercellular spaces kills young seedlings.
  • Soil lifting - Freezing soil water – expansion of soil mass – uplifting of siblings above their average soil level – frost heaving – damage the root system
  • Frost cracks on the stem.
  • Repetitive frost injuries → callus, canker formation → lowers timber quality
Frost protection
  • Thatching over nursery beds with grasses or leaves
  • Avoid clear-felling system, adopt selection or shelterwood system
  • smoky fire during the night to avoid radiation loss
  • Frost resistant species
  • Soil Mulching
  • Sprinkler irrigation in the morning
  • Higher dose of phosphorus and potassium increases resistance
frost hardyAcacia catechu, Dalbergia sissoo, Diospyros melanoxylon, Pinus roxburghii
moderately frost hardyAdina cordifolia, Anogeissus latifolia, Dalbergia latifolia, Gmelina arborea, Bombax ceiba
Frost tender speciesAcacia nilotica, Azadirachta indica, Tectona grandis, Shorea robusta (die back), Terminalia arjuna
Adaptation for high temperature
  • Morphological
    • Converting leaves into thorns
    • Shedding leaves during summertime
    • Reducing leaf size and surface area
    • Vertical orientation of lives and leaf rolling
    • Reflective leaf hairs
    • waxy leaf surface
  • Membrane
    • Agave, Cacti - more portion of the saturated fatty acids with higher melting points in membrane lipids → maintain the fluidity and stability at high temperature
  • Heat shock proteins (HSPs)
    • Low molecular mass proteins - chaperone function

Frost resistance

Internal factors (frost resistance)

  • Water content in the cell – more water less resistance
  • Osmotic concentration of cell colloids – higher concentration – less chance of freezing
  • permeability of cell to water – high → drain access water quickly
External factors
  • Temperature – rapid fall increases danger of internal formation
  • Season of growth - frost resistance varies with season
  • Light – less duration – less new growth – more frost hardness

Snow

Benefits
  • Favourable for distribution of Deodar, fur and spruce
  • Winter rainfall – regeneration of Deodar, flowering stimulation in Apple
  • Seed bank for conifers - protect against damages from insect, fungi, rodent
  • Access blanket to prevent further drop in temperature
  • Source of water for rivers
Harms
  • Shorten the vegetative growth period
  • Favors growth of certain fungi, for example, Fomes
  • Snow sliding – soil erosion, uproot tree
  • Mechanical bending of the stems and poles – unfit for commercial utilization
  • Snow accumulation – breaking of branches and tops of trees

Wind

Benefits
  • Anemophily - Wind pollination – pollen is distributed by wind – mangrove
  • Anemochory - seed disperse by wind – conifers
  • Maintain body temperature through evaporation
  • Fresh supply of carbon dioxide
  • remove pollution, dust from the Urban centers
Harms
  • Desiccating effect - Tree in the open and on the ridges on the hills are short in height and high taping rate in their boles
  • Bending of tree stem, formation of flag tree
  • Tree uproot (wind-throw) or windfall, damage to branches
  • Fans the forest fire – increases fire damage
  • Increases transpiration rate – loss of moisture
  • Wind erosion
  • Salt spray in coastal areas

Moisture

  • 90% part of plant sap, agent of pollination and seed dispersal, essential for germination, medium of mineral absorption, maintain body temperature, translocation of food to different body parts, movement of plant parts, expansion of roots and maintaining the turgidity of main steam, role in photosynthesis, required soil formation, chemical and mechanical weathering of rocks
Water logging
  • anaerobic soil→bacteria activates→nitrate, sulphate→NHX3,HX2S→toxic gaseskill plants\ce{anaerobic soil -> bacteria activates -> nitrate,sulphate ->NH3, H2S ->[toxic gases] kill plants}anaerobic soil​bacteria activates​nitrate,sulphate​NHX3​,HX2​Stoxic gases​kill plants﻿
  • Mineral absorption reduces
  • Leaching down of nutrients and fertilizers
  • Washout the regeneration or plantation work
  • Suitable species – Eucalyptus spp., Syzygium cumini (Jamun), Terminalia arjuna (Arjun), Acacia nilotica (Babul)

Drought

Shortage of moisture due to rainfall or due to poor water holding capacity of the soil

Plants growing under arid habitats are known as Xerophytes.

Water tappers - Phreatophytes
  • Long deep tap root system
  • Prosopis cineraria (Khejri), Prosopis juliflora, Acacia nilotica (Babool), Acacia senegal, Azadirachta indica (Neem), Ziziphus mauritiana (Ber).
Water saver (Xerophyte)
  • Sunken stomata – embedded deep into the leaf layers and partially covered by cuticle and hair - Pinus spp.
  • Closing the stomata rapidly and completely - temporary wilting and leaf rolling to avoid damaged by desiccation
  • Thick and waterproof cuticle
  • high osmotic pressure in cells – strongly bind water molecules
  • Rolling out and rolling in of the leaf to reduce effective leaf surface area
  • Scotoactive stomata - CAM plants - Open during the night and close during daytime - Cactus, Opuntia, Bryophyllum
Water storer
  • Flashy and thick roots - succulent plants - Cactus
Drought hardy
  • Acacia nilotica, Acacia senegal, Acacia tortilis, Albizzia lebbeck, Azadirachta indica, Boswellia serrata, Eucalyptus camaldulensis, Prosopis spp., Diospyros melanoxylon, Ziziphus spp.
Drought sensitive
  • Madhuca indica, Mangifera indica, Shorea robusta, Tectona grandis, Terminalia arjuna

Edaphic factors
  • Effects - Seed Germination, Anchor growing plant, Nutrient and water – hardpan, Air to the roots
Mycorrhiza

Mycorrhiza is the symbiotic relationship between fungi and higher plants. Mycorrhiza fungi are composed of fine, tubular filaments called hyphae. The mass of the hyphae that forms the fungus body is called mycelium

Types of Mycorrhiza

Ecto-Mycorrhiza
  • Fungal mycelium formed thick sheath or mantel around the
    lateral roots,
    and some mycelia penetrate between cortical cells. The network of fungi surrounding cortical cells is called hartignet.
  • External fungal hyphae that are much finer than the plant roots reach way beyond the areas of nutrient deficient soil near the roots → improve root systems capability to absorb nutrients.
  • Fungal partners - Ascomycetes, Basidiomycetes
  • Higher plants - conifers (Chir Pine, Deodar, Fir, Spruce), Salix, Casuarina, Eucalyptus, Dipterocarpaceae.
Endo-Mycorrhiza

Fungal hyphae enter the cell establishing direct contact with cortex cell’s cytoplasm. No need to form a hartignet or fungal mantle.

Occur in 90% of herbaceous and woody plants.

Fungus – Phycomycetes, VAM (vascular-arbuscular mycorrhiza)

Importance of Mycorrhiza
  • Fungal filaments work as root hairs – increasing net absorption surface area – increasing absorption of moisture and minerals – drought tolerance
  • Fungus release organic acids – change the soil pH favourable for phosphate fixation – increase availability of unavailable minerals
  • Some fungi fix atmospheric nitrogen – plant can grow in nitrogen deficient soil, whereas other plants cannot
  • Produce some growth hormones – Auxin, gibberellin
  • Phosphate reservoir
  • Mycorrhiza induced resistance (MIR)
    • Improved plant nutrient status – helps plant to fight competition, biotic, and biotic statuses
    • Inter-plant signalling - plants use fungal network to warn each other of incoming threats through proteins like Allelochemicals
    • Decrease space for attachment to other harmful fungi
    • Change root structure – promote colonization by non-pathogenic rhizobacteria and other microbial flora.
  • Increase salt tolerance
  • Increase resistance to heavy metal toxicity
Inoculation of Mycorrhiza into the plantation site or nursery plant roots
  • Planting infected plants and roots
  • Infected soil
  • fungal spore, Mycelium inoculation

Bio-fertilizers

  • Fertilizers: supply certain elements essential to the growth of plants
Classification
  • Nitrogen
    • Symbiotic : Legumes - Rhizobium (Acacia nilotica, Cassia fistula, Delonix regia, Sissoo)
      • Casurina and Alnus - Frankia
      • Azolla leaves - Anabena azallae
      • Cycas roots - Nostoc
    • Free-living
      • Aerobic - Azotobacter, Azospirillium in cereals
      • Non-aerobic - Clostridium
      • Cyanobacteria
  • Phosphate dissolving
    • Fungi - Fusarium and Mycorrhiza
    • Bacteria - Bacillus

Benefits

  • soil fertility, growth regulators, soil structure, chemical composition, resistance to disease, tolerance, more nutrient update
How to increase nitrogen fixation
  • Intercropping of legumes
  • soil moisture maintenance at optimum level
  • New strains of nitrogen fixers
  • Inexpensive nitrification inhibitors as neem cake
Essential plant nutrients

Criteria of essentiality –Arnon 1954 - absence –

  • Plant can't complete life cycle
  • Can be corrected only by that nutrient
  • Must directly impact plant

Nine macro nutrients (NPK, CHO, Ca Mg S)

  • CHO – from atmosphere as COX2,HX2O\ce{CO2, H2O}COX2​,HX2​O﻿
  • N – nitrogen fixation
  • Phosphorus, Potassium, Calcium, Magnesium, Sulfur – soil – soluble salts

Six micro nutrients

  • Manganese, Chlorine, Boron, Iron, Copper, Nickel

Importance

  • Component of biomolecules
  • Component of energy related compounds – phosphorus in ATP
  • Activate or deactivate enzymes
  • Alter osmotic pressure – potassium – opening and closing of stomata

Nutrient cycling

  • Internal

    between old dying parts to new developing parts – the mobilising nitrogen from roots to spring growth of leaves

  • External
    • Open - agriculture – once nutrient goes below rhizosphere do not return because crops do not have deep taproots
    • Closed - forest ecosystem – different root systems at different depths – nutrients are entirely absorbed after their decomposition
    • Closed and leaky – agroforestry

Physiographic factors

Latitude

Relationship of angle of solar rays with heating of earth surface

Altitude

  • Xerophyte at low altitude, Chamaephyte at high altitude
  • Reduced tree diameter, height
  • Flat tree at mountain age due to wind pressure
  • Prolonged maturity period
  • Higher water stress – due to more evaporation rate and low soil moisture

Configuration of land surface

  • Rainfall
  • Wind direction
  • Temperature – Valley and mountain breeze
  • Frost in the valley
  • valley soil - deeper

Slope, Aspect and exposure

  • Slope

    Angle between land surface and the horizontal plane

  • Aspect

    Direction of slope with respect to geographical north

  • Exposure

    Relationship between a site and its local weather, especially wind

  • Effect of slope
    • Intensity of solar radiation – surface temperature
    • Surface runoff and drainage – steeper the slope, greater than runoff and better drainage
    • Soil erosion, moisture availability and depth of soil - Hill top soil get washed with rainwater – low humus content
    • Vegetation
      • concave: luxurious with superficial root system
      • convex: deciduous with robust roots
      • Straight: devoid of vegetation
  • Effect of aspect
    • Solar radiation and temperature – southern aspect of Himalaya is warmer than northern aspect
    • East aspect is cooler – because it gets morning sunlight when temperature is low
    • Rainfall – seaside face of Western Ghats get more rainfall
    • Soil formation process
    • Vegetation
      • Sunny slope – less moisture – drought resistant
      • Shady slope – shade loving plants - ex- Forb
      • Himalaya – Deodar on Southern aspect, fir and spruce on northern aspect
    • high biomass on northern slope → high organic carbon – better nutrient cycling – high microbial activity

Biotic factors

RelationDescriptionABExample
CommensalismOne benefits, other is not harm+0- Orchids
- Vascular plants that grow on other trees only for support
AmensalismOne is harmed other is not affected-0Allelopathy
MutualismTwo species completely depend on each other++Lichen (fungi + algae)
Proto-cooperationBoth benefit, but can live separately++Soil bacteria, fungi + plants
Symbiosis++Mycorrhiza and Rhizobium
EpiphytePlants grow over other plant and do not have any soil contactorchids
Parasiticone species depends upon another for food and protection - without killing the host+-Sandalwood (Santalum alba)
PredationOne species draws food by killing the host+-
CompetitionFor food, water, and nutrients--- intra specific, interspecific
  • Plants and animals
    • Positive – seed and pollen dispersion
    • Negative – consumption and destruction of seeds and regeneration, spreading plant disease
  • Plants and man
    • Positive – conservation and protection, afforestation, introduction of exotics
    • Negative – shifting cultivation, accidental forest fire, illicit felling and encroachment, grazing and lopping, permanent deforestation
Influence of forest on their environment

Climate

  • Canopy intercepts sun-rays and precipitation
  • retards wind speed – on average 20 to 60% near the surface – utilized to create shelter-belts and windbreak
  • Retards loss of heat through long wave radiation
  • Humidity
    • 98-99% water is lost through transpiration – 5-15% more humidity than open area
    • Cover the soil surface – retard rapid moisture loss from soil
    • Higher humidity moderates temperature
  • Increased moisture and reduced temperature often creates local rainfall – 15 to 20% more rainfall than open land
  • Closed canopy insulate ground vegetation from frost
Hydrology

Hydrology is the scientific study of water on earth surface and beneath the surface of earth, its movement, distribution, physical and chemical properties, and its relationship with the living and material components of forest ecosystem.

  • Interception : Forest canopy serving as barrier against precipitation reaching the ground
  • Infiltration : Entry of water into the soil – 5% higher in forest than in open field
  • Percolation: Downward movement of water through soil profile
  • Stem flow : flow of intercepted water down the trunk or stem of a plant. It also transports accumulated nutrients on the canopy from dry deposition or animal feces directly into the soil.
  • Aerodynamic roughness, higher albedo, evapotranspiration
  • Cloud water deposition
Soil
  • Composition
    • Recycled minerals
    • formation of new minerals through breaking of parental rock
    • addition of organic material - chelating substance, humus – improve soil buffering capacity
  • roots loosen the soil aggregation
  • leaf litter protects soil - lower temperature variation in surface soil than air temperature
  • Interlocking roots system binds the soil – reduce erosion
  • Soil moisture
    • by reducing water-runoff, improving water percolation
    • loosens soil mass to improve its holding capacity
    • reduces water loss to evaporation
  • Soil erosion
    • Lesser run-off because of interception
Environmental conservation
  • COX2−OX2\ce{CO2–O2}COX2​−OX2​﻿ balance
  • Water, quality, and storage
  • Prevent soil erosion
  • Storehouse of genetic diversity
  • Reduce pollution
  • Green jobs
  • IPCC 2014 report – deforestation and forest degradation is second largest source of carbon dioxide emission
  • ISFR 2017 report – 7080 MMT of carbon is stored in Indian forest – neutralized 12% of India's GHGs
Tree morphology
  • Stand: Group of trees that are relatively homogeneous in composition, age class distribution, structure growing on a site of uniform quality

Kinds of stands

Based on composition

  • Pure - one species forms the stand
  • Mixed

Structure/form

  • Even aged - single cohort
  • Two aged - double cohort
  • Uneven - multiple cohort
  • even aged stratified - multiple species

Stand density

  • over stocked
  • fully stocked
  • under stocked

  • Even / Pure or uneven aged / Mixed stand
    Even / Pure / Artificial RegenerationUneven / Mixed stand / Natural regeneration
    Uniformity in tree size, shape
    Better bole formationmulti layer roots – closed nutrient cycle, well bound soil particles, better soil utility
    Better natural pruning
    Smaller crown
    Better quality wood – less taperMistakes in artificial regeneration can be corrected
    Easier and cheaper to apply silvicultural operations, mechanised harvestingNo risk of soil exhaustion and deterioration that is there under pure crops
    Higher economic returns per unit area - Higher yield and qualityDifferent leaf shedding periods – less leaf litter – reduced fire risk
    Can be easily converted or modified to meet the present and future demands of the market
    artificial regenerationnatural regeneration
    One or two speciesHundreds of species
    Trees are of same ageall age classes
    one layer of canopyMany layers of canopy - reduce rainfall impact → prevent soil erosion
    Reduction in richness and diversity – less wild animals, birdsAesthetically pleasing
    leaves of single species – slow decomposition – poor physical and chemical property – low soil productivity
    higher risk risk of insect pest damagesMore resilient against attack by pest, disease, insects, etc.
    Higher threat of soil erosion when soil is exposed after felling operation
    Opportunity to select and raise the most profitable species or exotic species
    labor intensive hence higher cost of production
    employment generation
    Improved and superior phenotype
    Crops are fully stocked
  • Stand density: Number of trees per unit area of an interested species
  • Canopy density land area covered by canopyland area×100\frac{\text{land area covered by canopy}}{\text{land area}}\times 100%land arealand area covered by canopy​×100﻿
  • Canopy bulk density: Measure of how closely canopy fuels are packed
Stand crown classification
  • Dominant (D) : uppermost leaf canopy
    • Predominant (D1)\left(D_1\right)(D1​)﻿
      • No vertical Competition
      • Well developed crown
      • Maximum tree diameter
      • Direct access to sunlight
    • Codominant (D2:56×D1)\left(D_2 : \frac{5}{6}\times D_1\right)(D2​:65​×D1​)﻿
      • Crown well developed, but medium size
      • Only tips get sunlight
  • Dominated (d:34×D1)\left(d:\frac{3}{4}\times D_1\right)(d:43​×D1​)﻿
    • narrow and short crown
  • Suppressed (s:12−58×D1)\left(s:\frac{1}{2}-\frac{5}{8}\times D_1\right)(s:21​−85​×D1​)﻿
    • Leading shoots over-topped by neighbours or shaded on all sides
  • Uneven aged
    • Free - large, well developed the crown
    • Restricted
    • Confined

Succession
  • Pioneers species

    First species that establishes itself

  • Seral Stages

    Intermediate stage

  • Climax stage

    Mature, final, stable community

  • Primary succession

    Colonizer grow on barren land

  • Secondary succession

    Previously available organic matter

  • Nudation

    Process of development of a bare area - erosion, volcanic eruption, forest fire, landslide

  • Invasion or migration
  • Establishment

    Process of establishment of plant in new area from its germination to the reproduction

  • Aggregation

    After establishment, individuals of species increasing number and they come closer to each other

  • Competition

    After aggregation, increasing population creates competition for light, space, moisture, Minerals nutrients

  • Sub climax

    Immediately proceeding to climax

  • Climax

    The final stage

  • Post climax

    A strip of vegetation of higher life forms occurring within climatic climax, for example, a forest in a grassland community

Importance
  • Classifying forest
  • Deciding silviculture system and operations
    • Climax – least disturbance – selection system
    • Pre-climax – heavy felling
  • Selecting suitable species
    • Immature soil – pre-climax species
    • Mature soil – climax species
  • Economically importance species at pre-climax stage – maintaining the stage through control on biotic factors, for example, grazing

Types of succession

  • On the basis of previously available organic matter
    • Primary : Slower - alpine areas after landslide
    • Secondary : forest vegetation after forest fire
  • On the basis of cause of succession
    • Autogenic – community modifies itself and its environment – Amazon rainforest
    • Allogenic – due to external force
  • On the basis of substratum
    • Xerarch - dry rock, extremely dry conditioner
    • Mesarch - moist, well-aerated soil
    • Hydrarch - wetland
  • Other
    • Induced succession - human activity responsible for succession – Keoladeo Ghana after dam construction in mid 18th century
    • Cyclic succession – a small number of species replace each other over time
    • Retrogressive succession – succession is obstructed by nature or biotic factors that push it a few stages back – in north Indian planes Sal Forest converted into Sal Savanna due to over-grazing and shifting cultivation

      Causes of retrogressive succession

      • Climate – drought, flood
      • Physiographic – landslide
      • Man-made – shifting cultivation, fire, lopping
      • Biotic – insect pest attack

Causes of Succession

  • Initiating
    • Initial causes of secondary succession
      • Climatic – drought, frost
      • Edaphic - soil erosion
      • Biotic – forest fire
    • Initial causes of primary succession
      • New lava planes after volcanic eruption
      • forest fire
      • heavy landslide
      • complete destruction of existing forest vegetation along with humus
        • long-term persisting flooding
        • Heavy surface soil erosion, and deposition
  • continuation: Establishment, aggregation, competition
  • Stabilising: According to local climate, soil, other complex factors

Succession in various ecosystems

  • Temperate mountain: Ice sheet/ glacier → Bare site → Shrubs/ grass → Pinus wallichiana (Himalayan Pine)→ Cedrus deodara → Abies pindrow (Silver fur)
  • Riverine: Bare site – fertile alluvial → Grasses like Saccharum tamarix → Acacia catechu → Lagerstroemia spp. (Nandi) → Shorea robusta
  • Estuarine or sea coast : Bare site with heavy alluvial deposit → Mangrove shrubs → Heritiera spp. (slow growing salt tolerant) → freshwater swamp (without Heritiera) → Evergreen Forest
  • Sand dunes : Bare site → Dune grass (Cenchrus, Andropogon) → Shrub (Euphorbia) → Pre-climax (Acacia spp.) → Anogeissus pendula

Theories of plant succession

Mono climax theory or climatic climax theory

  • F. E. Clement
  • Only climatic conditions control succession so only one type of climax community.

Poly climax theory

  • Tansley
  • Soil Moisture, nutrients, topography, slope, aspect, fire, grazing
  • Climate control – climatic climax – evergreen forest in Andaman and Nicobar
  • Edaphic control - edaphic climax - Babool forest in black cotton soil
  • Topography – topographic climax - Lower Chir-Pine forest occurring below 1000 m in subtropical pine forest.

Information theory

Fosberg, Odum

Climax is achieved upon balance of energy and nutrients cycling

Climax pattern hypothesis

Whittaker

climax community depends on totality of environmental factors – climate, site, soil, fire, animal — therefore no discrete number of climax community

Champion & Seth classification
Major Group: 1. tropical forest2. Mountain subtropical3. Mountain temperate4. Subalpine5. alpine

Northern,
Southern

- evergreen without conifers

4. Littoral and Swamp
4A. Littoral forest
  • intertidal zone, from high water mark to coastal area
  • 27°-30°C
  • 1000–3000 mm
  • Vegetation: Casurina equisetifolia, Manikara littoris, Callophyllum inophyllum
4B. Tidal swamp Forest

Over Ganges-Brahmaputra delta

forest type distribution species
Mangrove scrub Krishna Godavari, Sundarban DeltaAvicenia, Exocaria, Ceriops spp.
Mangrove ForestMahanadi, krishna Godavari delta, sundarban beltRhizophora spp., Avicenia, Bruguira spp.
Saltwater mixed forest of Heritaria sundarban areaHeritaria, ceriops, xylocarpa
Brackish water mixed forest sundarban + Andaman and NicobarHeriteria, Xylocarpa, Brugeria
13. Himalayan dry temperate forest
  • Inner ranges of the Himalayas
  • Ladakh, Chamba, Garhwal
  • -7°C – +17°C
  • 8–80 cm rain
  • Populus, Salix forests
