  • Trans Himalayan Region of Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, and Kashmir.
  • Xerophytic formations
  • Dwarf shrubs
  • Eurotica, Juniperus wallichiana, Juniperus communis, Artemisia

Natural regeneration

Objectives of propagation

  • Increase number of plants of same species
  • Preserve essential characteristics of the plants
  • Introduce exotics

By seeds

  • Good seed year

    Generally, after 5 to 6 years, a plant produces seeds in maximum quantity and best quality that is called as good seed year.

  • Seed dissemination
    • Phylly - pollen dissemination
    • Chory - seed dissemination
    • Hydrochory - Coconut
    • Zoochory - fig seeds by birds
    • Anemochory - Conifers
  • Seed Germination: better germination capacity — From middle aged tree + Bigger size

Flowering in bamboo

  1. Continuous annual flowering
    • Arundinaria falcata in Shivalik and Inner Himalayan region
    • Ochlandra travancorica in Malabar region
  1. Gregarious flowering - when a patch of forest is made of one species of Bamboo and all start flowering roughly at the same time
    • most Bamboo species
  1. Sporadic flowering - Bamboo forest flowers at different times without showing any flowering pattern – induced by environmental factors such as drought, cold instead of genetics
    • Guadua angustifolia

Factors for seed establishment

  • Climatic - hardy, tender
  • Edaphic
    • Litter on surface – mechanical barrier
    • Laterite Soil - poor nutrients
  • Biotic
    • Animal grazing, trampling, browsing
    • Pest attack
  • Genetic
    • Growth rate
    • Resistance

Ensuring successful natural regeneration

  1. coppicing of seedlings or trees
  1. Trenching for getting root suckers
  1. Reducing canopy so that light can penetrate - regeneration felling
  1. Removing weed and litter on ground
  1. Improving soil condition - removing hardpan, adding Mycorrhiza
  1. Grazing control
  1. Slash Disposal - to reduce fire risk
  1. Pest control

Dying back in Shorea robusta

  • Phenomena - Shoot portion of seedling keeps on dying - produced “whippy new shoots” next year. Root remains alive. When adverse conditions are gone, it produces a shoot that doesn't die and can go on developing.
  • It takes decades for establishment
  • Reasons - Inadequate light, dense weed growth, leaf litter as physical barrier, frost and drought, grazing and browsing
  • Shorea robusta - dying back in summer – regeneration in rainy season

Root sucker

When shoots arise from roots

Ex- Dalbergia sissoo

Inducing formation

  1. Felling the parent tree
  1. Injuring root by digging trench

Coppice

Method of vegetative reproduction – tree cut from ground level to produce coppice shoot

Root–collar shoot – produce better trees than stool coppice because it has developed its own root system.

Factors

  1. Strong coppicer species - Shorea robusta, Dalbergia sissoo, Prosopis juliflora
  1. Best season – when root is full of food reserved, February–March (not Monsoon)
  1. Age – young saplings and poles

Pollarding

  • Method of cutting stem at suitable height to obtain new shoots. (pollard)
  • Examples
    1. Salix spp. (Willow - J&K)
    1. Hardiwickia binata (Fibre - Kurnool)
    1. Cotoneaster bacillaris (Walking stick)
    1. Grewia oppositifolia (Fibre and fodder - UK, UP)
    1. Moringa oleifera

Artificial regeneration
  • Definition

    Renewal of forest by sewing, planting, or other artificial means.

    It includes

    • afforestation for non-forest area
    • Reforestation on cleaned forest

Objectives

  1. Supplement natural regeneration – for adequate and uniform stocking, Replacing natural regeneration, Reforestation, Afforestation of wasteland
  1. Support particular industries like fibre, silk, cricket bat, paper & pulp, resin
  1. changing crop composition
  1. Forest enrichment – increasing proportion of valuable species
  1. Social and agroforestry - roadside plantation
  1. Rural employment generation
  1. Environmental conservation, coastal protection
Artificial versus natural regeneration

Factors affecting plantation activity

  • Finance
  • Land
  • Labour
  • Infrastructure
  • Market
  • Social and culture factors – local demands

Plantation organization

Seed collection → land identification→ nursery for raising stock → pre-planting activities → sowing and planting → protection and maintenance → tending operations → rotating and harvesting

Plantation schedule

  • Definition

    A timeline for completion of various plantation activity

  • Grading of nursery stock – Y - 1 → sowing in nursery should start 1 to 3 years in advance

Success and failure of plantation

  • Technical factors
    • Selection of correct species
    • Proper size of nursery stock
    • Proper plantation technique
  • Socio-economic
    • Participation of local population
    • Financial commitment by government
    • Training
  • Infrastructure
    • Nursery
    • Seed
    • Storage
  • protection against biotic interference
Advantages of plantation
  • Can be grown on degraded land that is not suitable for agriculture
  • Can be grown near market or industries
  • More timber volume production
  • Species as per market demand
  • Can be raised beyond natural forest
  • Short and long rotation crop can be grown together
  • Easier to forecast yield
  • Checks soil erosion
  • Carbon sequestration
  • Employment generation

Choice of species

Site Factors

  • Climate
    • hot dry - Acacia, Albizzia, Prosopis juliflora
    • Cold desert - Salix, Populus, Juniper
  • Soil
    • Black soil - expansion causes crack - Babool (Acacia nilotica), Tamarindus indica, Pongamia pinnata
    • Laterite soil - Burma Ironwood (Xylia xylocarpa)
  • Biotic factor
    • Grazing pressure - Gliricidia sepium for fodder production

Silvicultural properties of species

  1. Ecological need of plant: Newly formed riverine bed → only Pioneers species (Kadamba)
  1. Weather species is light demander (clear felling), shade bearer
  1. Species impact on site – monoculture reduces fertility
  1. Rotation time
  1. Disease susceptibility - Dalbergia sissoo - root rot disease

Economic factor

  • Cost versus return
  • Demand and supply — Eucalyptus, poplar, bamboo

Purpose of plantation

  • Industrial need
    • Paper & pulp - Poplar, eucalyptus, bamboo
    • Silk – Mulberry
    • Bidi - Diospyros melanoxylon (Tendu)
    • cricket bat - Salix (Willow)
  • Social need – fodder, firewood
  • Environment protection
    • check soil and wind erosion
    • green buffer around industrial complex
    • Windbreak and shelterbelt to check effect of hot and cold wind
  • Aesthetic – parks, avenues

Hardwood versus softwood

hardwood softwood
broad leaves conifers
Dark colour, heavy weightLight colour, light weight
Comparatively hard, durable due to vessels, heavy deposit of gum and lignin
Construction work paper and pulp industry

Indigenous versus exotic

Indigenous

Grown naturally in the country or particular region of it

Advantages

  • Already adapted to environment – less susceptible to disease and pest
  • Market is already developed
  • easy growth forecast
  • Conservation of native species

Exotic species

Grown outside the limit of their natural zone of distribution. Example – (Tectona grandis) Teak growing in UP.

  1. Prosopis juliflora - Mexico
  1. Acacia tortilis - Israel
  1. Russian poplar - USA
  1. Bambusa burmanica - Burma
  1. Salix alba - Europe
advantages limitation
Provides wider choice of speciesNeed time to acclimatise – cannot fulfil immediate need
Absence of pest and disease for few rotationsDifficult to control spread due to absence of natural pest
higher productivitycannot produce viable seed because outside their natural habitat – Eucalyptus even after 200 years
can take advantage of R&D of foreign nationPest and disease after few rotation – pink disease in Eucalyptus spp.
may perform better outside native range due to absence of pest and disease. For example leaf eating insect on eucalyptus common in Australia is absent in IndiaEcologically less value than indigenous species – no linkage with local ecosystem

Steps to introduce exotics

  1. Species trial
    • Can it grow naturally or vegetatively?
    • Seed Viability
    • Do physical, mechanical properties meet our demand?
  1. Homo-climes - identify similar climatic requirement
  1. See if Mycorrhiza can be introduced
  1. Plasticity – adaptability two wide ranging environment – Eucalyptus camaldulensis grows even in semi desert
  1. Multiplication and distribution

Eucalyptus

advantage disadvantage
fast growing – 10 year rotationHigh water consumption – 20 to 40 L per day per tree
High degree of adaptabilityAllelopathy - prevents and growth and sales germination – increased runoff and soil erosion
Easy to raise and manageMake soil acidic due to higher rate of calcium recycling
high survival rate
no grazing issue
high economic returns – timber in paper and pulp

Nurse crop vs cover crop

Nurse crop

  • Crops raised to help the less hardy species — usually removed at early stage as soon as they serve their purpose
  • Function — protection from sun, Frost, biotic factors, etc.
  • Example — Arhar, Castor → seedlings of Teak and Sal

cover crop

  • Subsidiary crop with goal of providing cover over soil to reduce risk of soil, erosion due to exposure
  • Often needed for tea, rubber, and other economic crops
  • Example — Indigofera tinctoria (Neel) for 1st year Sal plantation

Fast Growing species

criteria

  • Timber production : >10 m3 / ha/yr\gt\pu{10 m3/ha/yr}>10 m3/ha/yr﻿
  • Young plantation — height growth >60 cm/yr\gt\pu{60 cm/yr}>60 cm/yr﻿

advantage

  • Early merchantability
  • Higher yield
  • Early maturity → less probability of damage

disadvantage

  • Physical and mechanical properties
    • Not for furniture or construction
    • For pulp, paper
  • Exhausts site’s soil and water
Seed supply

Seed collection

Seed requirement

Q: quantity of seed required

A: area to be planted during a year in ha

D: density of plants per ha

S: survival percentage of plantation expressed in decimal

N: number of seeds in 1 KG

G: germination percentage in decimal

M: mortality percentage in decimal

Procedure

  1. Collecting from standing tree — climb tree / use stairs → pluck seeds
  1. From crown during commercial failing
  1. Collect from fallen fruits
    • e.g. Terminalia arjuna

    Issues —

    • May collect immature seed
    • Rodents could damage them
  1. Do not collect from —
    • Young tree, old tree
    • Suppressed tree
    • Diseased tree
    • Self pollinated tree

Good seed year

Pinus roxburghii, Cedrus deodara — 4-5 years

Seed processing

  • Cleaning — blowing, winnowing, sieving, screening
  • Pre-curing — storing immature seed for ripening
  • De-pulping — fleshy fruits
  • Grading — based on shape, size

Seed storage

  • Aim — to retain viability of seed
  • Methodology
    • Reduce respiration rate (consumes its internal nutrients slowly — longer survival) → by
      • Reducing temperature
      • Reducing moisture
    • Other factors impacting storage
      • More light — harmful
      • Moisture — harmful
      • Ripen seed — longer store
Orthodox versus recalcitrant seed
orthodox recalcitrant
Can be dried to moisture content less than 5%mature content must be above 20 to 30%
From trees of semi-arid environment, legumestrees of warm, humid, temperate environment
Can be stored for several years few days to some months
Dormancy often occursDormancy is absent
Acacia, Albizia, ProsopisShorea robusta, Syzygium cumini (Jamun), Azadirachta indica (Neem), Mangifera indica (Mango)

Seed treatment

Seed dormancy

  • Dormancy: State of physiological inactivity in which seat does not germinate even influence of favourable environment.
  • Types
    1. Exogenous or seed coat dormancy
      • impermeable to oxygen and moisture
      • mechanical resistance for radical to come out
      • Teak, Betula, Many Leguminous
    1. Endogenous, Internal, embryo dormancy
      • Underdeveloped embryo
      • Lack of metabolic reaction
      • Inhibitory chemicals – ammonia, ethylene
    1. Combined (exo+endo)
    1. Induced dormancy - unfavourable conditions – water logging

Removing seed coat dormancy

  • Water soaking for 48 hours – AAP
  • Alternate wetting and drying – Teak
  • Scarification (removal of outer layer) – cutting with knife, rubbing with sandpaper, acid Scarification
  • Natural methods
    • Passing through animal body – goats eat AP
    • Fermentation – partial
    • Light fire – teak

Removing embryonic dormancy

  • cold stratification - when seeds are fully developed but initiated from immediate germination for physiological reasons - to wait for favourable season – Ex. Deodar seeds wait for end of winter, snow melting
  • Hormonal treatment
  • X-ray, gamma ray treatment

Seed dressing or seed palleting

  • larger seeds easy to scatter and areal sowing
  • Fertilizer – nourishment
  • Growth simulator hormones – root-shoot initiation
  • Fungicide or insecticide – prevent dumping off type diseases

Seed testing

Purity test

  • Find percentage of true seed — without seeds of other species, weed, leaf twigs
  • Purity%=weight of clean seedtotal weight of sample×100%\text{Purity} \%={\text{weight of clean seed}\over\text{total weight of sample}}\times100\%Purity%=total weight of sampleweight of clean seed​×100%﻿

Viability test

  • X-ray test
    • Easy and quick
    • No need to dissect seeds

Seed weight

  • Large seed – 100 seeds, small seed – 1000 seeds

Moisture content test

  • Put in oven at 105 °C\pu{105\degree C}105 °C﻿ for a few hours

Germination test

  • Induce seeds to germinate and grow
  • Germination percentage : percentage of seed that can produce using
  • Germination energy : measure of germination speed
Forest nursery

Forest nursery: An area where plants are grown for transplanting or for use as stock for vegetative reproduction.

Types of nursery

permanent temporary
To meet requirement of 1–2 year of plantation work
centrally located near plantation site, shifts as plantation shifts
conveniently situated by roadside
Have suitable layout, road, inspection paths, beds for sowing and transplanting, irrigation and drainage facilities, seed store, labor hut, etc. no elaborate road, bed layout
  • Dry nursery – without irrigation or artificial watering
  • Wet nursery — with
  • Seedling nursery - only seedling raised
  • transplant Nursery – seedlings are transplanted to prepare for forest planting stock.

Factors for site selection

  • Central location – reduce transportation cost
  • Accessibility
  • Topography – flat or gentle slope
  • Soil - well drained, or loamy
  • Water availability
  • Labor availability – skilled, unskilled
Layout

Nursery beds

Seed bed/nursery bed: An area in the nursery where seeds are sowed or transplanting or cuttings are raised.

Types of nursery beds

Raised bed

  • 10–15 cm above ground
  • In high rainfall area
  • To prevent moisture

Level bed

  • Normal rainfall area

Sunken bed

  • 10–30 cm deep
  • area of low rainfall
  • To avoid water flow outside the bed

  • Seedling bed
  • Transplant bed

Methods of sowing

Broadcast

  • Seed are sowed directly by hand

Challenges

  • Only for large seed
  • Cannot maintain spacing
  • Seeds on surface prone to attacked by rodents, pests
  • Weeding

Dibbling

  • Both space and depth can be maintained

Drill

  • Seeds are sown in the trenches made by the board
  • Both small and large seed

Method of raising stock in nursery

  • Sowing in bed – transplanting in polythene bag
  • Sowing in polythene bag
  • Sowing in bed – transplanting with – ball of earth around root, or naked root
  • Sowing in bed – growing seedling – prepare stumps
  • Cutting stem – plant in nursery - Salix

Pre-sowing seed treatments

Seed coating or seed dressing

Application of exogenous material on surface of seeds to

  • improve appearance
  • handling characteristics
  • delivering active compounds
    • protect the seed against pathogen
    • increase germination and plant growth

Seed pelleting

Heavy coating of inert material

  • increase size, shape, weight
  • uniformity

plant-ability - precise

  • metering
  • spacing
  • depth

Seed priming

Controlled hydration of seeds to a level that permits pre-metabolic activity to proceed, but prevents the actual emergence of the radical

Types

  • Hydro
  • Halo
  • Osmo

Protection of nursery

  • Seed dressing - coat of fungicide, seed repellent, cow-dung
  • Soil sterilisation – solarisation, fumigation
  • Mulching of bed
  • Shading during hot – dry season
  • wedding, cleaning
Containers

Brick container

soil:sand:manure = 1:1:1 ratio

10 cm deep cavity

Dona cup

Leaves of Bauhinia vahlii

Bamboo baskets

Earthen pots

Poly bags

  • Lightweight, durable, cheaper

root trainers

  • Air prune the roots extending outside the container. Develop stronger root system.
  • Roots are not damaged while removing plant.
  • Improve survival chances.
stump Preparation

Tectona grandis, Dalbergia sissoo - stumps give best plants

Grading of seedlings before plantation

Need: Success of plantation depends on quality of seedlings, transplants

selection criteriarejection criteria
balanced root-shoot ratioUndersized seedling
collar diameter - sturdy and capable of supporting itselfpoor root growth
transplanting, root pruning – helps develop fibrous and stronger root systemInfected with pest and disease
Height:
Conifer – 25–50 cm
Broadleaved species – 50-100 cm
damaged

Nursery calendar

Nursery Register

Vegetative propagation
  • Vegetative propagation: The method to regenerate the new independent plant from the body tissue of the parent plant.

Objectives of propagation

  • Increase number of plants of same species
  • Preserve essential characteristics of the plants
  • Introduce exotics

Future prospective

Advantages and disadvantages

Techniques

Natural

  • Tuber
  • Root sucker
  • Offsets

Artificial

Macro

  • Root Sucker
  • Coppice
  • Cutting
  • Budding
  • Grafting
  • Air layering

Micro: Tissue culture

Root sucker

Coppice

Cutting

Removing portion from the parent plant for regeneration.

Rhizome cutting

Bamboo - Bambusa arundinacea, Bambusa vulgaris, Dendrocalamus strictus

Root section cutting

l=5−30 cml=\pu{5-30cm}l=5−30 cm﻿

D=0.5−2 cmD=\pu{0.5-2cm}D=0.5−2 cm﻿

  • Cut and planted during dormant season
  • Bombax ceiba, Ailanthus excels, Robinia pseudoacacia

Stump Cutting

  • Plants central axis is cut
  • portion of stem and taproot
  • l=30 cml=\pu{30cm}l=30 cm﻿
  • Tectona grandis, Bombax ceiba, Gmelina arborea, Dalbergia sissoo

Stem and branch cutting

Softwood

  • Use portion that doesn't develop into wood
  • Cut before lignification

Hardwood

Cut after lignification

Failure of cutting

  • Old age – insufficient rooting power
  • Cutting in non-dormant phase
  • Nutritional and hormonal condition of plant
  • Light, temperature, humidity, water quantity, etc.

Budding

  • Form of grafting in which scion consists of single bud
  • Potion of bark of a genetically superior plant grafted on interior plant by making incision on it

Chip budding

  • Replace a triangular bark with an epicormic bud
  • Works well in regions with shorter growing season – temperate region

T-budding / Shield budding

  • T – shaped cut in root–stock
  • Shield - shape of scion bud

Patch budding

placing a rectangular patch of bark with a bud into a similar patch cut into the rootstock

I-budding

scion: rectangle

host: I shaped cut

Grafting

Grafting: Joining plant parts together in such a way that they will readily unit and continue to grow as one plant

Whip and tongue graft

Whip graft

Cleft grafting

When size of root-stock is much bigger than scion

Side veneer grafting

Side tongue grafting

Wedge grafting

Approach grafting

Success of crafting depends on

  • Compatibility of union
  • Closeness
  • Matching of vascular cambium layers
  • Time of grafting
  • Growing condition

Layering

A way of rooting cuttings in which adventitious roots are initiated on a stem while still attached to the plant. The rooted stem (layer) is then detached, transplanted and becomes a separate plant.

Simple layering

Intact shoot is bent to the ground → covered with soil → adventitious root forms

Air layering

Portion of stem above ground is girdled → covered with rooting substrate (sphagnum moss) → girdled part roots

Mound layering

Stem is cut back to ground level → rooting medium, or soil is mounded over it

Trench layering

Stem is laid horizontally in a trench → covered with rooting substrate (sawdust) → shoots develop from nodes on the stem

Micro vegetative propagation (tissue culture)

Tissue culture: In-vitro method of vegetative reproduction via plant cell, tissue, organ.

Importance

  • Clone preservation
  • Rapid multiplication
  • Small flask – easy transport
  • Soma-clonal variation (genetic changes through tissue culture) - somatic hybridisation - develop of plants with desirable traits

Advantages

  • Produce genetically identical plants with superior traits - e.g. more volume
  • no variability → uniformity of traits
  • For species that can't produce viable seeds
  • produce pest free plants
  • Induce early flowering
  • reduce rotation Period
  • accelerate breeding process
  • Preserve genotype
  • large scale multiplication

Disadvantages

  • Expensive
  • propagules - lack the taproot system – prone to damage due to wind or cyclone
  • short-lived
  • no genetic variation – one disease can wipe out entire plantation
  • Heavy intensive management may harm environment

Mist Chambers

  • For survival of vegetative propagation
  • Water is spread intermittently
  • Maintains 95% – 100% relative humidity

Modern nursery techniques

  • Tissue culture
  • Propagation structure - Poly house, glass house, Mist chamber
  • Seed treatment - gamma ray treatment
  • Root trainers
  • Automated sensors - pH, temperature, humidity - timely and effective management

Sowing and planting

Site selection

  • Sites are usually — degraded forest, wasteland, forest area without natural vegetation, plantation along road, canal e.g. National Green Highway Corridor, CAMPA
  • Pre-planting survey —
    • Topographic character
    • Biotic factor — vegetation, biodiversity
    • edaphic factor
    • Climatic factor

Site Preparation

  1. Clearing existing vegetation
    • Tree cutting
    • Stamp removal
    • Slash disposal
  1. Treatment of forest floor
    • Burning
    • Scarification — removing organic matter OR mixing it with mineral soil by mechanical means
  1. Soil working
  1. Stacking
    • Marking spots for plantation with bamboo sticks

Soil working

Pits

  • Ordinary pits
  • For clayey and Clayey-loamy soil
  • All rainfall classes
  • Size — 30 ×30×30 cm3\pu{30\times30\times30 cm3}30 ×30×30cm3﻿, 60 ×60×60 cm3\pu{60\times60\times60 cm3}60 ×60×60cm3﻿

Ridge ditch

  • partially filled trench
  • Sowing at bottom of trench
  • For sloping sides

Selfed trench

  • areas — murramy region, hardpan region

Trench mound

  • sowing on trench
  • planting in mound
  • For areas of low and erratic rainfall

Mound

  • for waterlogged area

Seed sowing

Direct sowing

  • Only for species with large seed size - Acacia spp.
  • Seed → cheap, abundant
  • No weed growth
  • Size – good and fine texture
  • Low biotic pressure
  • Issues
    • Need large quantity of seeds
    • Spacing is not uniformly maintained
  • Methods
    • Broadcasting
    • Dibbling
    • Line sowing

Aerial seeding

  • 1980-1986 in Chambal Valley
  • Aim - stop soil erosion, increase succession progress
  • Species - Prosopis juliflora, Acacia nilotica, Acacia catechu, Dendrocalamus strictua, Albizia lebbeck, Dalbergia sissoo
  • Seed required - 20−40 kg/ha\pu{20-40 kg/ha}20−40 kg/ha﻿

Hydro-seeding

  • Seed is mixed with fertilizer, mulching material, insecticide, etc.
  • Mixture is sprayed via pressurised sprayers

Planting out

Time of planting

SKIPPED

Methods of planting

Naked root

  • When seedlings are in dormant phase
  • Advantages - Easy quick chip
  • Disadvantages – high mortality, need continuous irrigation
  • Suitable for moderately drought hardy species

Earth ball

Brick planting

Stump planting

Tectona grandis, Dalbergia sissoo, Bombax ceiba, Gmelina arborea, Pterocarpus marsupium

Container planting

Planting of cuttings

Ficus spp., Bombax ceiba, Salix spp., Populus spp.

Planting pattern

Linear

Square

Triangular

Quincunx

Maintenance of plantation

Failure of forest plantation

  • Defective plantation work - root coiling, shallow planting
  • injured seedling
  • Poor soil condition - water logged, high salt concentration
  • Weather - frost, drought
  • Insect, pest
  • Weed
  • Grazing, browsing, trampling
  • Forest fire

Solutions

  • Replace seedlings (refiling)
  • Weeding
  • soil working
  • Watering
  • Stacking - support to withstand strong wind
  • re-spacing - competing plants of same or similar species are removed to remove unnecessary competition
  • Mulching – conservation of moisture, check weed growth, thermal insulation, favour soil microbial activity
  • Protection against insect, pest
    • Pits – open soil during summer heat
    • Fumigation – fungicide, pesticide
  • Fencing - prevent grazing, browsing
    • Live fencing – non-eatable and obnoxious plants - Euphorbia, Agave, Jatropha
    • Brushwood fencing - dense plantation of woody plants - Acacia nilotica
    • Stone fencing
    • Trench fencing - elephant
    • Wire fencing - barbed wire
    • Electric fencing
  • Fire protection
    • Clearing the strips around plantation
    • Planting evergreen trees at fire lines
    • Control burning
Tending operations

From establishment of the regeneration and the subsequent growth to the harvesting, several operations are carried out to provide healthy environment for their growth. These are called trending operations.

  • Weeding
  • Cleaning
  • Climber cutting
  • Pruning
  • Thinning
  • Cultural operations: Operations done to assist existing regeneration or to promote its proper development.
    • Weeding
    • Cleaning
    • Girdling - poisoning of unwanted growth
    • Climber cutting
    • Controlled burning
Tendingcultural operations
Create best condition for growthpromote development + regeneration + reduce side effects
Not aimed at natural regenerationsupports natural regeneration
Pruning but not controlled burningcontrolled burning, but not pruning
Initially done every year – later interval increasesDone after felling operations

Weeding

Removal of unwanted plants from a particular site

Objectives

  1. Reduce competition for water, nutrients, light, space
  1. Remove shelter for helpful insects, pathogens

Patterns

Inter-row

Methods

  1. Mechanical
  1. Chemical
  1. Biological

Cleaning

Removal of undesirable species, or poor performing desirable species

Objectives

  • To reduce competition for best performing trees
  • Regulation of shape and size of crown
  • Regulating crop composition

Weeding versus cleaning

WeedingCleaning
removal of unwanted speciesboth wanted and unwanted
Purpose – reduce competition, check insect pest growthreduce competition, regulate composition and structure of crops
At initial stages of developmentmainly during the sapling stage

Climber cutting

Climbers: Climb to the top of other trees to get sunlight

Issues

  • Obstruct diameter growth of tree
  • Carry at forest fire to tree top

Pruning

Operation to remove live or dead branches from standing crop to improve tree or timber.

  • Helps - straight, knot-free, less taper, good quality bole.

Types

Natural

  • Elimination of branches by biotic factors

Artificial

  • Dry pruning: Dead branches
  • Green pruning: Live branches

Improvement felling

Removal or destruction of the less valuable tree in a crop in the interest of better growth of the more valuable individuals.

  • Usually in a mixed, uneven-aged forest / inferior forest (thinning in even aged forest)
  • Usually performed beyond the sapling stage
  • Aim: Improve the composition and character of the crop
  • Operations
    • Removal of dead, dying and diseased trees
    • Removal of unsound, over-mature trees – may deteriorate further
    • Thinning out crowded groups
    • Removal of inferior species and undergrowth that can interfere with regeneration and growth of major and valuable species
    • Climber cutting

Salvage cutting

Removing trees that have been or are in imminent danger of being killed or damaged by injurious agents, other than competition.

Increment felling

Thinning

Objectives

  • Removed dead, diseased trees
graph LR
    a[Week tree] --> b[more susceptible to disease attack] --> c[source of infection]
  • Desirable crop composition
  • More space for crown and root development, diameter growth
  • intermediate financial returns
  • More light at forest floor – raw humus decomposition
Mechanical thinning

Trees are cut based on true of thumb e.g. – every alternate tree

  • For young plantation before crown differentiation take place
  • Disadvantage – removal of good trees, poor trees spared – non-uniform productivity
  • Types
    1. Row thinning

    1. Space thinning

  • Application - Deodar, Teak

Low / Ordinary thinning / thinning from below / German

removal of inferior individuals from the suppressed class → dominated → dominant class

Grading

gradeDescriptionDetails
ALightdead + decaying + suppressed
B moderateDefective dominated
C heavydominated + defective co-dominated
D very heavySome dominant – no lasting or permanent gap in canopy
E extremely heavyresearch purpose

Application

  • Market for small size timber
  • Area infested with climbers
  • Danger of crown fire
  • No danger of soil deterioration
  • Regeneration issue for light demander species

Advantage

  • Simple and easy
  • For light demander species - Teak, Sal, Chir-Pine
  • improve hygienic condition – removal of diseased, infected trees
  • Retain vigorous trees by removing less vigorous trees
  • help natural regeneration

Disadvantage

  • Costly if lots of bushes and climbers
  • The risk of soil exposure
  • Lower classes may be useful in utilization, nutrient recycling, carbon storage

Crown thinning / thinning from above / high thinning / French

  • Less promising trees of top crown are removed. Dominated and suppressed are retained for natural pruning of them, unless they are dead, dying, or diseased.
  • Objective — Crown development of selected potential trees
  • Types
    type details
    Lightremove dead, diseased and wolf trees of top crown
    heavyRemove all other trees, except dominated (II)(\rm{II})(II)﻿, suppressed (III)(\rm{III})(III)﻿, and a few of predominant (I(a))\left(\rm{I(a)}\right)(I(a))﻿

    Application

    • When lower canopy trees are shade tolerant – Sal
    • Market demand for big timber – plywood
    • When danger of frost, drought
    • When danger of soil erosion

    Advantages

    • Retaining lower canopy
      • Check soil erosion
      • Protect from frost
    • Protects shade-bearing trees
    • Side branches are naturally crud – due to presence of lower crown class

    Disadvantages

    • Dominant trees may face root competition for moisture and nutrients
    • Requires skill
    • Lower classes can create difficulties while carrying out operations
    • Diseased and insect infested tree of lower crown class – source of infection for main crop

HECK’s Free thinning / elite thinning

Method

  1. Elites are chosen based on size, age, stem form etc.
  1. Removing remaining crops based on their impact on elite

Merit

  • Simple, convenient
  • Trees that form the final crop grow free from interference – very rapid increment

Demerits

  • Cannot select elites in early stage of development
  • Subsequent thinning becomes time-consuming
  • If elite is damaged, for example by wind, then there is no substitute

Advanced thinning

Thinning is carried out before the competition among individual trees has begun.

Sal, Teak, Chir-Pine

Numerical thinning

Considers factors like

  • Number of stem for hectare
  • Tree area ratio
  • Basal area
  • Bole area

Factors affecting thinning

  • Light demander species — require frequent thinning to reduce competition
  • Mechanical thinning — done at young age, when crown development is yet not complete
  • Avoid heavy thinning at
    • Poor site — due to poor rate of growth
    • Steep slopes
    • Drier areas
    • If opening is likely to be invaded by weed, grass

Thinning of a irregular crops

Done in following order —

  • Dead / dying / diseased
  • Inferior and wolf trees (that restrict neighbours)
  • Inferior tree of similar species
  • Trees with no importance
  • Inferior trees standing over well grown trees
  • Thinning among well grown advanced trees
Plantation forestry

Forest productivity

Challenges

  • Global average of 2.1 million m3 / ha/year\pu{2.1 million m^3/ha/year}2.1 millionm3/ha/year﻿, Indian : 0.7 million m3 / ha/year\pu{0.7 million m^3/ha/year}0.7 millionm3/ha/year﻿
  • unregulated grazing, Uncontrolled fuelwood collection
  • Illegal felling, encroachment, land diversion
  • forest fire
  • Climate change

Measures

  • Richmond plantation
  • Afforestation and reforestation of degraded forest area
  • Preventing illegal felling, lopping, uncontrolled grazing in the affected areas
  • Multi stakeholder approach

Energy plantation

Data

Present energy basket

  • Coal – 55%
  • oil – 30%

  • Energy plantation: Growing of selected trees and shrub species for production of fuelwood or vegetable oil
  • Species: Acacia nilotica, Jatropha curcas, Pongamia pinnata

Importance

  • Energy security
  • Reduce import cost
  • Global emission commitments
  • Rural employment
  • Reduce household pollution

  • Initiative
    1. National Bio Fuel Policy 2018
    1. National Agroforestry Policy 2014

Clonal forestry

Clonal forestry

Cloning technology differs from species to species – requires continuous development.

2. Silviculture - systems :

Clear felling, uniform shelter wood selection, coppice and conversion systems. Management of

silviculture systems of temperate, subtropical, humid tropical, dry tropical and coastal tropical

forests with special reference to plantation silviculture, choice of species, establishment and

management of standards, enrichment methods, technical constraints, intensive mechanised

methods, aerial seeding thinning.

Silvicultural Systems

A planned silvicultural treatment – applied to forest crop – throughout its life – so that it assumes a distinctive form – begins with regeneration felling – tending – finally felling

High forest system

  • Regeneration by seedling, either natural or artificial
  • Long rotation

Concentrated regeneration

  • Clear felling
  • Shelterwood system

Diffused regeneration

  • Single tree selection system
  • Group selection system

Accessory system

Coppice system

  • Regeneration by coppice
  • Rotation is shorter

Clear felling system

  • A silvicultural system in which equal or equi-productive areas of mature crops are successfully clear-felled in one operation and regenerated.
  • Annual coupe: each year 1nth\frac{1}{n}^\text{th}n1​th﻿ of area is felled. (where nnn﻿ is the number of years in rotation)

Specifications

  • Entire coupe is felled and removed at once
  • Primarily artificial regeneration - sometimes natural regeneration
  • Even aged crop

Advantages

  • Simple and quick
  • Easy to supervise
  • All felling concentrated in one area
    • High yield per unit area
    • Less cost of felling and extraction
    • Allows for mechanisation
  • Even aged crop – cylindrical boles
  • Regular age class distribution
  • Does not damage new crop
  • Exotics can be introduced

Disadvantages

  • Most artificial way of raising crop
  • Soil exposed
  • Weed invasion
  • Destruction of natural flora and fauna
  • Even aged crop – less resistance

Examples

Tectona grandis (teak)

  • Cultivation: Agroforestry, block and boundary plantation
  • Under clear felling system
    • Rotation: 60–120 years (80 years in central India)
    • Divide forest in 80 equi-productive areas
      • fell 1 coupe each year
      • Subsequent plantation by nursery raised seedling
  • If soil erosion is a concern - do alternate strip system

Casuarina equisetifolia

  • At coastal Sand-dune area
  • Plantation
    • 30 cm diameter pit
    • 30 cm depth
    • 1.8 x 1.8 m spacing
    • Naked root or earth ball
    • Planted in June – July
    • Clear felling (alternate strip)
    • Coast – Orissa, Gujarat

Shorea robusta

  • North Indian plains
Modification
Clear strip system
  • Clear felling is done in form of strips, which go progressively in one direction, usually against the prevailing wind direction across the regeneration area.

Features

  • Entire strip is cleaned at once
  • Even aged strip
  • Less deteriorating site quality
  • Issue of grazing rights because the area needs to be closed for a long time

Example

Pinus kesiya in Assam

Alternate strip system

  • Alternate strips - felled and un-felled
Shelterwood system

Removal in two or more felling, depending on progress of regeneration. Called “shelterwood” because – regeneration is obtained under shelter of over-wood.

Uniform system / compartment system

Concentrated regeneration – canopy is opened uniformly over whole area of compartment in one operation – but 20–50 trees / hector, are left to provide protection, seed supply.

Pattern of felling

Seeding felling

  • opening canopy to provide conditions for underground regeneration
  • floor gets soil moisture, light

Secondary felling

  • gradually remove the shelter and admit increasing light

Final felling

  • Removal of last seed or shelter trees after regeneration is well established

Regeneration felling

Felling made with the aim of assisting regeneration – includes seeding, secondary, final felling

Method of regeneration

  • Mainly naturally, supplemented by artificial means

Tending operations

  • Slash is Collected and burnt in winter
  • Weeding and cleaning after regeneration starts

Character of crop

  • Even aged, but less than clear felling

Advantages

  • Soil is not fully exposed
  • Marking and felling as simple as clear felling
  • Regeneration done in shelter of older crops – lesser chance of failure and weed growth
  • Young crop is protected from adverse climate factors
  • Regeneration is obtained from best selected tree’s seeds – superior new crop
  • regeneration of both light demander and shade bearer is possible
  • New crop grow before old one is harvested – reduced length of rotation
  • Produces even aged crop with long clean cylindrical boles
  • Reduces risk of insects found in clear felling system

Disadvantages

  • Removal of over-wood – damage new regeneration
  • Requires skill if species are of different light requirements
  • Slow growing species required long regeneration period – weeding and cleaning for long time

Applications

suitable not suitable
Where regeneration can be obtained easilywhere wind storm occurs frequently
Where regeneration requires protectionWhere grazing pressure is such that it is not possible to close the area for longer periods.
Where clear felling can result in soil erosion or invasion by grass and weedwhere seeds of old crops are not suitable to regenerate or over wood create some regeneration issue

Examples

Pinus roxburghii (Chir Pine)

  • Uniform system in Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand
  • Easy natural regeneration
  • 15–25 seed bearer retained at the time of seeding felling
  • Slash is Collected and burnt in winter; weeding and cleaning done when needed
  • Area is closed for grazing and protected against fire
  • Protection – the regeneration is – 1-2 m (gentle slope), 2.5–3 m (steep slope)

Cedrus deodara (Deodar) with Pinus wallichiana (Kail)

  • Shade bearer - Deodar, light demander - Kail
  • Felling
    • Seeding felling first done to suit Deodar
    • Overwood is further opened up
      • help Deodar grow further
      • Enable Kail regeneration in the blanks
    • Deodar - 45-50 seed bearers per ha retained, Kail - 25-30
  • Face the issue of mechanical barrier created by heavy litter deposition. Un-decomposed or partially decomposed needles are cleared before a good seed fall is expected.
  • Natural regeneration is usually supplemented by artificial means.

Shorea robusta (Sal)

  • Uniform system in Gangetic Valley
  • Frost prone
  • Regeneration failed due to dying back
  • All India Sal Study Tour and Symposium (1953)
    • Uniform system is not suitable for Sal in localities where establishment of regeneration cannot be guaranteed on time schedule
    • irregular shelterwood system

The group system a.k.a Bavarian femelschlag

Regeneration felling done in scattered groups instead of uniformly in a compartment

Pattern of felling

Tending

  • slash disposal
  • weeding, shrub-cutting, cleaning

Character of crop produced

  • Uneven aged

Advantages

  • Crop develops in more natural way
  • Regeneration is protected - frost, wind, storm
  • Damages from logging and conversion can be minimised

Disadvantages

  • Difficult in hilly terrain to mark rings
  • Wind-throw of tree at the later stages because isolated seed bearers are exposed
  • Supervision and control difficulty
  • Requires intensive working – failed in India

Application

  • Tried in Chamba (Himachal Pradesh) for Deodar, Kail → failed
  • Also failed in Odisha, Uttarakhand

Irregular shelterwood system

Crop is opened irregularly → by removing trees above a predetermined diameter

Pattern of felling

irregular, no pattern

Application

  • steep terrain
  • danger of soil loss
  • difficulty to obtain regeneration

Character of crop

uneven aged

Indian irregular shelterwood system

Crop is opened irregularly → by removing trees above a predetermined diameter

Deodar forest of Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand

  • Remove all over 40 cm diameter class after retaining 40–50 trees per hectare
  • Steep terrain – selection type felling
  • Regeneration work completed in 30 years

Sal forest in Tarai of Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand

  • Uniform system failed because of dying back phenomena → Indian irregular system
  • Floating periodic blocks — regeneration is scattered all over in various developmental stages
  • Regeneration is completed in 60 years

Andaman canopy lifting shelterwood system

  • Tropical rainforest of Arunachal Pradesh and Andaman
  • Girth at Breast Height (GBH)
    • 150 cm: hardwood
    • 120 cm: softwood
    • 180 cm: others
  • Commercial trees below GBH – left as advanced growth
  • Canopy lifting done by
    • felling poles of all non-commercial species < 10 m height
    • Girdling trees of 10 m – 20 m height not needed as seed bearers or as part of future drop
  • Controlled burning
  • Cleaning operations – third year, sixth year
  • Thinning – 6, 15, 30, 50 year
  • regeneration complete: 3–10 year
criteriaIndian shelterwood systemuniform shelterwoodSelection system
Regeneration felling areaconfined to compartmentsSpread over the entire area
Regeneration time3–10 years in tropical rainforest, 30 years in Deodar, 60 years in Salcontinuous

Shelterwood strip system

Regenerative felling is done in the form of strips, successively from one side of compartment, against the direction of wind.

  • Mixture of clear felling and uniform system

Felling pattern

Modifications

Wagner’s blender saumschlag

  • regeneration felling is carried out in narrow strip, extending in east-west direction and advancing in north-south direction
  • provides sideward protection to regeneration from sun. hence used in subtropical, tundra region.
  • crop — even in E-W direction, uneven in N-S direction.

Strip and group system

  • felling is done in strips conform to group system
  • 1st seedling felling → in area with advanced growth
  • secondary felling → when regeneration comes up
  • simultaneously adjacent groups are taken where seedling felling started. Work progresses till groups merge
  • direction of strip progresses in against wind direction

Wedge system

  • felling strip is located in middle of cutting section
  • during regeneration, it is widened towards windward side.
  • with time, base of strip reaches top of cutting section
  • suitable for wind prone areas

Selection system

Single tree selection system

System in which felling and regeneration is distributed over whole area – crop is uneven aged – trees of all ages are found mixed together

  • Pattern of felling: Scattered single mature trees are selected from all over the area and felled
  • Mode of regeneration: Natural, supported by artificial regeneration
  • Tending operations: Weeding – once 2–3 years
  • Character of crop: Uneven aged, irregular

Group selection system

  • Trees are selected and felled in small patches
  • Size of group depends on light requirement
  • Crop is irregular, but within a group, all crops of similar age
  • Suitable for light demander
  • Applicable – Sal, Teak, Fir, Spruce

Issues

  • Poor timber quality – knots, tapering
  • Difficult supervision
  • Young crops are damaged during felling

Advantages

  • All ages mixed
    • Continuous canopy
    • Full use of soil
  • Roots draw from all layers
  • Easy natural regeneration
  • More resistant to pest, climate
  • Best system for large size trees – natural pruning – long clean Bole
  • Biologically superior forest – as well as aesthetic and scenic value

Disadvantages

  • High skill for carrying out marking and felling
  • As mature trees are scattered
    • Cost of logging and extracting is high
    • Timber quality varies
  • Felling, logging, extraction damages younger crop
  • Seed from good and bad tree – impact quality of timber
  • Regeneration continues all over the area - Cost of protection against grazing increases – affects grazing rights
  • Area is extensive – strict fire protection is difficult
  • Difficult to assess success or failure of regeneration

Application

  • Highly uneven topography
  • Area with high erosion chances
  • Catchment area near river – continuous leaf cover needed to conserve moisture, prevent flood
  • When market demand is above a particular size
  • best suited for sensitive shade bearer

Examples

  • Teak forest of MP
  • Moist and dry Sal forest of Tarai and MP
  • Tropical evergreen and semi evergreen forest
  • Sandalwood forest of Karnataka

Accessory system

High forest system - originate from modification of other even aged system – resulting in irregular or two storeyed high forest

Two storeyed high forest system

  • Formation of a two story forest – canopy differentiated into two strata, each storey is approximately even aged - usually seedling origin

Advantages

  • light demander (upper storey) + light bearer (under storey) grown together → soil protection
  • Increase proportion of valuable species
  • Cultivation of frost-tender species - cannot be raised in open
  • more income – growing two crops in same area
  • Can change species gradually

Disadvantages

  • Difficulty operation + high skill + labour intensive → likely to fail
  • Under storey is damaged during felling or thinning of upper storey
  • Under storey crop may affect growth of upper storey crop

Applications

Tarai and Garhwal (Uttarakhand) → Chir Pine + Sal grown together

High Forest with reserves system

Selected trees of the crop being regenerated are retained for part or whole of second rotation to produce large sized timber

Coppice system

Using coppicing power of tree stools to regenerate the area again

Simple Coppice system

old crop is clear felled completely → the new crops grow naturally through stool coppice

  • Felling — Clear felling annual coupe
  • Regeneration — Stool coppice, supported by artificial plantation
  • Character of the crop — Even aged
  • Example
    • Eucalyptus globulus in Nilgiri
    • Eucalyptus hybrid in north India

Advantages

  • Simple
  • Regeneration is more certain
  • Shorts grow fast in beginning - less cost of weeding, cleaning
  • Faster growth rate – higher mean annual increment than high forest system
  • Net Return on investment is higher due to shorter rotation and less amount invested

Disadvantages

  • produces only small sized timber
  • Inferior quality wood
  • Exhaust soil
    • Short Rotation
    • Quick growth
  • Coppice regeneration is limited only to few cycles – each cycle more stool die
  • More frost, wind damage

condition for applicability

  • Demand for – fuel wood, pole, small sized timber
  • Suitable for private sector – low investment, quick return
  • Social forestry

Modifications

Coppice of two rotation system

  • At the end of first rotation, some poles are retained for further growth – felled in second rotation
  • Objective: produce some large size timber in addition to poles of ordinary size
  • Not suitable for frost prone areas

Shelterwood coppice system

  • Leave some shelterwood trees (125-150 per ha) frost protection → till the newly formed coppice shoots wilfully establish → Later shelterwood removed gradually
  • Objective:
    • frost protection
    • Market for small size timber with some large size timber

Coppice with standard System

Over wood of standards (usually of seedling origin and composed of trees of various ages) is kept over coppice for periods, which may be multiples of coppice rotation, as a permanent feature

Overwoodlower storey
Compositionseedling origincoppice origin
different age classeven aged
High forest on principle of selection systemsimple coppice system
Aimlarge sized timberfirewood
Frost protectionpoles
Provide seedling regeneration
Rotationtree’s own rotationcoppice separate rotation
Fellingselection system clear felling
regenerationseed stool coppice
crop characteruneven agedeven aged

Tending

  • slash, climber
  • Thinning over wood, if a larger number of standards have been kept - 5th, 10th year

Conditions for application

  • Demand for both firewood, poles, and large sized timber
  • Climatic factors inhibit use of simple coppice system

Example — Sal forest in Pilibhit (Uttar Pradesh) — Rotation – coppice 30 years, standard 60 year

Advantages

  • soil protection
  • Stands provide seedling for regeneration
  • Standards grow in isolation – light increment without exposing soil
  • Small investment
  • coppice give early return

Disadvantages

  • Requires skill
  • highly fertile soil
  • Hectic process – felling, conversion, and extraction

Difference between coppice with standard and shelterwood coppice system

Coppice with standard shelterwood coppice system
Standard retained as permanent feature throughout the life of cropRetained only for part of coppice rotation
Objective – production of large sized timber; frost protection; enrichment of coppiceOnly frost protection
two rotations - standard and coppiceonly one rotation

Difference between coppice with standard and coppice of two rotation system

coppice with standardcoppice of two rotation
standard kept from very beginning as permanent feature of the cropstandard kept from second rotation, onwards, not from the initial itself
Objective – production of large sized timber; frost protection; enrichment of coppiceObjective – to get some large sized timber
Standards are of seedling originstandards are of coppice origin
two rotationsone rotation
standards are of different species from coppice cropstandards are the same species as coppice

Coppice with reserve system

Felling is done only in suitable areas after reserving all financially immature growth

  • Pattern of felling — No predetermined pattern, more emphasis on conservation
  • Regeneration — coppice + seed
  • Characteristic of crop — Uneven aged

Characteristics

  • Cannot be differentiated into different storeys as the reserved trees are irregularly scattered, and the whole crops is uneven aged
  • Only one rotation
  • Reserves
    • Irregularly distributed
    • Several species

Advantages

  • Improves locality quality
  • improves crop composition
  • Avoid unnecessary sacrifice of crop

Disadvantages

  • Requires high skill
  • intense fieldwork
  • Reservation of large areas affects coppice growth adversely

Coppice selection system

  • Fellings on the principle of selection system, but regeneration obtained by coppice
  • Pattern of felling — Selection – all trees above and exploitable diameter
  • Method of regeneration — coppice
  • Character of crop produced — Uneven aged
  • Application — Acacia catechu (Khair) in Himachal Pradesh

Pollard system

  • Pollarding periodically to obtain exploitable material

Examples

  1. Salix in Kashmir to produce shoots for cricket bat industry
  1. Hardiwickia binata in Andhra Pradesh – fiber extraction
  1. Boswelia serrata - small sticks - match industry

Conversion

Change from one silviculture system or one set of species to another

Need

  • Increase yield - example: Sal, Teak Indian irregular shelterwood → uniform system
  • Meet industry demand
  • Take advantage of a particular silviculture system
  • Failure of existing system - failure of Deodar in uniform system → Indian irregular shelterwood
  • Advancement in silvicultural knowledge

Techniques

  1. Part of forest is taken out of current working plan → remaining area continues under working plan
  1. Based on success, conversion is progressed to whole of forest from second revision onwards

Example

  • Conversion by artificial regeneration
  • Broad leaved → conifer
  • Clear felling
    • Clear felling of coppice → artificial regeneration by planting not sowing
    • Risk: artificial plants being suppressed by coppice shoots - therefore suitable in areas where coppice growth is poor
  • Artificial conversion under a shelterwood
    • Allow coppice species to grow to a specific height → start seeding felling →

Choice of silviculture system

Suitability of system to that species

light demander speciesClear felling system
shade bearingshelterwood
Good coppicercoppice system
Good seed yielding high forest system
long seed intervalselection system

Resistance offered to external dangers

storm, drought, frostselection system
snowselection or Indian irregular mode
dense woody growthselection

Soil and topography

  • Catchment area, Rocky area – erosion is high – use selection system for Indian Irregular shelterwood
  • Evergreen forest soil – Indian irregular shelterwood

Objective of management

production of fuelwood, small polecoppice system
large timberhigh forest system
low cost of extractionclear felling
Inadequate labor availabilityTaungya system
inaccessible areaselection system
less skilled staffclear felling
  • Economic consideration
  • Road and water transportation
  • Availability of skilled workforce
  • Forest rights
  • Aesthetic consideration

Management of Bamboo Forest

Management of roadside and avenue plantation

Objective

  • Provide shade to travellers
  • Protect road surface against weather conditions
  • Provide shelterbelt to tree less region
  • Aesthetic
  • Combat air pollution

Division of area

  • Avenue division → working circle → failing series
  • Each km of road is considered compartment → within this coupe is divided for work regulation

Working

  • All trees except middle age are felled
  • “National commission on agriculture” – 3 rows of trees on each side of road
  • Spacing of row – depends on species
  • three alignment – consider telephone, electricity lines
  • Tending operation - weeding, pruning
  • Crop nature – mixed, irregular

Species quality

  • Hardy
  • Wind firm
  • Fast growing
  • Good crown

3. Silviculture - Mangrove and Cold desert :

Mangrove : habitat and characteristics, mangrove, plantation-establishment and

rehabilitation of degraded mangrove formations; silvicultural systems for mangrove; protection

of habitats against natural disasters.

Cold desert - Characteristics, identification and management of species.

4. Silviculture of trees :

Traditional and recent advances in tropical silvicultural research and practices. Silviculture of

some of the economically important species in India such as Acacia catechu, Acacia nilotica,

Acacia auriculiformis, Albizzia lebbeck, Albizzia procera, Anthocephalus Cadamba, Anogeissus

latifolia, Azadirachta indica, Bamboo spp, Butea monosperma, Cassia siamea,Casuarina

equisetifolia, Cedrus deodara, Chukrasia tabularis, Dalbergia sisoo, Dipterocarpus spp., Emblica

officindils, Eucalyptus spp, Gmelina Arborea, Hardwickia binata, Largerstroemia Lanceolata,

Pinus roxburghi, Populus spp, Pterocarpus marsupium, Prosopis

juliflora, Santalum album, Semecarpus anacardium,. Shorea robusta, Salmalia malabaricum,

Tectona grandis, Terminalis tomemtosa, Tamarindus indica

Mangroves

  • Salt tolerant plants found in tropical and sub, tropical and subtropical coastal and intertidal zone

Species (5 genera)

FamilySpecies
AvicenniaceaeAvicennia germinance, Avicennia gymnorhiza
RhizophoraceaeRhizophora mangle, Brugulera gymnorhiza
SonneratiaceaeSonneratia alba
SterculeaceaeHeritiera littoralis

Habitat

  • High salinity
  • Anaerobic soil
  • Anaerobic bacteria decomposes nitrogen – N, P, K unavailable
  • 25° – 35°C
  • Rainfall – 100 – 300 cm
  • Edge Effect - rich biodiversity

Significance

  • 1% of world’s tropical forest
  • Southeast Asia + South Asia – 40% of worlds mangrove

Characteristics of mangrove forests

  • climate
    • hot and humid
    • salt spray
  • oceanic factors
    • high saline water
    • diurnal tidal inundation

  • edaphic
    • unstable mudflat
    • anaerobic soil
    • N deficiency, poor in many nutrients
    • high salinity

  • vegetation
    • root modification — Blind roots (pneumatophores) to overcome anaerobic soil condition
    • buttressing
    • viviparity - seeds germinate in treat itself
    • thick cuticular leaves
    • Salt secreting glands
  • Wildlife
    • Bengal Tiger
    • Crab, oyster, coral reefs
  • Evergreen ecosystem
  • Physiologically dry soil
    • Water is present in soil – but to saline – cannot be used
    • Physical wet but physiologically dry

Adaptations

High salinity

  • Salt exclusion
    • Reverse osmosis
    • Thick epidermis
    • Succulent leaves
    • Thick cuticle on leaves
    • sunken stomata
  • Salt secretion — Salt glands on leaves
  • Salt accumulation — In the form of crystolith and raphides

Water-logging

OX2\ce{O2}OX2​﻿ unavailable + physical support not provided

  • Pneumatophores for air breathing — Lateral roots that grow upwards
  • Roots for grip
    • stilt root
    • knee root
    • buttress
    • pneumatophore

Reproduction

  • propagule dispersal — Pollination via wind and insect
  • viviparity — pollination → seed remains attached to parent → germinate into propagule → drops into water

Succession

Soil conditionSpeciesNiche
Muddy and sand bankSonneratia (Pioneer)- can withstand high salinity, wind, wave; - extensive root system
soil becomes more compact and firmRhizophoda mangleprop roots → trap silt → more firm soil
higher ground, seawater level falls, more firm soilBrugueira cylindricathrives on firm soil
Nipahmangrove moves further towards sea

Zonation of vegetation

Zone examples vegetation characteristic
Low tidal zoneBruguiera, Ceriops, Laguncularia racemoseProp roots + wind pollination
medium – low tidalAvicennia germinans, SonneratiaPneumatophores roots
medium – high tidalRhizophora mangleknee roots + bee pollination
high tidal zoneButtonwoods superficial root system with buttresses

Classification

Ecological basis (Champion & Seth)

  • Littoral forest
  • Tidal swamp forest

Location

Coastal

  • Land based pollution
  • Eutrophication
  • Pressure for fuel and fodder

Delta

  • Less human disturbance
  • With Coral reefs
  • cyclone threat
  • Loose mudflat
  • Prone to subside by oceanic currents, tsunami, and cyclones

Marshy backwater, estuarine and coastal mangroves

  • West Coast

Island mangroves

Importance of mangroves

Coastal economy

  • Supply fuelwood, medicine, timber, dyes, fodder
  • Bark – tannins - Bruguiera cylindrica, Rhizophora mucronate
  • Medicine -
    • leaves of Avicennia officinalis - treat stomach and urinary disorders
    • Seeds of Heritiera littoralis - diarrhea and dysentery
  • Termite resistant timber

Disasters

  • storm — roots and canopy dissipate wind and wave energy
    • reduce damage to coastal areas
    • can reduce wave height upto 66%
  • worth
    • prevent over $65 billion in property damages annually
    • reduce flood risk for 15 million people worldwide

Coastal Erosion and pollution

  • erosion
    • Slow down water flow
    • sediments trapped in complex root structure → prevent corrosion
  • Filter pollutants – heavy metals

Ecological

  • Reduces salt concentration from soil – makes agriculture possible in Delta region

Climate change

  • can store up to 4 times more carbon than rainforests
  • sequester most carbon in their soil → long term storage, unlike rainforest in living tissue → released when trees die

Habitat

  • Birds, mammals, marine species
  • Breeding ground for fish and other marine fauna

Threats

40% of India’s mangrove cover lost in last century

Natural Threats

  • Tsunami, cyclones, root clogging from increased water turbidity, damage by disease and boring root animals

Climate change

  • Rising sea level – coastal erosion, and subsidence of Delta
  • Ocean chemistry shifting – exceed ability to adapt

Reduction in nutrient supply

  • Sealing of rivers – lower quantity of freshwater
    • Salt tolerance species : Avicennia alba, Exocoecaria agallacha replacing
    • Heritiera fames, Sonneratia casoelaris → require regular supply of freshwater for growth

Human

  • urban development
  • unsustainable tourism
  • agriculture
  • aquaculture
  • pollution
  • increasing salinity of water

Conservation Measures

Preventive

  • CRZ
  • Alternate sustainable costal economy

Curative

  • Restoration
  • Afforestation
  • Reforestation

Mangrove Initiative for Shoreline Habitats & Tangible Incomes (MISHTI)

  • conserve mangroves across 9 states and 3 UTs
  • links livelihood opportunities → integrates community participation

Need

  • regular monitoring and research
    • understand health and extend of forests
    • develop targeted strategies
  • enhanced community involvement and education
    • ensure the sustainability of conservation efforts
    • empowerment of local communities with knowledge and resources
    • aligning conservation goals with livelihood needs
  • private sector
    • advancing collaborations, research, awareness, and community participation

reforestation techniques

Plantation methods

  1. Direct broadcasting of propagule
  1. Raised bed plantation
  1. Canal method or fishbone channel plantation

Artificial regeneration

  • Rhizophora does not require any nursery.
  • Sonneratia requires nursery as water washes of their small seed.
  • A. alba, A. officinalis - aerial seeding - 50% success

Fishbone technique

  • Main channel indirect of prevailing tide
  • Feeder channel at 45°
  • Seedling planted inside bunds of channel
  • Water enters during high tide and leaves during low tide - without soil erosion

Silvicultural system

Clear felling system

  • Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia
  • Suitable for R. apiculata, R. conjugata — strong, light demander, withstand competition

Clear felling with retention of standards

  • In shelterwood system 2 thinning, followed by regeneration felling
  • subsequently regeneration is achieved without regeneration felling
  • So subsequently 7 trees / ha are retained during final felling
    • all trees with diameter > 7.5 cm are removed
    • a narrow belt of 3m is retained along river bank to prevent erosion
  • to avoid damage to regeneration, extraction is done with axes

Selection system

  • done in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Myanmar
  • above predetermined diameter
  • Sunderbans

Selection cum improvement system

Rhizophora racemosa in Sunderbans

  • separate annual coupe for timber, fuelwood, pulp
  • harvest 20-year cycle

Plantation and rehabilitation of degraded mangrove

Area selection

  • extensively degraded area
  • local people requirements

Species selection

  • fuelwood → R. mangle
  • fodder → Avicennia marina
  • Site has high salinity → R. mangle

Planting stock

  • 6-12 month old natural seedlings are transplanted
  • Avicennia, Rhizophora → raised by seed propagules
  • In all other cases → poly bag raised seedlings are used
  • Nursery
    • sunken bed with size 12.5 ×2.5m\pu{12.5\times2.5m}12.5 ×2.5m﻿
    • needs Bamboo support to prevent bag destruction by tidal waves

Site preparation

  • weed eradication
  • slash is pruned, collected, stacked in next row, perpendicular or 45° to waterway

Plantation work

  • done in monsoon
  • seedlings are planted at spacing of 2 ×2m\pu{2\times2m}2 ×2m﻿
  • Rhizophora → planted by crowbar hole
  • Avicennia → buried at 2.5−5 cm\pu{2.5-5cm}2.5−5 cm﻿ deep

Fishbone technique

Refilling

  • after 1 year, areas with >30% seedling deaths are refilled with fresh seedling
  • thinning → 10-15 year

Protection problem

  • browsing by buffalo
  • pulling of plant by fishing activity → barbed wire fencing

Cold desert

Area with extreme cold climate + denuded terrain

  • a.k.a. temperate desert
  • Mainly formed by rain shadow effect of Himalayas

Distribution

Trans-Himalayan

  • Leh - Ladakh
  • Lahul - Spiti valley
  • Pin valley (Himachal Pradesh)

Inner dry valley

  • Uttarakashi (Uttarakhand)
  • Chamoli (Uttarakhand)
  • North Sikkim
  • Vegetation
    • Food fodder timber fuel
    • Soil Binder – control soil erosion + increase soil fertility
    • Carbon storage and sequestration
    • Shelter to wildlife – Cheru

Importance

Habitat Characteristics

Climate

  • Rain shadow < 60 cm
  • Melting snow is the only moisture source
  • Temperature < 0°C
  • 3–5 months of growing season
  • High insolation due to thin atmosphere
  • High speed katabatic winds from mountain into valley → erosion, desiccating effect
  • Low atmospheric pressure – high evaporation

Soil

  • Unweathered rock
  • Poor organic matter, low fertility

topography

  • rugged
  • Landslide, cloudburst, heavy soil erosion

Threats

  • Forest degradation: Harsh weather, human pressure
  • Grazing
  • Forest fire
  • Road Construction
  • Climate change
  • Landslide, earthquake, cloudburst

Species

  • Salix alba - Willow
  • Populus alba - Poplar
  • Pinus gerardiana - chilgosa fruit
  • Betula utilis - birch
  • Rhododendron campanulatum - rhododendron
  • Hippaphae rhamnoides - Sea buckthorn
  • Dry temperate zone
    • Betula utilis
    • Salix spp.
    • Juniperus recurva
  • Alpine
    • Junipers
    • Birch
    • Rhododendron

Adaptation

Morphological

  • Grow close the ground
    • Warmth of soil
    • Protect from wind
  • Covered with fine hair – air insulation
  • Very small leaves – prevent water loss
  • Fibrous root system – trap more nutrients

Physiological

  • Complete growth cycle within growing season – dormant during winter
  • During winter
    • Cannot photosynthesis
    • Growth and reproduction stops
  • Rely on wind for pollination

Cellular/molecular

Internal factors (frost resistance)

  • Water content in the cell – more water less resistance
  • Osmotic concentration of cell colloids – higher concentration – less chance of freezing
  • permeability of cell to water – high → drain access water quickly

Soil working

Trench-cum-pit type

  • Area: gentle slope + stony surface
  • Trench: 10 ×10m\pu{10\times10m}10 ×10m﻿ space, l=4.3 mw={1 mtop0.6 mbottoml=\pu{4.3m}\quad w=\begin{cases}\pu{1m}&\text{top}\\\pu{0.6m}&\text{bottom}\end{cases}l=4.3 mw={1 m0.6 m​topbottom​﻿
  • Pit: 2 ×2m\pu{2\times2m}2 ×2m﻿ space, l=60 cm;w=60 cml=\pu{60cm};w=\pu{60cm}l=60 cm;w=60 cm﻿
  • Both are filled with 50:50 mix of soil and silt

Irrigation-cum-drainage type

  • Low lying areas — riverbank, marshy land
  • To allow leaching of salt
    • Planting done in 50 cm\pu{50cm}50 cm﻿ deep crowbar holes
    • Around plant, 45cm high mound made
    • ditch — 12.5cm spacing, 45cm deep,w={60 cmtop45 cmbottom w=\begin{cases}\pu{60cm}&\text{top}\\\pu{45cm}&\text{bottom}\end{cases}w={60 cm45 cm​topbottom​﻿
  • Excess water from ditches is drained

Salix cultivation
  • Description

    Salix alba (White willow)

Site requirement

  • 60-100 cm rainfall
  • 0°–32°C
  • Altitude: 1200–2500 m
  • Well aerated deep fertile loamy soil
  • Water availability along the river

cultivation

  • Old twig of Salix - cutting — l:20−22 cm,d:1−2 cml:\pu{20-22cm},d:\pu{1-2cm}l:20−22 cm,d:1−2 cm﻿
  • Plant cutting in nursery — spacing 60 ×30cm\pu{60\times30cm}60 ×30cm﻿, thinning 5th, 10th year, final space 3.7 ×3.7m\pu{3.7\times3.7m}3.7 ×3.7m﻿
  • Transplant to farm — when height is 2.5−3 m\pu{2.5-3m}2.5−3 m﻿
    • Planted in November – March and treated with sufficient water before planting
    • Planting – crowbar hole, pit planting
  • Pollarding when height reaches 5–6 m
  • Artificial regeneration —

Planting of sets

  • Sets are collected from pollarded young trees
    • Non-rooted sets are better than rooted sets
    • long size sets are better for submerged region
  • sets dimension: l:3−5 m,d:3−4 cml:\pu{3-5m},d:\pu{3-4cm}l:3−5 m,d:3−4 cm﻿
  • sets are planted in Nov-March and treated with sufficient water before planting
  • planting
    • crowbar hole : 60 cm deep
    • pit planting: pit size: 30 x 30 x 60 cm, spacing: 1.8 x 3.7 m
  • thinning 5th, 10th year, final space 3.7 ×3.7m\pu{3.7\times3.7m}3.7 ×3.7m﻿

planting rooted cutting

  • cuttings
    • length: 20-25 cm
    • diameter: 1-2 cm
    • spacing in nursery: 60 x 30 cm
    • 1 year old twigs are ideal for making cuttings
    • each cutting should have 1 main bud, no side bud
    • leafless cuttings are desirable
  • planting cuttings: Dec-Jan
  • Tending operations
    • goal is to obtain clean bole of height 2.5m and girth 120cm — suitable for cricket bat
    • immature buds are rubbed by hand using rubber gloves twice a year
  • pollarding — done at height of 4-6m so that bigger butt ends are obtained

Afforestation of cold desert

Problems

  • Soil – shallow, stony, poor moisture, and nutrient
  • Steep slope
  • Wind erosion
  • heavy grazing and browsing

Suitable species

  • Rocky areas → Pinus armandi, P. eldarica
  • Calcareous soil → P. leaucodermis
  • Cold temperature → Eucalyptus parviflora, E. guni
  • moist areas → Betula utilis, Salix spp.

two kinds of plantation

Trench cum pit type

irrigation cum trench type

Silviculture of trees

Silviculture of trees

• Tropical dry and moist deciduous forest
• red soil ✅

• Topography - undulating - upto moderate slope

• LR – before and after monsoon
• Flower – May – June
• Fruit – October – December
• Shed then Light

• Susceptible – frost, fire

• sustain moderate drought
• coppice, root sucker
• Root parasitism
◦ Derives nitrogen and phosphorus from root host with the help of Haustoria – parasite plant root, because it lacks root hair
• illicit fellings
• spike disease - by Mycoplasma
• obligatory root parasite
• hosts -

Anogeissus latifolia / Terminali anogeissiana (Axlewood) CombretaceaeCombretaceae• Sub Himalayan to south India
• Light demander
• Gums used in medicine, printing press
• fodder
Tamarindus indica (Imli, Tamarind) LeguminosaeLeguminosae• Native to tropical Africa, now pan-India
• Commercial cultivation in Tamil Nadu
• Black soil appropriate
• Tropical heat – up to 47°C
• 50–150 cm
• Medium to large size – 24 m
• Girth – 7 m
• Bark
◦ Dark grey
◦ Vertical and horizontal fissures
• LR – May
• Flower – April – July
• Fruit – winter
• Tolerates water logging

• Light demanding
• Cannot tolerate – frost, drought
• Deep root

• Slow growing
• Good coppicer
• Root sucker
• Natural
◦ Seed
◦ coppice
• Artificial
◦ Direct seed sowing
◦ Coppice
◦ Plant raised from nursery - space
Tamil cuisine,Sizing powder in cotton and Jute industry
Emblica officinalis (Amla) - EuphorbiaceaeEuphorbiaceae• hardy → various soils
• commercial in UP, TN
• dry sub tropical climate
• drought sensitive
• medium
• deciduous
• Artificial
• seedling, budding, softwood grafting
• rich vitamin C source
• dried fruits - cough, haemorrhages, anaemia
• ingredient in Ayurvedic
• murabba, candy

• deciduous
• timber
• fodder → leaves and stem
• fiber → ropes
Chukrasia tabularis (Indian mahogany) MeliaceaeMeliaceae• tropical evergreen and semi-evergreen
• light demander
• frost and drought sensitive

• strong coppicerhouse construction
Terminalis tomentosa / Terminalia elliptica (Sain) CombretaceaeCombretaceae• North, West, Central India
• Moderate light demander

• deep root - wind firm		• coppice, root sucker, pollardtimber
Anthocephalus cadamba (Kadam) RubiaceaeRubiaceae• pioneer in riverine succession

• shed then light
Acacia nilotica (Babool) LeguminosaeLeguminosae• tropical dry deciduous, subtropical dry deciduous
• North plains to MH

hardy to Black cotton soil damage, drought - phreatophyte, moderate frost

• suitable for water logging		• medium
• deciduous

Acacia catechu (Khair) LeguminosaeLeguminosae• throughout except Arid Rajasthan, high altitude
• strong light demander
• heavy browsing pressure
• good coppice• kattha
• catechin

Azadirachta indica (Neem) MeliaceaeMeliaceae• tropical dry deciduous and thorn

• light demander
• fire and frost sensitive

• drought hardy - phreatophyte		• almost evergreen
Eucalyptus spp. (Safeda, Nilgiri) MyrtaceaeMyrtaceae• E. hybrid, E. tereticornis, E. globulus → pan India
• E. cameldulensis → Semi-Arid
• E. grandis → High rainfall

• light demander

• wind firm
• suitable for water logging

• water guzzling

• ecto-mycorrhiza
• no grazing issue
• large size
• deciduous
• cylindrical crown
• seed → poor, except Nilgiri hills
• coppice
• fibre, paper

• gums
• leaf oil
Populus deltoides (Poplar) SalicaceaeSalicaceae• exotic : temperate region
• J&K → UK

• water-logging sensitive

• resistant to wind and frost		• medium size
• cylindrical crown
• artificial - cutting - 2yo in winter - 4x4m spacing• fibre for paper
Casuarina equisetifolia (Beefwood) CasuarinaceaeCasuarinaceae• coastal
• thrives in tropical conditions

• light demander
• well-drained sandy soil needed

• extremely sensitive to drought
• nodular bacteria - Frankia - symbiotic
• exto-mycorrhiza
• evergreen
• resembles conifers
• medium size
• conical crown
• extensive deep root
• poor coppice• seed, coppice, root sucker
• naked root and ball of earth plantation
• protection → clear felling 10/20 year rotation
• fuelwood → 7-10 year rotation
• protection
• afforestation of barren, shifting sand dunes
• aesthetic
Prosopis juliflora (Mesquite bean) - LeguminosaeLeguminosae• drought hardy - phreatophyte
• frost resistant


• light demander

• native — Mexico		• medium size
• evergreen
• good coppice, root sucker
Acacia auriculiformals (Australian wattle) LeguminosaeLeguminosae• native to Australia
• India - peninsula
• light demander

• fire tender

• drought tolerant		• medium
• evergreen
• bad coppice, good root sucker in India• seed, root sucker• fuelwood
• timber
• pulp
• shade
• ornamental
• wasteland reclamation
Pinus roxburghii (Chir Pine) PinaceaePinaceae• outer Himalaya (Shivalik foothills)
• sub tropical climate
• light demander

• extensive - V+H roots → wind firm
• frost hardy
• thick corky bark → fire hardy

• ecto-mycorrhiza		seed, direct plantation• furniture
• packaging
• house

• resin
Cedrus deodara (Deodar) PinaceaePinaceae• 1.5-3.0 km altitude
• western Himalaya
• better on northernly aspect

• light demander

• wind hardy
• frost hardy

• snow - injurious in dense
- benefits - moisture, seed protection
• ecto-mycorrhiza
• large
• evergreen
• irregular shelterwood
Abies pindrow (Silver fur) PinaceaePinaceae• 2.5-3.5 km altitude
• Afghanistan to Arunachal
• associated with heavy snowfall and accumulation

• frost hardy

• short branches → no snow break

• root not extensive → wind throw

• shade demander		• very tall
• evergreen
• cylindrical crown
• good seed 3-4 years
• plantation 2m x 2m
• Punjab shelterwood
• selection
• packaging
• furniture
• railway
• pulp

• non-refractory wood

• light demander
• bark → fire resistant

thorny bole and buttressing		• good coppice• root section cutting

Butea monosperma (Palas) LeguminosaeLeguminosae• tropical and subtropical
• drought resistant
• medium
• deciduous
• seed coppice root sucker• ornamental

• bark → butea gum / Bengal kino
• flowers - red dye
Dendrocalamus strictus (Male bamboo) GraminaePoaceae


Cedrus deodara

Importance of snow in regeneration

  • Essential for flowering simulation
  • Act as seed bank - protection
  • chilling treatment remove seed dormancy
  • Melting – source of moisture
  • Breaking of trees or branches – increase light availability on the ground; reduce crown competition

Paper 1 Section B

Agroforestry

Sustainable land use system – maintain or increase total yield – combine food crop with tree crop – and or livestock – on same land – either alternating or at the same time

Attributes

  • Increasing production
  • Sustainability by beneficial effect of tree on soil
  • Adaptability

Scope

  • Meet domestic and industrial need
  • Protect environment, forest and ecosystem

Benefits

environment

  • Climate change mitigation
  • Less pressure on forest
  • Reduce runoff
  • Improve micro climate
  • Lower soil temperature

economic

  • Increase farm output
  • Reduce risk of crop failure
  • Meet industry requirement
  • Rural employment generation

social

  • Doubling farmer income
  • Agro forestry work like nursery, plantation, etc., generates more employment than agriculture

Issues

effect of trees on crop

  • Competition for light - dense canopy shade in Tarai region reduces wheat maturation by 15–20 days
  • Competition for space
  • Competition for nutrients
  • Competition for moisture
    • Crop yield fell 2–3 m radius of eucalyptus plant
      • Allelopathic effect
      • Eucalyptus requires a lot of water

other issues

  • High investment
  • depresses crop yield
  • Trees have long rotation – long time to realize gains
  • allelopathy
  • Birds, pest, insect live in trees– damage crops
  • No tree insurance scheme
  • Local market – Limited absorption capacity for tree products

Allelopathy

  • Effect of one plant – over growth and survivor of other plant – via release of chemical inhibitors
  • Allelochemical - chemicals released after leaf decomposition
    • Eucalyptus spp. → release gallic and other phenolic chemicals from decomposition of bark and leaves

Types

based on effect

autogenic

  • Impacts young seedlings of own species

alellogenic

  • Impact other species

based on form of chemical

True allelopathy

  • Toxic chemicals released directly into environment

functional allelopathy

  • Released chemicals become toxic after action of microbes

Solution

  • Increase spacing
  • Crown management
    • Pruning
    • Pollarding
    • Thinning
  • Root management
    • root Pruning
    • root trenching
  • Planting east – west direction to reduce shedding effect
  • Choice of tree and agriculture crop
    • Poplar – wheat intercropping in Tarai region
      • Poplar shades leaves in November when wheat plantation begins – so no light competition
      • Shaded leaves act as manure
      • Wheat harvested at mid April - Poplar leaves reappear

Classification

(Nair 1987)

Structural basis

nature

  • Agro-silviculture
  • Silvo-pastoral
  • Agro-silvo-pastoral
  • Other system

arrangement

  • Spatial
