  • temporal

Functional basis

productive

  • Food
  • Fodder
  • Fuel wood
  • Timber
  • NTFP

protective

  • Shelter
  • Soil conservation

Socio-economic basis

commercial

  • e.g. Oil Palm in Manipur
  • Rubber in Kerala
  • Poplar in Tarai

intermediate

  • e.g. Teak at farm boundaries
  • Cash crop alongside food crop

subsistence

  • Managed by farmer and family
  • To meet just their basic needs

Ecological basis

Tejawani (1995) - fifth basis of classification

in humid/ subhumid low land

  • Albizzia lebbeck
  • Leucaena l
  • Home Garden
  • Range land and pastures

in semiarid and arid land

  • Windbreak
  • shelter break
  • Acacia fortilis
  • Acacia nilotica
  • Albizzia lebbeck
  • Azadirachta indica
  • Hardiwickia binata

in tropical Highland

  • Plantation crop like tea, coffee
  • Leucacena leucouphala

Physiogonomic basis

Xeromorphic

  • Xerophytes
  • Dryland farming

Mesomorphic

  • Terrestrial plants adapted neither particularly to wet nor dry
  • AF in tropical and temperate come mostly under this

hydromorphic

  • Hydrophytes - plants that grow only in water/ moisture
  • e.g. wetland AF
  • Fish paddy cultivation
  • aqua-silviculture

Agri – silviculture system

Taungya system

  • Growing agriculture crop between space of tree plantation
  • Types
    • Departmental Taungya → raised by forest department
    • Leased Taungya → department allows, local farmers to grow crops by lease rent
    • Village Taungya → villagers living in forest are permitted to cultivate between tree - most successful

Alley cropping or Avenue cropping

  • Crops and pasture grown in alleys
  • Preferable legumes
  • Spacing
    • Between rows
    • between trees
  • Species
    • Laucaena leuceocephala

Shelter belt

  • Several rows of tree at 90° to prevailing wind
  • Aim – protect farm from wind
  • Height:width:length – 1:10:25
  • Species
    • Dalbergia sissoo
    • Eucalyptus spp.

Wind break

  • 2–3 rows of trees at 90° of wind – protect field, home, canal
  • Difference from shelter break
    • All rows have same tree of same height
    • Longer length

Shifting cultivation

  • 2% of geographical area → 40% in Northeast – called “Jhum”

Impact

  • deforestation
  • Biodiversity loss
  • Forest fire
  • Hurts Forest hydrology
  • Canopy opening – soil erosion
  • Less productivity
  • Soil degradation
  • Weed invasion
  • Food insecurity

Advantage

  • burning of pest, weed
  • Labor intensive → employment
  • Simple and speedy
  • Waste burnt → nutrient for growth
  • no input, skill
  • Opportunity for new species to grow

How to control?

  • Institutional mechanism
    • KVK, NGO, Academics → Provide – seed, manure and irrigation
    • NITI:
      • Mission mode program under Ministry of agriculture
      • Address food security during this transition period
  • Home garden → cultivate seasonal local crop
  • Credit facility
  • Agroforestry model
  • Alternatives → oil palm plantation in Manipur under Taungya system
  • PM Van Dhan scheme
  • Land classification based on land capability

Silvi-pastoral system

  • Agroforestry system – woody plant + pasture (grass)

Protein bank

  • Multiplepurpose tree
  • Protein rich tree around farmland or wasteland
  • Species
    • Acacia nilotica
    • veneers
    • Neem

Live fence

  • A hedge of fodder tree and shrub around farmland
  • Prevent animal infiltration

Agri-silvo-pasture system

  • Agraforestry system – tree + agriculture crop + pasture

Home Garden

  • In high rainfall areas
    • e.g. kerala, Tamil Nadu → coconut is main tree
  • Grow vegetables, herbaceous plants
  • Highly productive
  • Species
    • Mango
    • (Cocus nucifera) Coconut
    • Cabbage
    • Pumpkin

Woody hedgerows

woody hedges → fast growing and coppicing fodder shrubs

Other systems

Silviapiary

  • Tree and honey production
  • Species
    • Syzgium cumini (Jamun)

Aqua forestry

  • Tree and shrub preferred by fishes are planted at boundary of pond
  • Fish feed on tree leaves
  • Also stabilise bunds of pond
  • Species
    • Leucaena leucocephala

Role of tree in agroforestry

Role in soil conservation

  • Tree – reduce impact of rain
  • Multi layer canopy – prevent erosion
  • humus layer
    • Prevent direct impact of soil with rain
    • Increase infiltration
  • Taproot - hold soil layer

Role in nutrient cycling

  • Nitrogen fixation
  • Recycling leached nutrients
  • Roots breaking underground rock → release of new minerals
  • Mycorrhiza → adding phosphorus
  • Lateral root → redistribute nutrients
  • Reduce surface flow of agricultural chemical pollutants

Micro climate modification (buffer effect)

  • Tree shade → reduce soil and air temperature + increase humidity → impact transpiration → yield increases
  • Reduce wind erosion

Impact on carbon sequestration, air quality, environment

  • Maintaining balance
  • Intercropping – 50% more sequestered than monoculture system
  • Protection from wind and frost

Role in biodiversity conservation

  • Flora for kids, food, and habitat
  • Nutrient cycle
  • Creating wildlife corridor
  • Preventing weed encroachment

Promoting sustainable livelihood to marginal farmers

  • Reduce water requirement of crop
  • Crop protected from frost, etc.
  • For timber fuelwood – insurance crop failure

Agroforestry protecting under story crop

  • Prevent from sunburn
  • Reduce insect attack – neem tree
  • Transpiration – maintain humid environment
  • Root water absorption – prevents water logging for crops – E eucalyptus plant

Tree in water shed management

  • Reducing runoff
  • Reducing soil erosion
  • Increase water infiltration
  • Increase nutrient cycling
  • Remove pollution

Agricultural system

  • No litter recycling
  • Low litter fall
  • Rainfall runoff
  • Heavy leaching
  • Leaky system

agroforestry

  • Litter used by crop
  • Complementary nutrient sharing
  • Less leaching
  • Closed the system and leaky

forest ecosystem

  • litter fall
  • Mycorrhizal association
  • Some leaching
  • Closed system

Choice of agro forestry system

Tree requirement

  • Fast growing and easy to manage
  • Ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen
  • Should not compete with food crop for light and moisture
  • No toxic chemical releases - allelopathy, allergy
  • Ability to - coppice, self-pruning, pollarding
  • High Survival rate - high termination capacity
  • Wider adaptability
  • Local acceptability
  • Multipurpose use – timber, fodder, fuelwood

Agroforestry in different Agro ecological zones

  • India has 15 agro – climatic regions (planning commission)

Western Himalayan

  • Fruit orchid intercrop → guava, and apple with cereals
  • Tree at agriculture boundary → Grewia optiva
  • Silvi-pastoral → Grewia optiva for leaf fodder

north Indian plains

  • For soil reclamation → AAP (Acacia, Albizzia, Prosopis juliflora)
  • Protein bank → Acacia nilotica, Albizzia lebbeck, Neem
  • Boundary plantation → Tamarindus spp., Eucalyptus
  • Alley cropping → poplar (Tarai region)

Northeast region

  • shifting cultivation “Jhum”
  • Aptani method → rice, and fish cultivation
  • Bamboo drip irrigation in Meghalaya
  • ZABO system, Nagaland
    • Means “impounding water”
    • Combination ⇒ forest + agriculture + animal husbandry
    • Hilltop → protected land
    • Middle → water harvesting structure
    • Bottom → cattle yard, paddy field

Multipurpose tree in agroforestry

Trees purposefully grown to get multiple products and services

  • Gliricidia sepium - living fence, fuelwood, fodder, green manure for agriculture
  • Leucaena leucocephala -
    • One way of management → wood is main output
    • or → leaf fodder main output

Benefits

  • Reduces risk of total failure
    • Leucaena leucocephala → if insects destroy leaves then would it still be sold
  • Income generation
  • Services
    • Food – fruit, nut, leaves
    • Fertilizer – nitrogen fixation, nutrient cycle, leaf litter humus
    • Energy – fuelwood, ethanol production
    • Fibers
  • Ecosystem services

Selection criteria

Tree Requirement of chapter 4

Arid, semi-arid zone

Acacia niloticaFuelwood
Acacia fortillisFuelwood
Albizzia lebbeckFuelwood + timber
Azadirachta indicaTimber, oil, insecticide, medicine

Humid tropics

Eucalyptus camaldulensisFuelwood, timber
Leucaena leucocephalaFuelwood, pole, fodder, windbreak, soil improvement

nitrogen fixing trees in agroforestry

  • Trees that fix atmospheric nitrogen → into plant usable form → via symbiotic micro-organisms in its roots
    • Rhizobium of bacteria at root of AAP

nitrogen fixing trees impact on soil fertility

  • Fix atmospheric nitrogen
  • Deep nutrient capture via roots
  • Adding nutrient via leaf litter
  • Closed cycling of nutrients
  • Improve soil’s physical and chemical condition

Tree selection based on

  • Rapid growth rate
  • Nitrogen fixing ability
  • coppice ability
  • Easy propagation
  • Deep root
  • salinity tolerance

NFT's for agroforestry

timber yieldingAcacia nilotica, Dalbergia spp.
forageProsopis juliflora, Acacia lebbeck
fuelwoodAcacia nilotica
arid and semi-aridAcacia lebbeck, Acacia fortilis, Prosopis juliflora
humid and semi-humidLeucaena leucocephala
tropical highlandsAlnus nepalensis

Diagnosis and design survey of agroforestry

  • Methodology for - diagnosing land management problem - and designing agroforestry solution
    • Designed by ICRAF

Key features

  • Flexibility
  • “rapid appraisal” of application at planning stage
  • “in depth follow” at project implementation
  • Design improvement is open ended

Criteria for good design

  • Should improve net productivity
    • Improve yield
    • Reduce inputs
  • Sustainability - to motivate farmers to join
  • Adaptability

Research process → “agroforestry system research”

  • Macro D&D - at ecozone or national level
  • Micro D&D - system level
  • Technology – design testing, and adoption
  • Component experimentation

Who can use D&D

  • researchers
  • Government officers at field
  • NGOs

D&D stages

stagefactors considered
Pre-diagnostic- comparing different language use system;
- analyzing and describing system
diagnostic- interview
- Direct field observation
design and evaluation- design iteration
- reevaluating all alternatives
planning research design project planning
implementationre-diagnosis and redesign in light of new information

Scale of D&D

Macro level

  • Ecozone/ state/ national level
  • Experts across field like Forester, agro scientist, economists
  • Identify broad issues
  • Identify priority areas
  • Identify research priorities

Meso level

  • Unit larger than farm
  • e.g. water shed level.
  • For soil and water conservation
  • Design: established Village cooperative

Microlevel

  • Household or group of farmers

Agroforestry policy 2014

Need

  • Previous agroforestry programs failed due to lack of national policy
  • Previous agroforestry programs failed due to lack of integrated farming system
  • Obstacles by restrictive guidelines – e.g. Supreme Court guidelines, NGT guide guidelines
  • Insufficient R&D
  • Poor coverage of finance and insurance
  • Agroforestry produce – weak market access

Policy’s goals

  • Establish - national Agro-forestry mission, national agroforestry board
  • Convergence of various schemes and programs
  • Improve productivity, employment and income
  • Meet demand of timber, food, fuel, etc.
  • conserve forest – reduce pressure

Objective

  • Encourage tree plantation
  • Stabilize ecosystem
  • Resilient cropping promotion
  • Increase forest cover
  • Enhance R&D

Strategy

  • Institutional set up – at national level
  • Simplify regulations
  • Quality plans
  • Credit support
  • Market access to products
  • Farmer access to market
  • Sustainable agro forestry
  • Certification

Social forestry

  • Practice of forestry – outside conventional forest area – to benefit rural and urban communities
  • Principle – voluntary peoples participation in the projects
  • National forest policy (1988) - social forestry
    • On panchayat and community land
    • Government to provide technical assistance
    • Revenue generated should belong to panchayat

Aim and objective

  • Meet rural needs like fuelwood and timber
  • Meet leaf fodder requirement
  • Rural income and employment
  • Eco-restoration
  • Increase forest cover
  • Reduce pollution
  • Aesthetic value

Scope

  • Village common land
  • Government Wasteland
  • Side of the road, canal, etc.
  • Degraded government land near village
  • Around agricultural field margins

Components

Farm forestry

  • On farmer’s own land
  • First started in Gujarat in 1970s
  • Fuelwood, small timber, leaf fodder
  • Local issues
  • To do

Recreational forestry

  • Flowering trees and shrubs
  • Aesthetic beauty
  • Saraca indica

Extension forestry

  • Outside forest area
  • To increase area and growth (main goal) + protect environment + fuel, folder, etc.

Urban forestry

  • Planted in urban areas to improve environment and landscape
  • Objective - GHG, runoff, pollution, groundwater recharge, water shed, fuel and fodder, aesthetic, wildlife at urban
  • Scope
    • CAMPA
    • Delhi air pollution
    • Recharge Okhla water shed
    • Reduce urban heat island temperature
    • Aesthetic
  • Species
    • Mango
    • Jamun
    • Neem
  • Issues
    • To do
  • Social benefit, environmental benefit
    • To do
  • Maintenance
    • Crown pruning
    • Pruning for safety

    Aesthetic pruning

Issues of social forestry

Tree

  • Long gestation time
  • Insect and pest attack

Community

  • Poor participation
  • Lack skill

Land

  • availability
  • Scattered patches
  • Ownership issues
  • Low productivity due to low water table

Criticism of social forestry

  • Farmers see it as a commercial activity, not for fuel and fodder
  • Peoples dissatisfaction - Poplar in Jammu and Kashmir
  • Felling of trees leads to harassment of farmers by forest department
  • Lack of technical knowledge among community

Species examples

Roadside plantation

  • Mango
  • Neem
  • Eucalyptus
  • 1 m x 1m\pu{1m x 1m}1 mx1m﻿ or 5 m x 5m\pu{5m x 5m}5 mx5m﻿

Canal plantation

  • robust taproot
  • Dalbergia sissoo, Eucalyptus

Program example

West Bengal social forestry project

  • World Bank funded
  • 1981–90

Joint forest management

  • Started under national Forest policy 1988
  • State Forest department supports forest dwelling community – to protect and manage forest
  • Sharing of cost and benefit
  • Community organise themselves – JFM committee

Success story – Arabari forest range (West Bengal – 1971–72)

  • Heavy degradation of Sal
  • DFO A. K. Banerji → participation of local community
  • Participate approach
    • Involve local community for plantation of 1200+ hectare of degraded forest
    • On maturity – villagers will get 25% share on sale produce
  • Outcome
    • 15 lakh expenditure – sale of 1.2 crore
    • Non timber benefit - Sal seed and leaf, Mahua flower, fodder, grass, medicinal plant → 22% income of tribals

Objectives

  • Reduce government burden, local participation, transparency, tribal employment, end shifting cultivation, local solutions, achieve NDCs

Features

  • Local people
    • Consultation
    • Benefit sharing
    • Decision making
    • Management and protection

Structure

  • Forest Protection Committee (FPC) : a village level committee
    • General body
      • all voters of village
    • Joint Forest Management Committee (JFMC)
      • Elected members + ex-officio members
      • → executive body
      • → 2–5 year term, 5–15 members

JFMC

  • Usually one JFMC per revenue village

Powers

  • rules of forest management
  • voting rights
  • Punitive provisions
  • Distribution of benefits
  • Financial powers

source of finance

  • Forest sale produce
  • Fund From forest department
  • Panchayat fund
  • Grants
  • Fines

who can form JFMC

  • Ranger or DFO upon receiving request from gram panchayat

Entry point activities under JFM

community welfare

  • Road connectivity
  • Drinking water
  • School
  • Healthcare

income generating activities

SHG →

  • Handloom
  • skills
  • NTFP value addition

Principles of benefit sharing under JFM

  • Only for NTFP
  • No alteration in basic silvicultural operations
  • Can get benefit sharing for timber produce if
    • Successfully regenerated and protected forest for 10 years
    • Revenue share: 20% -25%

Issue with JFM

  • Dependent on government fund
  • Forest department has arbitrary powers to dissolve FPCs
  • Issues with micro plan
  • Women – low participation
  • Inadequate recommendation to communities
  • Intra-Community conflict
  • Denial of rights over valuable NTFP to locals

Case studies

  • To do – Internet

JFM network (pyq)

  • To do

Provisions in national Forest policy 1988 for JFM

sections of policy

  • People's movement for JFM
  • Expanding forest cover
  • Right and concessions
  • Bona fide used by communities

some proposals

  • Legal backing to JFM committees
  • 50% women

micro plan

  • Integrated participatory development plan for village level
  • Contains village – specific problems, and solutions
  • Preparation - by forest Officer after PRA - use local knowledge

2002 guidelines

  • To do

Formation of JFMC

  • For a village within 5 km of forest boundary
  • Forest officers should educate villagers on JFMC benefit
  • If villagers want to join -
    • Application to officer
    • Gram Saba → pass resolution where Officer will be present

Participatory rural appraisal, rapid rural appraisal

PRA

  • Tool to collect and analyze information by community for themselves → uses local knowledge → community involved in monitoring and planning

Benefit

  • Collaborative
  • Outsider can understand how a community manages its resources

How PRA is conducted

  • Involve local community in series of meetings
    • First build good rapport
    • Explain purpose of PRA
    • Explain tools of PRA
    • Let community to PRA themselves with government staff assisting them
    • woman and marginalized community participation
    • Display all likely output
    • Participant identify their village problems

Tools of PRA

  • Stakeholder analysis
  • Community needs
  • Participatory mapping
  • Cropping pattern
  • Gender analysis
  • History
  • Resource mapping
  • Livelihood mapping

PRA in JFM

  • About, benefit, tool (PRA)
  • Management and execution by local community
  • Makes them cooperative and understanding
  • Use a local human and material resources
  • Uses indigenous knowledge
  • Benefits shared by all

RRA

  • Set of practices - that help manager or government agency → assess in a rural set up → situation, problem, socio-economic condition

Salient features

  • Less time taken
  • Site specific
  • Simple tool for data collection
  • Input from community
  • Can analyze information during its collection

Constraints

  • New technique
  • Personal bias
  • Government agency is inexperienced

Tools

  • Semi structured interview
  • Group interview
  • discussion
  • Direct observation
  • Sampling - random or stratified

NGOs

  • Not for profit - activities to - relieve suffering, protect environment, develop community
  • Types - registered society, charitable organization, trust, SHG, cooperative

Role in JFM

  • Buffer between forest department and villagers
  • Promote awareness
  • Confidence building among people
  • Awareness and training camp
  • Feedback to forest officials
  • Operational arm of civil Society

activities undertaken

  • Advocacy for villagers
  • As pressure group
  • Conflict resolution
  • Service delivery
  • Evaluating government work

Climate change and global warming

  • To do from environment
  • GHG gases
  • Global warming - human factors
  • Air pollution
  • Carbon sequestration
  • Ozone layer depletion

Chemistry of ozone layer

  • Ozone in both atmosphere and ground level
  • Found in sphere at 17–25 km (ozonosphere)
  • Ozone formation
  • Ozone destruction
  • Impact of ozone destruction
    • Skin cancer
    • Cataract
    • Plankton death
    • Impacts biogeochemical cycle

Environment conservation

  • To do
  • Wildlife protection, environment, protection → laws, and schemes
  • National park, wildlife sanctuary, conservation reserve → in situ
  • Seed bank, botanical garden → ex situ
  • Biodiversity hotspot
  • Biosphere reserve - all in India
  • National Park vs wildlife sanctuary difference
  • Core area, buffer area, etc

Biogeographic zones in India

Forest certification

Aim

  • promote sustainable use of forest resources
  • Ensuring certified for products
  • Consumer preference to use such products

International certification

  • Program for endorsement of forest certification (PEFc) - by Forest Stewardship Council (FSC)

History

  • Smart wood program of Indonesia, 1990
  • Rio earth Summit 1992 – gained popularity
  • No international convention

India

Network for certification and conservation of forest (NCCF)

  • India based nonprofit organization
  • Globally recognition by PEFC
  • Launched the programs
    • Sustainable forest management certificate (NCCF-SFM)
    • Carbon registry – India
    • Land degradation neutrality certificate

Environment Ministry

  • Green Good Deeds Movement
    • Products made from certified wood → promote sustainable forest management

Sustainable forest development

  • Maintain and enhance forest … present, and future generations needs

History of sustainable develop

  • 1983 UN – Brundtland commission – report: our common future 1987
  • Sustainable development - meeting needs of present and future

need for SFD

  • Bad forest management leads to - Livelihood loss, Loss of biodiversity, traditional knowledge loss, more inequality
  • To bring good governance in forestry
  • Optimal forest production
  • protecting environment
  • Soil and site management

challenge

  • Rising market demand
  • Poor forest management practices
  • Clearing forest for agriculture expansion
  • Artificial alternatives to forest products
  • Illegal logging industry

International effort to define sustainable forest management

  • Guideline and indicators by
    • International tropical timber organization (ITTO)
    • Forest Stewardship council
  • → consulted NGO, academia, FAO, governments in framing

India – national working plan 2014

  • 8 criteria and 37 indicators
criteria indicator
(to maintain, conserve, increase —)
Forest coverchange in forest area, cover, boundaries
biodiversityspecies diversity, genetic diversity
forest healthforest fire, grazing, weeds, natural calamities
soil, and water resourceswaterbodies, and wetlands near forest
forest productivitywood growing stock, volume increment of wood
forest resource utilizationDemand and supply of NTFP, timber, bamboo
SocioculturalJFM, indigenous knowledge, Sacred Groves
policy, legal, institutionalforest law and policy, working plan, forest offences, R&D

EIA

Purpose or objectives

  • Tool for decision makers
  • Sustainable development
  • Predict environmental impact of projects
  • Find ways to mitigate
  • Efficient use of resources

Principles

  • Participation
  • Transparency
  • Clear objectivity
  • Accountability of decision makers
  • Credibility – decision decisions based on best information
  • Cost-effective
  • Practicality

Methods

  1. Ad-hoc method
  • Assembled team of specialists who identify impact in their area of expertise
  • Gives broader analysis of impact
  • Used as preliminary analysis
  • Types
    • Expert opinion
    • Opinion poll
    • Delphi method
  • Advantages
    • Simple
    • Broad impact
    • Preliminary
  • disadvantages
    • May leave out areas of impact
    • Inconsistent
    • Difficult to find and assemble specialist
  1. Checklist method
  • Environmental factors are listed in instructor format and given weightage
  • Types
    • Simple checklist
    • Scaling checklist
    • Descriptive checklist
  • Advantages
    • Simple
  • Disadvantages
    • Does not distinguish between direct and indirect impact
    • No action – impact link
  1. Matrix method
  • Action action on one axis, impact on another axis
  • By Leopold (1971)
  • Advantage
    • Links action – impact
    • Good results displayed
  • Disadvantage
    • Does not distinguish between direct and indirect impact
    • Can lead to double count of impact
  1. Simulation method
  • Micro method → assess impact of small scale activity
  • Limited to single activity
  • Experimental in nature
  • e.g. → pollution impact of electric car versus petrol car
  1. Cost – benefit analysis
  • Impact measure measurement in monetary value
  • Also consider socioeconomic value
  1. Environmental performance index
  • To rank a country
  • Distance to target method
  • Score: 100 (best) → 0 (worst)
  • 32 indicators and 11 parameters
  • Not fixed result because subject to -
    • Context
    • Project
    • Ecology

EIA in India

EIA notification 1994

  • Investment criteria → for industry and project > 50 crore
  • Exemption
    • Small scale industry: < 1 Cr investment
    • Defense related road construction
  • EIA done by - project proponent
  • Impact assessment agency - MoEFCC

EIA notification 2006

category
AAA﻿ central expert appraisal committee
B1B_1B1​﻿State expert appraisal committee
B2B_2B2​﻿No EIA
  • Process and stages

    screening

    • B2B_2B2​﻿ does not need screening

    scoping

    [expert appraisal committee]

    • Project description
    • Baseline data
    • Impact identification
    • Impact prediction

    public consultations

    [state/center pollution control board]

    appraisal

    [expert appraisal committee]

    • Make recommendations to regulatory body
    • Within 60 days
  • Issues
    • EIA by project proponent
    • Report manipulation
    • EAC lacks skilled personnel
    • Wide exemptions

Draft EIA notification 2020

  • Six stage process

    Scoping → draft EIA → public consultation → final EIA → appraisal → approval or rejection

  • 5 categories of projects - earlier 3
  • B2B_2B2​﻿: no “environmental clearance” but needs “environmental permission”
  • Technical expert committee - to classify projects into categories
  • Online submission of EIA application
  • 90 days to grant clearance
  • Appeal at NGT

Criticism

  • Public to submit within 20 days → earlier 30
  • Post facto approval
  • 1.5 lakh m2\pu{1.5 lakh m2}1.5 lakhm2﻿ land increase in project does not require EIA → earlier allowed increase without EIA was 20,000 m2\pu{20,000 m2}20,000 m2﻿
  • Submit clearance report every year → earlier it was six months
  • Exemptions to “strategic projects” declared by centre

1. Agroforestry, Social Forestry, Joint Forest Management and Tribology :

Agroforestry - scope and necessity; role in the life of people and domestic animals and in

integrated land use, planning especially related to (i) soil and water conservation; (ii) water

recharge; (iii) nutrient availability to crops; (iv) nature and ecosystem preservation including

ecological balances through pest-predator relationships and (v) providing opportunities for

enhancing bio-diversity, medicinal and other flora and fauna. Agro forestry systems under

different agro-ecological zones; selection of species and role of multipurpose trees and NTFPs,

techniques, food, fodder and fuel security. Research and Extension needs.

Social/Urban Forestry : objectives, scope and necessity; peoples participation.

JFM - principles, objectives, methodology, scope, benefits and role of NGOs.

Tribology - tribal scene in India; tribes, concept of races, principles of social grouping, stages

of tribal economy, education, cultural tradition, customs, ethos and participation in forestry

programmes.

Soil

Soil

Unconsolidated mineral material - on immediate earth surface - serves as natural medium of growth for plants on land

Pedology

Study of soil formation, classification, and description

Edaphology

Study of soil from point of view of agriculture crops

Regolith

Soil composition

  • solid (50%)
    • Organic - humus
    • Inorganic - sand, silt, clay
  • Liquid (25%)
  • Gas (25%)

Minerals

  • Primary - Quartz, Mica, Feldspar
  • Secondary - Clay minerals, hydrous oxide

Soil Profile

Forest SoilCultivation
develop under natural conditionsInfluenced by human activity
High organic contentLow
Uniform moisture because of litter fall and tree shadeVarying
Low soil temperature because of moist condition and tree shadeHigher
Slow nutrient releases
Less nutrient cycling
More demand for mineral nutrients
Physical and chemical properties of soil varies as per management

Rock and its formation

Rock

Hard mass of mineral - made of one or multiple rock forming minerals

Petrology

Study of rocks

Rock types (based on formation)

igneous rock

  • By cooling of molten magma
  • Crystal formation
  • No – fossil, layer, porosity

Types based on origin

  • Extrusive
    • Magma on earth surface
    • e.g. Basalt rock
  • Intrusive
    • Within earth
    • e.g. granite

Types based on chemical composition

  • Acidic
    • >60% Silica
    • e.g. Granite
  • Basic
    • <60% Silica
    • e.g. Basalt

Sedimentary rock

  • By sedimentation of fragmented, weathered material of pre-existing rock
  • 75% of surface soil
  • Layers, porous, fossil
  • No crystal
  • e.g. limestone, sandstone

Metamorphic rock

  • Alteration in chemical structure or form of rocks mineral - due to heavy temperature, pressure
  • Thermal metamorphism → heat is main factor
  • Dynamic metamorphism → pressure is main factor
  • Pre-existing → metamorphic
    • Granite → Gneiss
    • Shale → Schist
    • Dolomite → Marble
    • Coal → graphite

Mineral

Mineral

Naturally occurring solid - definite chemical composition + crystal structure

Secondary mineral (clay mineral) → formed from changes in primary mineral and rock

Essential minerals → chief constituent of rock (e.g. Feldspar, Pyroxene, Mica)

Accessory mineral

  • present in small quantity
  • Presence and absence does not alter rock properties
  • e.g. Magnetite

Ways of mineral formation

  1. Solidification of magma
  1. Precipitation from liquid solution
    • Ions dissolved in liquid → liquid – ion bond → from solid Crystal → crystal separates from liquid
    • e.g. Salt crystals develop when sea water evaporates.
  1. Precipitation from gas
    • Volcanic gas → enters atmosphere → cool quickly → minerals precipitate directly
    • e.g. bright yellow sulfur deposit.
  1. Biomineralization
    • Metabolism of a living organism causes atom to precipitate
    • e.g. corals extract CaX+\ce{Ca+}CaX+﻿ and COX3X2−\ce{CO3^{2-}}COX3​X2−﻿ from water → form shells of calcite

Mineral classification by chemical composition

categoryDescriptionExample
Oxide mineralMetal cation - bonded with - oxygen anionHematite FeX2OX3\ce{Fe2O3}FeX2​OX3​﻿, Magnetite FeX3OX4\ce{Fe3O4}FeX3​OX4​﻿
SilicateSiOX4X4−\ce{SiO4^{4-}}SiOX4​X4−﻿Quartz SiOX2\ce{SiO2}SiOX2​﻿
sulfideSX2−\ce{S^{2-}}SX2−﻿Pyrite FeSX2\ce{FeS2}FeSX2​﻿
sulfateSOX4X2−\ce{SO4^{2-}}SOX4​X2−﻿Gypsum CaSOX4 ⋅ 2 HX2O\ce{CaSO4.2H2O}CaSOX4​⋅2HX2​O﻿
carbonateCOX3X2−\ce{CO3^{2-}}COX3​X2−﻿Calcite CaCOX3\ce{CaCO3}CaCOX3​﻿
halideClX−, FX−\ce{Cl-,F-}ClX−,FX−﻿Rock salt NaCl\ce{NaCl}NaCl﻿

Weathering of rock

Weathering

disintegration, and decomposition of rock and mineral → regolith formation

  • parent material - unconsolidated mineral material from which soil develops
  • Types

    physical/mechanical

    • Frost cracking in cold climate
    • Salt crystal growth - inside crevices - in warm climate
    • Thermal action - different mineral expand at different rate
    • Glacier action - moraine formation by glacier

    chemical

    • Hydration - water combines chemically
    • Hydrolysis - water dissolves as HX+, OHX−\ce{H+,OH-}HX+,OHX−﻿ ions
    • Solution - running water removes water soluble substances → develops holes, rills on rock surface
    • Carbonisation - COX2+any base\ce{CO2 +any base}COX2​+any base﻿ → rock decomposition
    • Oxidation and reduction

    Biological

    • Earthworm pass soil through their alimentary canal → Change soil’s physical and chemical property
    • Root of plant penetrate rocks
    • Moss, Lichen, Fungi, bacteria release acid on rock

Soil formation

  • Conversion of Regolith into true soil
graph LR
  A[soil farming factor] --> B[active]
  A --> C[passive]
  B --> climate
  B --> vegetation
  C --> F[parent material - rock]
  C --> G[topography]
  C --> time

influence of parent rock on distribution of tree species

  • Parent rock is passive factor
  • decides soils
    • Texture
    • Structure
    • Water holding capacity
    • pH
    • Mineral
Soil Group tree
Laterite soilXylia xylocarpa (Burma Ironwood)
Basalt soilTectona grandis (Teak)
Acidic rockShorea robusta (Sal)
Quartzite rockPinus roxburghii (Chir Pine)
Mica Schist rockPinus wallichiana (Blue Pine)
Conglomerate and metamorphic sandstoneDipterocarpus spp. (Keruing)

Pedogenic process (soil farming process)

  • soil formation process is complex → many reactions occur simultaneously

general process

  • Humification - raw organic matter transforms into humus
  • Eluviation - leaching of minerals from upper layer to lower
  • Illuviation - Sahil material removal from eluvial layer deposits into a lower layer
  • Horizonation - differentiation of soil in different layers

Specific process

(only in specific environment)

  • Calcification - deposition of CaCOX3\ce{CaCO3}CaCOX3​﻿ → formation of calcic horizon
  • Decalcification - removal of CaCOX3\ce{CaCO3}CaCOX3​﻿ by leaching
  • Laterization
    • organic and silicate matter eluviate to lower layer
    • Upper rare remains reach in iron oxide
  • Salinization - Punjab, Haryana
  • Desalination
  • Pedo-turbation - soil is mixed to action of microorganism (earthworm)

Soil properties

Physical properties

Soil texture

  • Relative percentage of sand, silt, clay in soil
  • Cannot be changed ⇒ basic, and permanent feature
  • Hydrometric method (mechanical analysis) separates sand, silt, clay
  • Soil texture
    • Sandy soil ⇒ coarse texture
    • Loamy soil ⇒ medium texture → best for agriculture
    • Clay soil ⇒ fine texture

Soil structure

  • Arrangement of primary soil particles into a pattern

Soil density

  • True density → weightvolume\text{weight} \over \text{volume}volumeweight​﻿ for solid portion of soil
  • Bulk density → weightvolume\text{weight} \over \text{volume}volumeweight​﻿ of dry soil → includes volume of solid and pore space ⇒ always less than true density

Soil porosity

  • Part of soil volume not occupied by solid particle
  • Tells about → soil aeration, permeability, infiltration
  • Sandy soil → macro pore → gravitational water passes through
  • Clayey soil → micro pores → holds capillary water

Soil water

  • Gravitational water
    • At macro pores
    • Moves due to gravity

  • Capillary water
    • At micropore
    • Retained by surface forces
    • Free and mobile
    • Evaporate easily
    • Roots absorb it → therefore called available water

  • Hygroscopic water
    • Water held tightly on surface of colloidal soil particles
    • In vapor form
    • Unavailable water

Chemical properties

pH

  • Excess HX+\ce{H+}HX+﻿ ions → acidic
  • Excess OHX−\ce{OH-}OHX−﻿ ions → basic

electrical conductivity

  • Proportional to amount of soluble salts

Ion exchange

  • Movement of ion between : exchangeable site and soil solution
  • Reversible
  • Essential for nutrient supply to plants
  • Cation exchange capacity : number of exchangeable cations present per unit weight of dry soil
  • Anion exchange capacity: number of exchangeable anions present per unit weight of dry soil
  • Base saturation = basic cationtotal cation exchange capacity\text{basic cation} \over \text{total cation exchange capacity}total cation exchange capacitybasic cation​﻿

Biological properties

Soil organic matter

  • Humus - Fully decomposed, a dead organic matter, present in soil
  • Duff - partially decomposed
  • litter (or detritus) - freshly fallen plant and animal material
  • Types of humus

    Mor

    • Thick mat of un-decomposed or partially decomposed litter
    • Not incorporated in soil
    • e.g - Conifer forest

    Moder

    • Partially decomposed
    • Shallow incorporated
    • e.g. broad leaved deciduous

    Mull

    • Well decomposed
    • Mixed deeply

    Muck

    • Highly decomposed - original plant part cannot be recognised
    • contains more mineral
    • darker than peat

Rhizobium

  • fix atmospheric Nitrogen

Mycorrhiza

  • mobilize nutrients + fight pathogen

4 types of soil microorganisms

  • Microflora – bacteria, fungi, algae, etc.
  • Microfauna – protozoa e.g. amoeba
  • macro flora – roots of higher plants
  • macro fauna – insect, spider, earthworm, snail

Soil types

Alluvial soil

Features

  • types
    • Deltaic alluvial
    • coastal alluvial
  • Rivers deposit alluvium to flood plane
  • Kankar formation – due to poor drainage
  • banger – old alluvium – has kankar
  • khadar – new alluvium – poor nitrogen and phosphorus

Trees

Sal

Black cotton soil

  • Derive from Deccan trap
  • rich in lime magnesia Alumina
  • poor in nitrogen and phosphorus

Teak

Babool

Red and yellow soil

  • Derived from crystalline and metamorphic rock
  • Red color – diffusion with iron
  • Yellow color – hydrated form
  • Shallow soil
  • Low insoluble salt

Laterite soil

  • Due to heavy rainfall leaching and alternate high temperature
  • Heavy rain Leach salt
    • Leave them in porus matrix of vesicular structure
    • Facilitates easy drainage
  • Has hydrated oxide of Fe, Al\ce{Fe,Al}Fe,Al﻿
  • Poor cation exchange capacity
  • Western ghats and Northeast
  • Xylia xyrocarpa (Burma Ironwood)
  • cashew nut

Desert soil

  • High soluble salt percentage
  • high pH
  • Rajasthan

Prosopis juliflora

Acacia camaldulensis

Acacia fortilia (Israeli babool)

Acacia senegal (Kumat)

Peat Soil

  • Formed due to accumulation of organic material material in soil under restricted drainage condition
  • During monsoon
  • Acidic in nature due to an anaerobic decomposition of organic material

Syzygium cumini (Jamun)

Salix alba (Salix)

Afforestation of difficult sites

Hot desert and shifting sand tunes

Distribution

  • Area: 31.7 mn ha
  • Area of hot desert – 61% in Rajasthan (Thar desert)

Types

  • Desert
  • Ravine sand
  • Coastal sand

Sand dune

  • Dominant landform – covers 60% of Thar desert
  • Issues
    • Poor nutrient
    • Unstable structure – shifting
    • Poor water holding
    • High salinity
    • High pH
    • Poor rainfall
    • Hardpan CaCOX3\ce{CaCO3}CaCOX3​﻿
  • leads to
    • Failure of seed germination
    • Wind blows seedling
    • Sand buries seedling

Local factor

  • Rainfall – 10–45 cm
  • Temperature – 48° in summer, 15°C in winter
  • Wind – 100–150 km/h
  • Sandy soil
    • hardpan of CaCOX3\ce{CaCO3}CaCOX3​﻿
    • Low nutrient
    • coarse texture
    • Poor water holding
    • high pH
    • Deficient moisture

Sand dune stabilisation

  • Protect area from biotic pressure
    • Prevent vegetation destruction by human and animals
    • Iron barbed wire fencing
  • Micro – wind break erection
    • Across wind direction
      • Parallel strip design
      • Checkerboard design
    • Use local brush wood: Prosopis cineraria (Khejri)
  • Afforestation of sand dunes
    • Mulching – bury local shrub upside down in parallel strips
    • sowing across windbreak – creeper, grass, shrub, small tree
    • Nursery raised sapling of larger trees – planted in monsoon – regular watering

Planting method

  • Grass, creeper - direct sowing
  • Tree
    • 5 month old nursery raised
    • 5 m x 5 m planting
  • Brick plantation
  • Root cutting – l:60−80 ml:\pu{60-80m}l:60−80 m﻿

Species

  • Grass – Chencherus ciliaris (Anjan)
  • Creeper – Cucumus spp. (Kachri)
  • Trees
    • Acacia tortilis (Israeli babul)
    • Acacia senegal (Kumat)
    • Prosopis juliflora (English Babul)

acidic soil

  • Soil pH < 7

Cause

  • leaching of base due to high rainfall
  • Acidic nature of parent rock
  • Farmers using acid forming fertilizer
  • acidic minerals – AlX2OX3, FeX2OX3\ce{Al2O3,Fe2O3}AlX2​OX3​,FeX2​OX3​﻿
  • COX2\ce{CO2}COX2​﻿ accumulation
  • Accumulation of leaf litter

Type

  • Active acidity ⇒ increased HX+\ce{H+}HX+﻿ concentration → not much impact
  • Exchange acidity ⇒ HX+\ce{H+}HX+﻿ absorbed by soil colloids → High impact

Impact

  • Toxicity ⇒ impact plant growth by disturbing water absorption, and translocation
  • Nutrient unavailability ⇒
    • Nitrogen fixation is hindered
    • Phosphorus unavailable

Remedy

  • Lime application - CaO, CaCOX3\ce{CaO,CaCO3}CaO,CaCOX3​﻿
  • Remove leaf litter

Saline alkaline soil

  • Area - 0.6 mn ha
  • Soil with toxic concentration of chloride (ClX−)(\ce{Cl-})(ClX−)﻿ and sulfide (SX−)(\ce{S-})(SX−)﻿ of Na, Mg\ce{Na,Mg}Na,Mg﻿ → as a result electrical conductivity > 4 ds/m\pu{4 ds/m}4 ds/m﻿ and pH falls below 8.5

causes

  • Irrigation with salty water
  • Arid and semi-arid – rainfall < 55 cm → salt gets deposited on soil surface
  • Impervious hardpan of clay (kankar pan)
  • Basin shaped topography – salt accumulates at one place
  • Water table with salt
  • Blocked drainage — prevents soil leeching
  • Parent rock bearing salt
  • Canal irrigation
  • Seawater flooding

Soil properties

  • Soluble salt leads to high osmotic pressure
    • Affects plant’s water absorption capacity
    • Impacts osmo-regulation
    • Hinders growth
  • Sodium salt – toxicity
  • Hardpan – reduces soil moisture and air availability
  • Low aeration
  • Low microbial activity
  • Poor in Fe, Bo, Zn\ce{Fe,Bo,Zn}Fe,Bo,Zn﻿

Soil reclamation

mechanical method

  • Scrapping salt
  • Break clay hardpan → Flood area with water → This will allow salt leaching
  • Loosen soil by deep tillage → allows rapid root development
  • Deep trenches (1-2 ft) around field → salt comes to this trench by seepage → drain
  • Use non-salty water for irrigation
  • Mound plantation - for young seedling

chemical method

  • Addition of
    • Gypsum :12−15 ton/ha\pu{12-15 ton/ha}12−15 ton/ha﻿
    • Sulfur :2.4−4 ton/ha\pu{2.4-4 ton/ha}2.4−4 ton/ha﻿
    • Iron pyrite FeSX2\ce{FeS2}FeSX2​﻿
  • Maintain soil fertility via
    • Manures
    • Fertilizers
    • Farm yard manure

biological method

  • use of molasses
  • Use salt tolerant plant
    • Acacia nilotica (Babool)
    • Azadirachta indica (Neem)
  • Flooding → green algae grow → apply farm yard manure

Ravine land

Distribution

  • Network of deep gullies – cut whole land mass
  • ≈1 mn ha\approx \pu{1 mn ha}≈1 mnha﻿
  • Banks of River Yamuna, Chambal, Betwa

Locality factors

  • 75–125 cm rainfall
  • Temperature – 48°C in summer, freezing and frost in winter
  • Steep slope – maximum runoff
  • Gully depth up to 100 m
  • Subsurface hardpan formation – kankar pan formation

Soil working

  • Grow local brushwood
  • Check dam and contour bunding
  • Plantation work – at the boundaries of check dam and contour
  • Break hardpan

Species

  • Acacia nilotica (Babool)
  • Dalbergia sissoo (Shisham)
  • Acacia catechu (Khair)

Aerial seedling at chambal

Cold desert

Refer

Coastal sand dune

Distribution

  • Thin strip of east and West Coast
  • 8.4 mn ha

Locality factor

  • Alkaline soil, poor nutrients
  • Low water holding capacity
  • High water table – waterlogging
  • Texture – Sandy,
    • Runn of Kutchh 60%
  • High sodium salt
  • Rainfall – 50–350 cm

issues

Need forest belt to deal with

  • Cyclone
  • Prevent salt spray
  • Tsunami

species

  • Mangrove species
  • Sundari tree
  • Casurina equisetifolia (Coastal sea oak)
  • Cocus nucifera (Coconut)

Wetland

  • Area where soil is waterlogged or poorly drained
    • e.g. - large parts of Punjab and Haryana due to Canal irrigation

Locality factor

  • Defective aeration
  • Excessive salt concentration
  • Poor nutrient availability

soil working

  • Deepening of drains
  • cross drains (45-90 cm)
  • removes saline patches by making ridge or open trench
  • Tree planting on raised mounds

species

  • Salix spp
  • Syzygium cumini
  • Acacia nilotica
  • Terminalia arjuna
  • Casurina equisetifolia
  • Eucalyptus robustus

Mining area

  • Open cast mining – coal, bauxite, limestone – vegetation destroyed, and soil profile disturbed

Locality factor

  • Full of Boulder, stone, inert materials
  • Undulating topography
  • Absence of organic matter
  • High biotic interference i.e. human activity

Soil working

  • Level area with bulldozer
  • Pits of size 60 cm3, 2m ×2m\pu{60 cm3, 2m \times 2m}60 cm3,2m×2m﻿ space
    • Filled with mixture of
      • Fertile soil
      • FYM (0.5 kg/pit)(\pu{0.5 kg/pit})(0.5 kg/pit)﻿
      • Mycorrhizal inoculum
      • Fertilizer
      • Insecticide
  • Plant container raised seedling of 10–12 month old age

species

  • Acacia auriculiformis
  • Dalbergia sissoo
  • Eucalyptus camaldulensis
  • Albizia lebbeck

Watershed

Watershed

  • A geo – hydrological unit of land — that feeds at the water running under it → and drains at a common point

watershed management

  • Process of creating and implementing – plan, program, policies – to sustain and enhance watershed functions

Objectives of watershed management

  • Improve percolation and infiltration
  • Control runoff
  • Rainwater harvesting
  • Control flood
  • Double farmers income
  • Develop forest and timber

Importance in rural development

  • Irrigation water facility
  • Drinking water
  • Improve water table
  • Increase pastureland
  • Employment

Characteristics

Rainfall

If rainfall moves downstream, peak discharge occurs early

Climate

Dry climate ⇒ more evaporation loss

Size

Large ⇒ more storage

Shape

  • Large watershed ⇒ more infiltration

Slope

Elevation

Vegetation

Geology

Land use

Hydrology

  • If cracks in underlying rocks → water percolate easily

Time of lag (t1)(t_1)(t1​)﻿

  • Time between center of mass rainfall (hyetograph) and peak of hydrograph

Reason for watershed deterioration

  • Faulty agricultural practices
  • Faulty silvicultural practices
  • Uncontrolled mining and quarrying
  • Construction work
  • Waterlogging
  • Shifting cultivation
  • Encroachment of forest land

Forest hydrology

Refer

Role of forest in watershed management

  • Precipitation
    • leaf canopy intercepts rainfall
      • Acts like sponge
      • Absorbs up to 18% precipitation
    • Reduce precipitation speed
      • Gradually release it into channel
      • Slowing speed also increases time for groundwater recharge
  • Pollutant removal
    • Reduce 80% nitrate and 75% phosphorus – from agricultural field runoff that could otherwise enter river and stream
  • Role in river stream
    • Stability to river bank
    • Reduce stream velocity
    • Reduce downstream flooding
    • Buffer during stream overflow

Factors affecting watershed management

  • Lack of financial resource
  • Unsustainable policy
  • Faulty agricultural and cultural practices
  • land ownership issues
  • Peoples participation and once project is developed
  • Labor issues
  • Poor implementation
  • No legal backing

Rainwater harvesting

  • Preventing rainwater runoff – to collect and store for future use
  • Method

    micro-catchment

    • Collect surface runoff as sheet flow over short distance
    • Small catchment area ≈1000 m2\approx \pu{1000 m2}≈1000 m2﻿

    On-farm system

    • Contour
    • Bunds
    • Bench Terrace
    • Small pits
    • Runoff strip

    rooftop system

    • At building
    • Courtyard
    • Lawn

    macro-catchment

    • Collect runoff from large catchment area
    • Catchment area is a natural large area like steppe, mountain, etc.

    Wadi-bed system

    • Wadi-bed used to store water
    • Either on the surface by blocking flow
    • Or slowing flow to allow infiltration

    off-wadi system

    • Outside wadi-bed
    • Structures built to force water to flow towards agriculture fields

Component of watershed

  • Soil and water conservation
  • Water harvesting
  • Crop management
  • Alternate land use system

Benefits of watershed management

  • River channel stability - tree plantation, intercept rain, control runoff
  • Landslide control
  • Rehabilitation of degraded area
  • Avalanche control

Steps in watershed development

Collect basic information

  • Land ownership
  • Basic information
  • Topography
  • Cropping system
  • Land use pattern
  • Rainfall
  • Socio-economic status of population

Developmental component

  • Soil and watershed conservation
  • Runoff harvesting
  • Groundwater recharge
  • Develop degraded forest

Soil

Forests Soils: classification, factors affecting soil formation; physical, chemical and biological

properties.

Soil conservation - definition, causes for erosion; types - wind and water erosion;

conservation and management of eroded soils/areas, wind breaks, shelter belts; sand dunes;

reclamation of saline and alkaline soils, water logged and other waste lands. Role of forests in

conserving soils. Maintenance and build up of soil organic matter, provision of loppings for

green leaf manuring; forest leaf litter and composting; Role of microorganisms in ameliorating

soils; N and C cycles, VAM.

Watershed Management - concepts of watershed; role of mini-forests and forest trees in

overall resource management, forest hydrology, watershed development in respect of torrent

control, river channel stabilization, avalanche and landslide controls, rehabilitation of

degraded areas; hilly and mountain areas; watershed management and environmental

functions of forests; water-harvesting and conservation; ground water recharge and watershed

management; role of integrating forest trees, horticultural crops, field crops, grass and fodders.

3. Environmental Conservation and Biodiversity :

Environment; components and importance, principles of conservation, impact of

deforestation; forest fires and various human activities like mining, construction and

developmental projects, population growth on environment.

Pollution - types, global warming, green house effects, ozone layer depletion, acid rain, impact

and control measures, environmental monitoring; concept of sustainable development. Role of

trees and forests in environmental conservation; control and prevention of air, water and noise

pollution. Environmental policy and legislation in India. Environmental Impact Assessment.

Economics assessment of watershed development vis-a-vis ecological and environmental

protection.

Tree Improvement and Seed Technology

Forest genetics

Branch of forestry involving study of heredity and variation in forest trees.

Tree breeding

Application of genetics, reproductive biotechnology, economic principles for genetic improvement and management of forest trees.

Tree improvement

A silvicultural tool that deals with genetic make up of trees to improve yield, and quality of forest produce.

Heritability

Proportion of genes in controlling phenotype, rather than proportion of environmental factors.

Objectives of tree improvement

  • New species with desired characteristics
  • High yielding varieties - e.g. Dalbergia sissoo (DS 18) by TNAU has 150 ton\pu{150ton}150 ton﻿ yield.
  • Improve wood quality - wood density
  • Eliminate undesirable elements - e.g. Phorbol esters in Jatropha hinders its use as biodiesel.
  • Pest-resistant varieties
  • Thermo-insensitive varieties to deal with climate change.
  • Gene Conservation
  • Trees with desired characteristics - clean bole, small crown, self pruning ability

Advantages of tree improvement

  • Change in genetic makeup is permanent
  • Improve characters
  • Developed the material can be used for perpetuity using vegetative propagation
  • Gene Conservation
  • Domestication of exotics
  • Meet specific wood requirement e.g. plywood.

Limitations

  • Large area for R&D
  • Large size of tree - difficult to do breeding work
  • High cost
  • Long life of tree
    • Difficult to maintain record
    • Difficult to see generational changes
  • Impact of environment on phenotypes
  • less studies on tree species compared to crops

Variation

Variation

Individuals of same species show, genetic, and morphological differences, e.g differences in hair color.

  • Causes
    • Environmental influence
    • Mutation, genetic drift, natural selection, inbreeding, etc.
  • Importance
    • Members of same genus show different adaptation, mechanisms, e.g. leaf variation in Dalbergia sisoo and Dalbergia latifolia

Types

Phenotypic (somatic)

  • Alter physiological mechanism like color of leaves, tree size, etc
  • Non-heritable
  • Genotypic variation + environmental influence
  • Generally Not used for breeding program

Genotypic (germinal)

  • Due to mutation or rearrangement of genes
  • heritable
  • e.g. White Tiger in Bandhavgarh
  • Types
    • Continuous variation
      • Variation due to crossing over
      • Cannot give rise to new species
        • Substantive - variation in shape, size, colour
        • Meristic - variation in number
    • Discontinuous variation
      • Due to mutation
      • Forms new species - mutants
        • Substantive
        • Meristic
    • Additive variation
      • Cumulative effect of gene on segregated loci
    • Non-additive
      • dominance - between allele at same loci e.g. Aa
      • Epistasis - between allele of different loci

Exotics

Indigenous versus exotic

Exotics

Selection

Selection

Process of choosing a tree with superior genotype and phenotype, based on parameters like: growth rate, tree form, etc.

Selection differential

Difference between mean of selected group versus mean of population

Selection intensity

Mean of deviation from the population mean, based on measurement of phenotypic standards.

selection criteria →

Selection method →

  • plus tree selection
  • elite tree selection

Mass production

  • seed production area
  • seed orchard
  • tree breeding

Selection criteria

for timbers

  • Large tree
  • Fast growing
  • Narrow crown
  • Straight, clean bole
  • Self pruning
  • Thick bark
  • More fiber

For fodder

  • Medium size
  • high branching habit
  • More leaves
  • Digestibility
  • pest-resistant
  • drought-resistant
  • frost resistant

For fuelwood

For Agroforestry

Selection method

candidate tree

  • Tentative trees for inclusion in a breeding program
  • No measurement done to compare with surrounding tree

Plus tree

  • Superior phenotype
    • for pure, even-aged : comparison (check) tree selection method
    • For mix, uneven-aged
      • Baseline (index) selection method
      • Regression equation method
      • Mother tree selection
      • Subjective grading method

Elite tree

  • Superior genotype and superior phenotype
  • Method
    • Provenance test
    • Progeny test
    • Clonal test

Plus Tree

Comparison / check tree selection method

  • Select candidate trees from stand
  • pick few comparison trees from dominant/co-dominant class from same stand of similar age within 100m range of candidate tree
  • plus: superior to comparison tree
  • Precaution
    • Not for uneven aged
    • Doesn't consider isolated and border trees
    • Not more than 3–4 candidate trees per ha
    • Should have good seed production capacity

Baseline / index selection method

  • Select candidate tree from stand
  • For trees in that Neighbourhood find average of various traits
  • Index this to calculate minimum selection of standard (MSS)
  • Plus: superior to MSS
  • Application – both even and uneven aged

Regression equation method

  • Sample characters of several trees
  • Each regression line represents one character
  • Compare candidate tree character with regression line
  • Precaution
    • Age of tree must be known

Mother tree selection method

  • Best suited when there is no urgent need to get improved seed
  • Site condition - Seriously degraded stand
    • Only few scattered trees with good phenotypes
    • Comparison tree not available
  • Procedure
    • Locate good trees
    • Seedlings are established by genetic test
    • Best parents are established in seed Orchards
  • Suitable for - short rotation, hardwood species

Subjective grading system

  • Selection based only on judgment of experienced scientists
  • Sometimes used along mother tree method

Other methods

  • Direct selection
    • Selection based on one character (usually timber yield)
    • Used for tree breeding program
    • But genotype, environmental factors can impact yield → less effective
  • Indirect selection
    • Uses character that are more correlated to yield, but doesn't use yield itself
  • Mass selection
    • Individual plants are selected based on phenotype, out of mixed population
  • Tandem selection
    • One desired trait selected → breeding to improve this trait further → achieved desired improvement → focus on other trait
  • Independent culling
    • Multi trait selection method
    • Minimum acceptable value of each trait is set
    • Individuals fall below any minimum value are removed
  • Selection index
    • Multi trait selection method
    • Combines information on traits into one single index
  • Recurrent selection
    • Individuals are selected after many generations of breeding

Elite tree

Provenance test

  • Provenance = place of origin
  • To find seed from which area is best suited for local condition
  • Provenance testing
    • Seed of the same plant species is collected from different area
    • Raised at one place to compare performance e.g. Teak seeds from different states were raised at Chandrapur forest range

Phases

  1. Range wide provenance phase
    • Objective
      • Range wide test to find total genetic variation of a species
      • Find extent of variation within a province for species
    • Outcome
      • 10–13 promising provenance
  1. Restricted Provenance Phase
    • detect minor differences between stands to find location of specific stand with best germ plasm
    • includes statistical experiment design
  1. Provenance Proving Phase
    • to confirm actual stand under normal plantation condition

Role in tree improvement

  • Confirm that -
    • selected stand is best suited
    • Selected plus tree has superior genotype
    • Breeder has best genotype

Progeny test

  • Evaluating worth of parents based on performance of their progenies
  • A.k.a. Vilmorin isolation principle.

Procedure

  • Grow progenies of selected tree at different sample plot, but in similar environment
  • Collect data after fixed interval e.g. 15 days
  • Estimate progeny performance

Types

Half sib

  • When only one parent in (mother tree) close is known.
  • Done at the start of breeding program when quick results are needed
  • Seeds are collected from open pollinated plants
  • Tells general combining ability (GCA)

Full sib

  • When both (seed and pollen) parents are known
  • Seeds collected from cross pollinated plants - anthers are removed before their maturity
  • Tells specific combining ability (SCA)

Role in tree improvement

  • Calculate heritability
  • Calculate GCA and SCA
  • Held in removal of inferior genotype from seed Orchard
  • Establishment of progeny tested seed orchard

Combining ability

  • Combining ability

    Ability of an individual when crossed to produce progeny with strong expression of a particular trait.

general combining ability

  • Ability of individual to produce progeny with higher genetic quality when crossed
  • via half-sib families
  • Allows for selection of suitable parents for hybridization
  • Related to heritability
  • Due to additive genetic variance

Specific combining ability

  • When progeny of a particular full-sib cross perform better than GCA
  • via full-sib families
  • Allows for identification of superior cross combination
  • Related to heterosis
  • Due to dominance genetic variance

Application of combining ability in tree improvement

  • Most tree characteristics are of polygenetic nature
  • Combining ability helps to develop develop varieties with desirable traits

Clonal test

Within population of and an improved stand, there are individuals of outstanding characteristics - they are vegetative propagated to produce superior clones

  • Test is necessary to
    • Test their performance
    • Ensure that they are indeed superior
    • That their performance is consistent
  • Methodology - similar to progeny testing
  • Objective - screening best clones for production of improved stock

Seed production area

  • Area of phenotypically superior stand of commercial trees inside permanent forest estate. It consists of vigorously, growing trees, and thinning of poor phenotype to produce large quantity of seed.

Purpose and advantage

  • Continuous supply of seed
  • seed with known origin
  • High-quality seed
  • Reduced seed collection cost
  • Create seed bank
  • Increase genetic diversity
  • Integrated seedling restoration program can be developed

Development of Seed Production Area

criteria

  • Known seed source
  • Tree should be mature for seed production
  • Stand should be fully stocked
  • Large number of trees with good phenotype
  • No pest or disease infection
  • Trees should have capacity to produce flower and seed
  • Stand should not be used for commercial timbering
  • Minimum 4 ha land
  • Isolation zone to prevent stray pollination

Steps

  • Identify species
    • High commercial value
    • Seed – high potential for reproduction
    • High seed production capacity - e.g. Teak
  • Survey area - identify stand with healthy trees
  • Mark boundaries
  • Create pollination dilution zone - 200–500 m width
  • Removal of trees from SPA - diseased and defective, other species
  • Other Silvicultural operations - fencing, weed control, pruning

Limitation

  • Land must be government owned
  • Site must be accessible
  • Skilled labor force
  • Avoid inbreeding
  • Competition from new technology – tissue culture, bio-technology

Seed Orchard

Clone, Ortet and Ramet

Clone is an individual obtained from single plant via asexual reproduction.

An ortet is a single tree that is selected from a family of seed origin, while a ramet is a clone that is derived from an ortet.

Seed Orchard

Area where superior genotype, phenotype are established - managed extensively for seed production or tree breeding.

Types

Based on type of planting material

  • Clonal
  • Seedling
  • Extensive seedling
    • Established with special stock from a balanced mix of minimum 60 good parents
    • Used where large number of families are involved

Based on purpose of Orchard

  • Production
  • Breeding

Objectives

  • Produce genetically improved seeds
  • Produce large quantity of seed
  • Maximise genetic gain
  • Prevent stray pollen contamination
  • minimize cost
  • Facilitate inter-mating and inter-mating for seed production

Clonal Seed Orchard

  • S. O. established by using vegetative propagation of selected plus trees.
  • Types

    accompanied s.o. a.k.a progeny tested

    • Clone from plus tree
    • grown vegetative method to reproductive age → progeny, tested by both open pollination and cross pollination (half sib and full sib)
    • Removal of undesired clones

    Unaccompanied a.k.a without progeny tested

    • Clone from wild population
    • Grown via vegetable method → used as a means for conservation of species under threat or gene conservation

    advantages

    • Testing possible at individual level
    • Outstanding genome appears many times
    • Flowering appears earlier than accompanied

    Disadvantages

    • Narrow Genetic base
    • High skill needed
    • Incompatibility between scion and stock makes vegetative propagation difficult

Seedling Seed Orchard

  • Progenies from open pollination of selected phenotypes → using seed as propagation material

advantage

  • Simultaneous - genetic testing and seed production
  • Broad genetic base
  • Testing at family level

Disadvantage

  • Outstanding genotype will appear only once
  • First flowering fruitition takes longer than clonal s.o.
  • Harvesting seed difficult due to more tree height

clonal seed Orchard

  • Established by vegetative propagation
  • Narrow, genetic base
  • Outstanding genotype appears many times
  • Testing at individual level
  • First flowering and fruit early
  • Easy to harvest due to low crown and branch

seedling

  • Established by seeds of selected parents
  • Wide genetic base
  • Outstanding genotype will appear once
  • Testing at family level
  • Late flowering and fruits
  • Difficult to harvest

Generations of Seed Orchard

  • First generation - clone obtained from plus tree → vegetative propagation → roughing (removal of inferior plant and seedling) based on progeny testing
  • 1.5 generation - 1st generation + introduction of new improved genotype
  • Second generation - 1.5 generation + further introduction of new species that replace most all trees of first generation

Seed Orchard management

Planning

Location

  • Well connected roads
  • Protected against wind, frost, fire
  • Should be government land

Climatic factor, Edaphic

  • As per species requirement

Pollination dilution zone (PDZ)

  • width: usually 300–500 m
  • up to 1000 m for windy area
  • conifers: 500–600 m
  • Self pollinated and sporadic flowering plant: <100 m

Size of SO

  • 2.5–5 ha

Breeding method

  • Selection, hybridization

Steps to establish SO

  • Site preparation – cleaning, wedding, soil preparation, add fertilizer
  • Collect clones from plus tree
  • Orchid designing – marking space
  • plantation work
  • Maintenance – cleaning, weeding, stacking
  • Protection against insect and pest
  • Tending operations

SO design

  • Pure rows – all clones sown in parallel rows
  • Chessboard – for bi-clonal orchard
  • Random block
  • Fixed block
  • Reverse block
  • Balanced incomplete block
  • Unbalanced incomplete block

SO management

aim

  • Increase seed yield
  • Record and check growth of progenies

Silvicultural operations

  • Wedding, cleaning, roughing (removing poor ramets), tending, fertigation

Pollen management

  • Develop pollen dilution zone (PDZ)
  • Regular cleaning of PDZ
  • Prevent self pollination via suitable design
  • Cold water irrigation – delay floral bud burst

Protection

  • Insect, pest, forest fire, illegal felling

See Orchard record

  • Provides history of Orchard
  • Decides future recommendations
  • Record all treatment given to - orchard as a whole and individual tree
  • Information
    • Type of SO
    • Spacing
    • Plantation design and method
    • Thinning operation
    • Fertigation
    • Soil management practices
    • Flowering

Biotechnology in tree improvement

Micro vegetative propagation (tissue culture)

Tissue culture: In-vitro method of vegetative reproduction via plant cell, tissue, organ.

Tree seed technology

  • Deals with production, harvesting, processing, testing, packaging, marketing of seeds
  • Characteristics of good quality seeds
    • Improve variety
    • Genetic purity
    • vigour germination
    • Free from weeds
    • Seeds, health, weight size moisture
  • roguing → removing low quality or diseased plants to prevent downgrading of quality of seed lot
    • Reason for roguing
      • Accidental growth of plants of other species
      • Seed from previous crop on plot
      • Mutation
      • Disease

Seed certification

  • Legally sanctioned system for controlling seed quality

procedure for certification

  • Scrutiny of application by FRI
  • Verification of seed source (provenance)
  • Inspection of SO
  • Post harvest inspection
  • Seed sampling and testing
  • Grant of certification

Certifying agencies

  • FRI
    • Issue guidelines
    • Issue certificate
  • ICFRE Linked Central institutions – e.g. - CAZRI
  • State Forest research Institute
  • Botanical survey of India – in some cases

Information in certificate

  • Scientific name, common name, family, variety
  • Provenance (place of origin)
  • characters of mother plant - height, diameter, crown shape
  • Date of collection, method of collection, seed treatment after collection
  • Test on seed - viability days, germination percentage

Purpose and importance

  • Make seed available to people
  • High quality seed
  • Notified varieties
  • Ensure genetic purity
  • Prescribed standards
  • Doubling farmer income
  • Climate change resilience
  • Promote investment

Hybridisation

  • Inbreeding between two genetically divergent individuals
    • Intra-specific : same species
    • Inter-specific : different species
  • Example
    • Eucalyptus fereticornis x E. camaldulensis ⇒ FRI-4 : shows heterosis - 3–5 times superior than parent plants

objective

  • Improve various characteristics of plant so that they become more desirable silviculturally, ecologically, economically
    • high yield
    • Less rotation age
    • Improved quality
    • Insect resistance
    • Small crown
    • Thermal – insensitivity
    • saline tolerant
    • No alleloapathy

Advantage

  • heterosis
    • Improve productivity and production
  • Faster growth rate
  • Inducing polyploidy
    • Production of triploids (3n) or haploids (n)

Problem

  • Trees are cross-pollinated, and heterozygous
  • Homozygous or pure lines are not available in trees
  • First flowering appears late - compared to clonal origin
  • Difficulty to synchronize flowering time in tree
  • Difficult to collect anther due to size of tree
  • Controlled crossing requires knowledge and timing of anthers, pollens
  • If flowering period is missed - need to wait for another year

types

Intraspecific

Interspecific

Intergeneric

Different genera same family

procedure in hybridization

  • Selection of flower in mother tree
  • Emasculation - removal of anthers without affecting female reproductive system
  • Bagging and labeling
  • Collection of pollen grains from another plus tree of required characters → transfer these pollen to our mother plant (pollen reacts with stigma)
  • Fertilization of ovary
  • Removal of bag
  • Harvesting of mature seed
  • Seed processing, treatment, palleting, storage
    • Use in nursery
    • Direct Sowing

Mating design

  • Specifically designed program for crossing of parent trees
  • Purpose
    • Creates progeny population
    • Gives information on further testing
  • Types

    Incomplete Pedigree Design

    • one parent is known

    Complete Pedigree Design

    • both parents are known

incomplete pedigree design

open pollinated mating

  • Easiest method
  • Seats are collected from selected parent tree in natural stand
  • Plants from these are established in SO
  • Utility
    • Tells GCA
    • Estimate breeding values
    • Estimate additive genetic variation
  • Advantages
    • GCA can be used for rouging
    • Tells - genetic variance and heritability
  • Disadvantages
    • Cannot tell about SCA
    • Cannot be used for future generation of selection as identity of other parent is not known

Poly – cross design

  • Each female parent is crossed with mixture of pollen from several selected male parents
  • Utility
    • Estimate - GCA
    • Breeding values
    • Additive genetic variation
  • Advantages
    • Less expensive than complete pedigree
    • Tells - genetic variance and heritability
  • Disadvantages
    • Cannot tell about SCA
    • In advanced generation - selection from poly – cross design is complicated
    • Estimated values may be wrong - due to non-random pollination

complete pedigree design

Nested design

  • Hierarchial mating design
  • Group of parents of one sex is mated to members of other sex
  • Progeny is made of full-sib families
  • Gives estimate on
    • Additive genetic variance
    • Non-additive genetic variance
    • Heritability

Factorial design

  • Members of one sex are crossed in all combinations with several members of other sex
  • Useful for – progeny testing program
  • Estimates – breeding values of genotypes

Simple pair mating design

  • Each parent is mated to one other member of the population
  • Creates
    • Unrelated families in each generation
    • Minimum number of crosses
  • Useful for – maintenance of large population size
  • Not useful for – rouging

Full dialled design

  • Each parent is crossed with all other in all combinations
  • Includes reciprocal crosses

Half dialled design

  • Each parent is crossed with all other in all combinations
  • No reciprocal crosses

Heterosis

  • Process where crossing between two genetically dissimilar parents → leads to F1F_1F1​﻿ population - that has increased or decreased vigour
  • Types based on function

    luxuriant

    • evaluation restricted to one or few characteristics

    Adoptive

    • Evaluation based on fitness of hybrid to environment

    selective

    • Evaluation based on advantage in vegetative phase, not in generative phase

    Reproductive

    • Evaluation based on productivity

application

Leads to increase the growth and development of tree - more yield, more adaptability, more vigour, increased resistance, shorted rotation

4. Tree Improvement and Seed Technology :

General concept of tree improvement, methods and techniques, variation and its use,

provenance, seed source, exotics; quantitative aspects of forest tree improvement, seed

production and seed orchards, progeny tests, use of tree improvement in natural forest and

stand improvement, genetic testing programming, selection and breeding for resistance to

diseases, insects, and adverse environment; the genetic base, forest genetic resources and

gene conservation in situ and ex-situ. Cost benefit ratio, economic evaluation.

Paper 2 Section A

Forest Management and Management Systems

Practical application of - scientific, technical and economic principles - of forest estate to achieve certain objectives.

Goals and Objectives

  • Maximum benefit to maximum people
  • Maintain and increase productivity
  • Promote protective role of forest
  • Habitat to local Flora and fauna
  • Attain normal forest
  • Needs of local population
  • industrial demand
  • Westland improvement
  • carbon sequestration
  • Urban forestry – natural scenic beauty, and pollution control
  • CAMPA plantation

Peculiarities

  • Long rotation period – no private interest – 96% state owned
  • Long period of investment return – 40–120 years
  • Purpose – multipurpose
  • Benefits – tangible and intangible
  • Welfare of – whole society, long-term
  • Large size of forest, Difficult connectivity, Difficult to monitor
  • Regulated by variety of laws and policies
  • Less fertile soil, undulating topography – low productivity
  • Insect, pest attack, forest fire, human and wildlife pressure
  • Landslide, erratic rainfall, drought, soil erosion, cyclone
  • Yield regulation is complex and difficult – difficult to get even aged forest
  • Poor private investment, R&D
  • Civil Society protest, FRA issues, popular opposition to exotics
  • Legal – judiciary intervention

Ways to overcome peculiarities

  • Increasing forest productivity
    • Enrichment plantation
    • Biofertilizer, mycorrhiza to increase soil fertility
    • Integrated pest management
    • Improvised silviculture practices
    • Ecosystem modelling using technology – remote sensing
  • Climate resilience
    • Genetically modified – superior and climatically resilient native trees
    • Introduction of exotics after long-term trial
    • Artificial irrigation facilities to prevent drought stress
  • Reducing biotic pressure
    • Carrying capacity based forest management
    • Mixed cropping to improve insect pest resistance
  • Private sector investment — Privatization of plantation program
  • Connectivity
  • Alternative economy
    • Agro forestry, and farm forestry
    • Food certification, and price assurance by promoting pre-production agreements

Private forest management

  • Focus on tangible benefits only
  • no concern for sustainable yield
  • No concern for large scale social welfare and long-term benefit
  • Focus on immediate benefit and individual benefit
  • Only market oriented approach, not multiple purpose

Comparison of public forestry versus private forestry, ecological forestry versus timber forestry

ObjectivePublic forestry (ecological forestry) private forestry (timber focus forestry)
ManagementSustainability, diversity- economic goals
- ecosystem goals if required by regulatory authorities
ecological implications- emphasises complexity and heterogeneity
– higher species diversity
– reduced insect-pest attack risk
- simplicity and homogeneity
– simple stands, reduced species diversity
- higher risk
Social implications multipurpose, welfare long-term individual welfare with immediate, market driven
Economic implications- returns on capital not the primary performance metric
- sustainable financial returns through strategic harvesting, Eco tourism, ecosystem services
- Higher per unit production cost because of complexity and professional expertise needed
- high return on investment capital is primary concern
- not much concerned with sustainable yield
- lower per per unit production cost
Silvicultural considerations native species, retains defective trees as habitat, long rotation, based on ecological model of stand development species with desirable economic characteristics may include exotics, eliminate defective, short rotation, based on agronomic model

Activities related to forest management

  • forest inventory
  • preparation of working plan
  • silviculture
  • harvesting
  • forest protection, fire management
  • wildlife management
  • monitoring and evaluation
Forest organization

Administrative or organizational classification

graph TD
  Secretary --> B[DG of forest]
  B --> C[ADG, FC]
  B --> D[ADG, NTCA]
  B --> E[ADG, Wildlife]
graph TD
  A[principal chief conservator of forest] --> B[chief conservator of forest] --> C[CF circle] --> D[DFO division] --> E[ACF subdivision] --> F[range officer - range] --> G[sub Range officer - block] --> H[beat officer - beat]
Territorial classification
graph LR
  Range --> block --> compartment --> D[sub compartment]
  • Range — has 10-15 blocks
  • Block
    • Main territorial division
    • Clear cut boundary with pillars
    • Local name e.g. Haldwani block
  • Compartment
    • Permanently defined forest territorial unit
    • Basis for planning, monitoring, recording
    • Smallest permanent working plan unit
    • Boundaries formed by natural features or artificial fire lines
    • Naming: Arabic numeral 1,2,3
    • Based on tree associations, soil, topography and site productivity – biophysical features homogenous so that they can be easily managed
  • Sub-Compartment
    • An area of forest with special description requiring separate silvicultural treatment
    • Silvicultural unit
    • Permanent or temporary
      • Maybe revoked when the crops have been brought into condition that do not require different treatment
    • Name: small letters a,b,c

Compartment

  • Types
  • Based on protection
    • Protected forest
    • Reserve forest
  • Based on intensity of management
    • Small – homogeneous, intensive
    • Large – heterogeneous, for protection and selection forest

  • Need
    • Forest manager can better understand how the different components of the local ecosystem function and interact with each other.
      • Help decide – how to best manager utilized resources – harvest timber, protect biodiversity
