      • Identify potential bottlenecks or vulnerabilities – develop strategies to address these
    • To assess and evaluate growing stock
    • DFO can choose which area to deploy labor and capital
    • Easy work scheduling, and record keeping
    • Planning for rotation felling cycle
    • Area based the silvicultural treatment
    • Preserves local diversity

Compartment history

Documented record of all past events that have affected forest of an individual compartment

Forms

  • Compartment description
  • Compartment enumeration
  • Biodiversity and regeneration assessment
  • Management details
  • Details of NTFP including maps
  • Trees marked for felling since last plan
  • Compartment outturn
  • Harvesting of NTFP
  • Past events during the last plan in the compartment

Compartment description

As per national working plan code 2014 -

  • Identification - division, range, block, compartment
  • Area
  • Location
  • Boundaries
  • Altitude
  • Slope
  • Topography
  • Rock
  • Soil
  • Crop composition
  • Crop density
  • Growing stock
  • Signature - working plan officer

Silvicultural classification
graph LR
  A[Working plan area: division or circle] --> B[Working circle] --> C[Felling series] --> E[Cutting section] --> D[Coupe]

Working circle

A forest area with particular objective, and subject to one silvicultural system, and working plan prescriptions

  • Determination
    • Goal and objectives of forest management
    • Ecological considerations - large enough to include targeted areas of high biodiversity, wetlands, old growth forest or endangered species
    • Skill and ability of team members
    • Logistic feasibility for management and monitoring, road accessibility
    • Designed to allow for - Public participation in planning and decision-making
  • Types
    • Rehabilitation of degraded forest working circle
    • plantation
    • Improvement
    • JFM
    • Wildlife management
    • NTFP
    • Forest protection
    • Soil and moisture conservation
    • Eco development and Eco tourism
    • Biodiversity conservation
    • Selection

Felling series

  • Whole or part of working circle limited to
    • Distribute felling and regeneration to suit conditions
    • Maintain or create a normal distribution of age class
  • Yield is calculated separately for each felling series

Coupe

When felling series is divided into annual coupes.

  • Only in clear felling system
  • Number of coupes = number of rotation years

Cutting Section

  • When it is desirable to avoid felling in continuous coupes in successive year – fire, insect attack
  • A subdivision of a felling series to regulate cutting in some special manner.

Felling series under different silviculture system

Clear felling

Uniform shelterwood system - periodic blocks

  • Age gradation replaces age class
  • Periodic blocks replace annual coupes
  • Example - Chir Pine
    • Rotation: 120 years
    • Regeneration: 30 years
    • 120/30 = 4 periodic blocks

Selection system

  • Ideal – entire area work every year – not practical
  • entire area divided into a number of coupes → each of which is worked at an interval of planned number of years known as felling cycle.
  • Example
    • 100 year rotation, 10 year felling cycle
    • 100/10 = 10 felling coupes
    • each being 1/10th area of working circle
    • Work interval of 10 years
Sustainable yield

Regular and fixed the supply of forest produce with its full capacity without harming productivity of forest

  • How to achieve
    • Same amount of produce on annual or periodic basis.
    • Example – Eucalyptus 20 ha, 10 year rotation - 10 annual coups -
      • Figure - plantation, felling

Advantages

  • Consistent revenue to department
  • Regular work for staff
  • Allows to establish permanent infrastructure and hire skilled workers
  • Assured and continuous supply of food – confidence of industry – market development
  • For developed nation – stagnant demand
  • For protection forest
  • Core of our tribal economy

Disadvantages

  • Rigid supply ignore market fluctuation
  • Growing economic needs increasing supply
  • Fire insect drought – hampers even natural supply
  • Competition from new materials – market demand may change at the end of rotation period
  • Not attractive for private sector

Increasing or progressive yield

  • Concept by Hartig
  • raising productivity of forest and soil by - changing crop composition - replacing original, inferior crop by superior species through silvicultural operations, tending operations, forest enrichment

Advantage

  • Supports increasing demand of market with economic growth - suitable for developing nations
  • introduction of new species
  • Changing species composition
  • For private forestry – attracting private investment - pathway to faster tree planting to achieve carbon sequestration targets
  • Supports R&D and innovation

Intermediate yield

Material or cash return obtained by various thinning operations from a forest before final felling

Intermediate yieldFinal yield
Material obtainedBetween regeneration and final felling at the end of rotation
PurposeTo give proper shape and remove diseased and infected plantsRemove all valuable material at maturity
ReturnSmall size timber, NTFPLarge sized round timber

Yield from Indian forest lower than Western countries

Indian Western
ObjectiveMultiple use sustainable yieldTimber based single use commercial forestry
Forest typeTropical – diverse – timber species compete with non-timber and non-commercial spaces for space, nutrient, moisture, and lightConifers
Heavy biotic pressure – declining forest density
AreaSmall – easy to manage
StakeholdersMultiple beneficiaries – tribals, contractors, wildlife – management by governmentOne stakeholder owns and manages – Corporation or government – re-investment R&D

Rotation

Importance

  • Controlling tree size – longer → larger growth
  • Influences timber yield, profitability, regeneration methods, and productivity of forest
  • Better planning of plantation work
  • Better productivity assessment
  • Stable supply
  • We can fix rotation based on our objective

Limitation

  • Growth rate depends on site quality
  • Sacrifice of immature trees – that could not reach exploitable site due to tending operations
  • Impact of fire, pest - force earlier felling
  • If profit is main objective – cut early on delay as per market demand – forced to change rotation period
  • new technology, social changes, climate change - impact rotation

examples

species rotation lengthPlace
eucalyptus10
Teak 60–120Nilambur (Kerala) - 60 years
Sal90-180Gorakhpur Taungya - 90 years
Chir-Pine 80–120Kangra (HP) - 120
Deodar150Kulu (HP)
Silver fir90Kulu (HP)

Types

Physical rotation

  • Age up to which trees remain sound and can produce viable seed or coppice shoot
  • Fire protection forest, parks, roadside plantation
  • Limitation - time period not fixed, longest - not commercial

Silvicultural

  • Do not fell the crop up to the age it shows satisfactory vigour, growth, and reproduction
  • Applicable – aesthetic and recreation purpose

Importance of physical and silvicultural rotation

  • Beautification of urban centers
  • Pollution buffers
  • Carbon sequestration
  • Raising new crops through natural regeneration

Technical

  • Rotation for which species yields maximum material of specific size or use
  • Application – captive forest

Rotation of maximum volume production

  • Rotation that equals maximum quantity of materials – age at which mean annual increment is maximum
  • applicable - Quantity of or material more important than size – fuel wood, pulp & paper industries, fiber industries

Rotation of highest income/revenue

  • Use highest gross revenue
  • Does not consider capital investment, expenditure, time

Financial or economic rotation

  • Highest net return on invested capital
  • For private forest
  • Determination
    • Based on soil expected value
      • Net present value for an infinite time horizon when starting from bare land.
    • Based on financial yield

      Net Annual income

  • How does soil expected value it help in deciding financial rotation?
    • It was monetary value on land.
    • Using the principle of time value of money – rotation can be decided to achieve maximum return.
    • It accounts for multiple factors – revenue, cost of soil improvement, value of carbon sequestration, etc.

Factors deciding length and choice of rotation

Management objective

objective rotation
services supply Silvicultural + physical
controlling output technical + maximum volume
financial return maximum gross income, financial

Silvicultural characteristic of species

  • Growth rate
  • Natural lifespan
  • Age of best futile seed production
  • Age at which timber starts decorating

  • Site quality – poor – more time
  • Climatic, biotic, topographic factor – is some special protection required or natural growth is possible
  • market demand
  • Socioeconomic – ownership and stakeholders – tribal, forest rights, employment policy of state

Modifying rotation length

Benefits of short rotation

  • More per unit forage production
  • Reduce damage by root rot etc
  • Less thinning needed
  • Less chance of fire damage

Negatives of short rotation

  • Water, soil, nutrient depletion
  • Poor protection role of tree
  • More risk of windthrow
  • Less carbon sequestration, shelter to wildlife
  • Reduce the volume of wood, NTFP production
  • More cost of per unit wood production

Increment

Types

Current annual increment (CAI)

  • Increment during a particular year

Mean annual increment (MAI)

Periodic annual increment

Average annual increments for a given period of time

e.g. between 10th and 15th year.

Final mean annual increment

MAI at rotation

Quality increment

  • Price per unit volume increases because of better quality
  • e.g. Price of 30 year old sandalwood higher than 20 year old because hardwood formation increases with age which is source of sandalwood oil.

Price increment

Due to market fluctuations, not related to quality

Relationship between CAI and MAI

  • Beginning : CAI = MAI
  • Initial phase
    • CAI > MAI
    • MAI is continuously rising
  • CAI attains maximum before MAI
  • CAI falling, MAI rising
  • Intersection: CAI = MAI → MAI attend its maximum (Culmination)
    • MAI curve becomes flat → rotation of maximum volume production
  • Both CAI and MAI fall, CAI falls more rapidly
  • CAI = 0 when plant dies or is harvested

Increment percentage

  • increment expressed in percentage over a specific period of time
  • Pressler’s formula : base - average of quantity at the beginning and end of period.
  • CAI %=gain in current yearinitial value×100%\text{CAI \%} = \frac{\text{gain in current year}}{\text{initial value}}\times 100\%CAI %=initial valuegain in current year​×100%﻿
  • PAI %=gain in periodinitial value×100%\text{PAI \%} = \frac{\text{gain in period}}{\text{initial value}}\times 100\%PAI %=initial valuegain in period​×100%﻿
  • MAI %=MAIvolume×100%\text{MAI \%} = \frac{\text{MAI}}{\text{volume}}\times 100\%MAI %=volumeMAI​×100%﻿
  • Quality increment percentage
  • Price increment percentage - similar to quality increment percentage

Factors affecting increment

  • Site quality
  • Locality
  • Species - growth pattern, suitability to local factors, genetic makeup
  • crop nature
    • even , uneven
    • plantation or natural (natural - equilibrium - no change in growing stock - net increment 0)
  • Silvicultural treatment
    • Heavy thinning - decreases both CAI and MAI

Impact of thinning on volume increment

  • Enhanced crown projection by 80% in Pine, Spruce
  • Increases DBH and height in younger stands
  • Thinning from below → decreased canopy stratification
  • Thinning from above → maintains or increases canopy stratification
  • Quality and quantity per tree increases
    • more light, spacing → more crown volume
    • graph
  • reduces biomass, carbon storage

Increment estimation

  • Felled tree - stem analysis
    1. measure height, diameter at various heights → volume
    1. count annual rings
    1. prepare age-height or age-diameter curve to calculate increment
  • Standing tree

    Yield table

    diameter, height, age → increment for different ages

    regular forest →

    Irregular forest

    MAI=Total volumeAge\text{MAI}=\frac{\text{Total volume}}{\text{Age}}MAI=AgeTotal volume​﻿

Growing stock
  • Sum (number or volume) of total trees in a forest.
  • Relative concept
    • Timber production – include only above certain DBH
    • Carbon sequestration - include all biomass

Importance

Help in estimating

  • Species composition
  • Site productivity
  • Value of existing trees
  • Impact of climate change
  • Carbon sequestration capacity
  • Impact of silviculture operations

Estimation of growing stock

Actual growing stock

  • By enumeration
  • By sampling

Normal growing stock

  • by MAI
  • by Yield Table

Forest classification based on growing stock

Estimation of normal growing stock by MAI

  • Consider 10 acre eucalyptus plantation – 10 year rotation.
  • By year 10, we get 10 age gradations.
  • Calculate MAI
    • Let's say volume of 10 year-old felling = 500 m3\pu{500 m3}500 m3﻿
    • 10 year of increment = 10i=500 m310i = \pu{500 m3}10i=500 m3﻿
    • i=50 m3i=\pu{50 m3}i=50 m3﻿

  • Calculate normal growing stock
    • At the start of growing season
    • End of growing season

Estimation of NGS with yield table

Yield table gives 2 type of data

  • Data collection in one year interval → add volume of all successive years → get NGS
  • Data collection in 5 or 10 year interval → plot data on graph paper → draw a curve → calculate area below the curve

Age class and age gradation

Interval into which range of tree is divided for classification

  • Age class distribution — Proportional representation of different age classes

Normal series of age class distribution

Having complete series of age class, in such proportion that it allows equal volume of felling (annual or periodic)

  • Age gradation — Age class with one year as interval
  • Normal series of age gradation — Having complete series of age gradation from seedling to rotation age in such proportion that it allows equal volume of felling

Importance of these five concepts in forest management

  • Tell about composition structure distribution
  • Estimating effect of silvicultural treatment
  • Understanding growth behavior, regeneration issues, etc.
  • Understanding interaction of vegetation with site factors
  • Carbon sequestration capacity
  • Calculating growing stock
Normal forest

A forest that has - ideal growing stock, ideal age class distribution, ideal increment → where produce removal (annual or periodic) is equal to increment → without compromising future yield or site quality

Attributes of normality

  • Normal growing stock
  • Normal age class distribution
  • normal increment

Normal Increment — Best or maximum increments attainable by a given species per unit area at a given site

Normal growing stock — Volume of stand with normal age classes, and normal increment

Types of abnormality

  • Growing stock becomes overstocked or understocked due to excessive age classes or reduction in rotation
  • Abnormal distribution of age classes
  • Abnormal increment due to disease, fire, etc.
  • Normal increment in abnormal forest

Stand structure and dynamics
  • Stand: Group of trees that are relatively homogeneous in composition, age class distribution, structure growing on a site of uniform quality

Types

based on composition

  • pure stand - one species > 80%
  • mixed stand

Based on stand structure (or form)

  • even aged
  • two-aged
  • uneven aged

based on stand density

Stand dynamics

Study of changes in forest structure and composition, including its behave after some disturbance.

Five general types of age class structure within stand

Even-aged

  • Height uniform
  • Diameter not uniform - bell shaped

Two aged stand

Balanced uneven-aged stand

Irregular uneven aged stand

Even aged stratified mixture stand

  • Diagram
  • Graph

Factors affecting stand structure

  • Forest fire
  • Strong wind - windthrow
  • landslide and avalanche - remove all sown seed
  • herbivory by animals
  • flood
  • insect-pest attack
  • harvesting, logging

Stand development stages

First stage - stand initiation stage

  • After major disturbance
  • Herbaceous plant and fast growing shade intolerant
  • Fast growing shade intolerant dominant
  • High biodiversity

Second stage - young stage

  • Clown closes - heavily shaded phase begins
  • Competition for light space → many species start dying
  • New species cannot invade
  • Low biodiversity

Mature stage

  • Overstorey grows older → gaps appear in crown → some illumination at surface → opportunity for new species to invade
  • Biodiversity slightly increases

Old growth stage

  • Stand grows older → old trees begin to die → under-storey, whose growth was inhibited now begins to grow → stand becomes stratified
  • Biodiversity further slightly increases

Importance of stand dynamics

  • Understanding forest response to disturbance
  • Preparing growth model – predicting yield
  • Improving stand composition
  • Quantification of silvicultural operations and yield experiments
  • Management of complex forest ecosystem
  • Development of multi-aged forest

Stand density

Stand density

  • Number of trees per unit area of a species
  • Describes degree of crowding of stand
  • used to predict growth and yield
  • Stocking – relative concept – compare stand density of a site to ideal conditions

Canopy density

Canopy bulk density

Measures how closely canopy are packed – reflects likelihood of spread of forest fire in canopy

Impact of stand density or other factors

  • Add stand density decreases, spacing increases
    • Diameter, live crown ratio, survival percent increases
    • Basal area and relative density reduces
  • High stand density - smaller crown, smaller branch, straight bole, no knots in bole
  • High stand density in early stages - more deaths

Graph

Diagram – circle circular experiment design

Forest cover monitoring

All forest land > 1 ha with canopy density > 10% regardless of land ownership, use and legal status.

Method for for cover monitoring

Traditional

  • Intensive use of manual data collection
  • Limited use of airborne remote sensing by balloon or Dakota aircraft
  • Issues
    • Too much manpower needed
    • time and cost consuming
    • Areal remote sensing – data recorded in black-and-white spectrum – cannot identify invasive species, cannot detect stress on ecosystem

Modern

  • Drone
  • Satellite
    • Resroucesat-II - 1:50,0001:50,0001:50,000﻿ map scale (medium resolution), canopy density
  • LIDAR - canopy height
  • Limitations
    • Resourcesat-II resolution Limited to 1:50,000
    • Cloud cover
    • Haze and atmospheric deterioration
    • agricultural crops like cotton, sugarcane get mixed with tree cover data
    • Young plantation with best chlorophyll – satellite doesn't capture it
    • Forest boundary not available – satellite fails to delineate it

Forest classification based on canopy cover

densityCategory
>70% very dense
40-70%moderate
10-40%open
<10%scrub

total forest cover → 21.71% of geographic area (ISFR, 2021)

Forests survey of India (FSI)

Mandate

  • Forest cover mapping
  • Decision support system
  • forest fire monitoring and alerting
  • E green watch - integrated information system - afforestation, CAMPA activities
  • Indian state of forest report (biennial)
  • forest inventory
  • spatial database → collect, compile, store and disseminate information
  • training of forest personnel in technology usage
  • aid state in forest resource mapping

Forest fire monitoring

36% of India’s forest cover prone to forest fire

National Action Plan on forest fire 2018

  • Reduce incidence
  • Reduce forest vulnerability
  • Empower fringe community
  • Enhance institutional capacity

Forest fire alarm system (FAST) 3.0

Satellite based instrument

  • MODIS - 1km x 1km resolution
  • SNPP-VIIRS - 375m x 375m resolution

→ NASA-ISRO collaboration

  • Processed by NASA algorithm
  • Data transmitted to FSI
  • Van Agni portal senses alert
    • SMS to registered users
    • Email to nodal officers
  • Nodal officers act on forest fire
Forest management planning
  • What are the classical methods for determining the allowable cut?
  • What are the recommended practices for strategic harvest planning?
  • How yield is regulated? Describe the von Mantel’s formula for yield regulation in forests.
  • What is the yield regulation in forest management? How can yield regulation by Judeich method be used?

Yield regulation in regular forest

Determination of yield and its expression in a management plant prescription, including where, when, how the yield should be extracted.

  • Yield Capacity: Total quantity of material per annum of a given species that an area is capable of producing under normal conditions with locality factors unchanged
  • Yield determination: Calculation of amount of material that may be removed annually or periodically
  • Yield: Volume or number of stem that can be removed annually or periodically
  • Final yield: All the material that yield by the main felling in a regular forest.
  • Intermediate yield: All the material that yield before main felling is done.
  • Total yield: Intermediate + final yield

Basis of yield regulation

Area

  • Annual coups by gross area (i.e. equi-extensive area)
    • Divide entire plot into sub-parts of equal area size
  • Annual coups by reduced area (i.e. equi-productive area)
    • Divide entire plot into sub-parts with equal productivity.
  • Volume of growing stock
    • Von Mantel formula
    • Smythies modification
    • Howard modification
    • Simmon modification
    • Burma modification
  • Area and volume
    • Permanent periodic block
    • Revocable periodic block
    • Single periodic block
    • Floating periodic block
    • Judeich’s stand selection
  • Increment
    • Increment method
    • Swiss method
    • Briolly’s check method / French method (Methode du controle)

Based on area - yield regulation in clear felling system

Area is divided into small parts - equal size or equal productive

Advantage

  • Easy
  • Get absolute age gradation

Disadvantage

  • Very rigid - cannot modify in the middle of rotation in case of failure, coupe destruction
  • Doesn't consider crop condition during the felling
  • Cannot be used in - natural forest, mixed forest, hilly areas
  • How is yield regulated in a forest which is worked under clear felling system?
  • What is progressive yield? How is an annual yield obtained in a forest worked with periodic block method?
  • Describe the procedure for allotting different types of periodic blocks in a forest.
  • Write short notes on — permanent and floating periodic blocks.
  • How is the regulated by periodic block method?
  • Why the modification is necessary to the von Montel formula? name these modifications.
  • Describe the Austrian assessment method of yield regulation in regular forest.
  • Explain the French method of yield regulation in irregular forest. What are its advantages and disadvantages?

Yield regulation in shelterwood

Based on area and volume – periodic block

Permanent periodic block

  • Divide entire area, i.e. compartment into number of periodic blocks
  • Each block has equal area
  • Periodic block cannot be changed even in case of fire, damage, etc.

Revocable periodic block

  • Compartment is divided into number of periodic blocks after considering factors like condition and locality of drop.
    • e.g. If PB2 is destroyed in fire, we replace it and name it PB1.
    • If PB1 one shows excellent growth, we name it as PB2.
  • Under circumstances of frost, fire, pest attack, regeneration failure – the fixing area of periodic block can cause problem in yield regulation

Single periodic block allotment

  • Only allocate area for regeneration as periodic block.
  • Do not allocate area for other periodic blocks.

Floating periodic block allotment

  • Neither area nor period is fixed.
  • All area where regeneration is happening is considered as regeneration periodic block. We will stick with this periodic block until full regeneration happens.
  • How annual yield is obtained in forest with periodic block?
  • Describe procedure to allocate area for different type of periodic blocks in a forest.

Judeich’s stand selection

  • Goal: fixed annual yield
  • In Germany
  • Principal: treatment of each crop as per its requirement.
  • We carefully select the mature stands and allotment of proportional area of such stand to be felled and regenerated during working plan period.

Based on volume

Von Mantel’s formula

  • NGSNGSNGS﻿: Net Growing Stock → actual volume standing in that area
  • rrr﻿: rotation period of crop
  • III﻿: mean annual increment (MAI) = Yield

Howard’s modification

It doesn't count trees in first half of rotation age.

Von Mantel →

YYY﻿: Yield

VVV﻿: Enumerated volume

Burma Modification

  • Does not innumerate in first r3\frac{r}{3}3r​﻿ of age.

Simmon’s modification

Enumerator decides upward fraction of rotation age or diameter class to consider.

aaa﻿: Not enumerated volume

xxx﻿: Age upto which counted

Based on increment

Austrian assessment method

III﻿: increment

YYY﻿: annual yield

VaV_aVa​﻿: Actual volume

VnV_nVn​﻿: Normal Volume

rrr﻿: period for which difference between normal and actual is adjusted.

  • Applies to both regular and irregular forest
  • Doesn't consider age class distribution

Based on diameter class

French method / Quartier Blue Method

  • For irregular forest

Procedure

  • Find exploitable diameter
  • Find corresponding rotation by stem analysis
  • Divide stock in three class of diameter-age

    Old; medium; young

    YYY﻿: Annual Yield

    VoV_oVo​﻿: volume of old class

    t1t_1t1​﻿: increment per unit volume per year of old class

    rrr﻿: rotation period

Forest Management

Objective and principles; techniques; stand structure and dynamics, sustained yield relation;

rotation, normal forest, growing stock; regulation of yield; management of forest plantations,

commercial forests, forest cover monitoring. Approaches viz., (i) site-specific planning, (ii)

strategic planning, (iii) Approval, sanction and expenditure, (iv) Monitoring (v) Reporting and

governance. Details of steps involved such as formation of Village Forest Committees, Joint

Forest Participatory Management.

Working plan

A written scheme of management → aiming at continuity of policy and action → besides control treatment of forest

Need

  • Systematic planning
  • Long rotation of trees
  • socio-economic development of tribal
  • DFO are transferred in 2–3 years
  • Forest facing biotic pressure
  • CAMPA, REDD+

(as per working plan code 2014)

  • Make national forest policy more effective
  • Orderly development of forest within policy
  • making aims clear and realistic to achieve
  • make staff aware of intended future development

Objective

  • Provide guidelines and standards
  • Framework for sustainable management
  • Make forestry
    • environmentally responsible
    • Socially beneficial
    • Economically viable

Scope

  • Preparing micro plan for JFM
  • For forest certification
  • Sustainable forest management
  • Mitigating climate change impact
  • Basis for EIA, SIA
  • Poverty elevation of forest community

Features

  • Simple and brief
  • Based on thorough knowledge
  • Realistic aim
  • Minimized discretion of executive
  • Recognizing practical difficulties
  • Has past work reference
  • Gives preference to indigenous or exotic

  • Working plan period
    • Earlier 10 or 15 years
    • National working plan code 2014 : 10 years only
  • Working scheme — For private forest
  • Annual plan — 10 year working plan will have yearly targets → annual plan

Preparation of working plan

Preliminary working plan report (PWPR)

  • Conservator of forest (territorial) → asks DFO to prepare preliminary notes 2.5 years before current plan expires
    • DFO → notes review current system, and suggest changes → submit notes to CF(T) within two months
  • CF(T)
    • Inspect forest
    • Consult local stakeholders – JFM committee, village panchayat, forest development agency
  • CF(T) prepare PWPR
  • Submit to CCF/APCCF

Approve of PWPR by standing consultative committee (SCC)

  • Draft PWPR is discussed and amended by SCC
  • PCCF heads SCC
  • approval must come two years before existing working plan expires

Draft working plan by WPO

  • SCC direct WPO to prepare draft working plan based on approved PWPR
    • WPO should be assisted by 2 ACF + 4 RFO + 12 Forester
    • Draft WP must include
      • Past management systems
      • Forest inventory assessment
      • Stats of growth
      • No extra reference - self-contained
  • CCF/APCCF (WP) → scrutinize plan
  • RAPCCF (MoEFCC) → must get a copy minimum 45 days before final meeting of SCC

Approval of plan

  • By RAPCCF(MoEFCC)
    • Within three months
    • With necessary suggestion, direction, modification

Printing of plan

  • Uploading on website of state forest department

Amendments

  • Required approval of RAPCCF(MoEFCC)
  • Example- change in silvicultural system, new felling series, etc.

Compartment description

Compartment description

As per national working plan code 2014 -

  • Identification - division, range, block, compartment
  • Area
  • Location
  • Boundaries
  • Altitude
  • Slope
  • Topography
  • Rock
  • Soil
  • Crop composition
  • Crop density
  • Growing stock
  • Signature - working plan officer

Implementation of working plan

Working scheme

  • For forest outside government control - e.g. private forest, municipal, village, Autonomous District Council of Northeast
  • It provide implementation of
    • Various forest acts
    • PESA, FRA (2006), biodiversity act (2002)
    • Meeting goals of
      • Forest policy
      • International conventions and agreements

Annual plan of operations

  • Short term plan, within range of working plan
  • Tabular statement showing order and extent of all work to be carried within that year.
  • DFO approve it, based on workload, staff strength, industrial supply commitment

Importance of working plan

Role in forest conservation

  • Information on past management practices
  • Information on degraded land
  • Information on regeneration status
  • Information on → site quality, soil, geography
  • Prescribes management practices
  • Information on forest composition
  • Information on local people and demands

Tool for forest management

  • Result of past work
  • Assessing forest potential
  • Aim of sustained yield
  • Data of locality, wildlife, forest composition
  • Evaluating alternate use
  • Act as reference manual

Tool for wildlife conservation/biodiversity conservation

  • Calculate carrying capacity
  • Protection and enrichment of wildlife dwelling area of forest
  • Calculate site quality
  • Manage availability of food, predator, etc.

Working plan versus management plan

Management plan

  • For national Park, wild life sanctuary, tiger reserve, etc.
  • To conserve wild life
  • To improve habitat

A model working plan

Part I

Chapter 1: area under working plan

  • Boundary, description, legal status, etc.

Chapter 2: locality factors

Chapter 3: forest resources

  • Crop composition, natural regeneration, etc.

Chapter 4: utilization of forest produce

  • Export, market, prices, NTFP, etc.

Chapter 5: staff and labour

Chapter 6: result of previous management

Chapter 7: growth and yield statistics

Part II (future)

chapter 1: discussion of working circles

  • General objectives
  • Method of treatment

Chapter 2: working circle

  • Formation
  • Duration

Chapter 3: working plan for block forest working circle

Chapter 4: working plan for road working circle

Chapter 5: working plan for canal working circle

Chapter 6: working plan for rail working circle

Working plan code 2023

Need

  • Separate working plan wing - headed by additional PCCF → organization has been restructured
  • Areas added → eco-sensitive zone + CRZ
  • Extension of working plan → 10 + 2 + 3 years
  • Data collection - “national forest inventory methodology”

Changes

  • Additional PCCF (head of working plan)
  • CF(T) asks DFO for notes 28 months ago → earlier it was 2.5 years
  • CF(T) has to report to additional PCCF within three months
  • Additional PCCF send this to SCC headed by PCCF

New national Forest inventory (NFI) design

  • Used by FSI for inventory survey
  • Country is divided into 5x5 km grid
  • Revisit time → five years
  • Importance
    • sync with grid
    • Fixed revisit time
    • increased the sample size

2. Forest Working Plan :

Forest planning, evaluation and monitoring tools and approaches for integrated planning;

multipurpose development of forest resources and forest industries development; working

plans and working schemes, their role in nature conservation, bio-diversity and other

dimensions; preparation and control. Divisional Working Plans, Annual Plan of Operations.

Forest mensuration

Branch of forestry → determination of - dimension (diameter, height, volume), form, age, increment - of a single tree / stand / whole forest - standing or after felling

  • Forest biometry : bio - living thing, metry - measurement
  • Objectives
    • Basis for sale
    • research
    • carbon trading
    • forest certification
    • planning future needs

Diameter and girth measurement

Breast height

  • at 1.37 m=4 ft 6 in\pu{1.37m}=\pu{4 ft 6 in}1.37 m=4 ft6in﻿
  • DBH - Diameter at breast height
  • GBH - Girth at breast height (circumference)

Why breast height is used

  • Cannot take base / root for measurement
    • Covered with grass shrub thorn
    • root swelling, buttressing
  • uniform point of measurement
  • convenient → avoids unnecessary fatigue

Rules

  • Mark cross “+” at breast height.
  • measure diameter/girth perpendicular to longitudinal axis of stem
  • remove creepers, lichens, loose bark before measurement
  • Diameter measurement - in cm, two decimals
  • Girth measurement - in m, one decimal

leaning tree - measured along leaning side

sloping ground - measure along sloping side

bulge at BH - measure either up or slightly down

buttress at BH - take BH at lowest point where there is no buttressing

tree is forked below BH - consider each fork as individual tree

tree is forked above BH - consider whole tree as one

Tools of measurement

DBH

Wooden scale

  • cm, mm marking
  • 60 cm & 30 cm - divided in 2 arms
  • measures
    • stem diameter
    • stump diameter

Caliper

Precautions with caliper

  • well-opened caliper, arm should be movable - not forced on the tree
  • if stem is elliptical - measure 2 diameter
  • Movable arms should be perpendicular to ruler.
  • Both arms should touch stem
  • caliper should be at right angle to tree axis
  • Take the reading before removing caliper

Tape

  • band of cloth, plastic or metal
  • 1.5 m\pu{1.5m}1.5 m﻿ wide, length 10m, 20m, 50m, etc.
  • Reading in cm, mm, and inch on other side

precautions

  • not twisted
  • not old and damaged
  • be perpendicular to axis of tree

Advantage

  • easy to carry
  • easy to use
  • one reading is enough

Issues

  • tape elasticity
  • rough bark of tress - exaggerated girth or diameter

Significance of tape, caliper

  • To measure both, girth, and diameter
  • For elliptical stem - caliper give us more accurate basal area
  • girth Calculation - caliper gives more accurate
  • felled tree - easier to use tape
  • caliper - both +ve and -ve error → neutralise → less error
  • tape - only +ve error → accumulate

Baltimore stick

  • To get quick rough idea of diameter
  • 60-90 cm of long stick is held perpendicular to tree stem
  • Operator is 25 inch away from tree
  • Operator aligns zero mark at A

Upper stem diameter

Ruler

A simple board

  • l=150 cml=\pu{150cm}l=150 cm﻿
  • b=10 cmb=\pu{10cm}b=10 cm﻿
  • 1 m\pu{1m}1 m﻿ rod attached at middle
  • a detachable 8 m\pu{8m}8 m﻿ rod can be added to 1 m\pu{1m}1 m﻿ rod
  • Measurement

    can measure diameter at 5-6m of stem height

Finnish Parabolic caliper

  • parabolic arm has reading scale
  • measure diameter at 8-12 m stem height

Dendrometers

  • optical device to measure cross section at greater height
  • types
    • Kramer’s
    • Electric

Relaskops

Spiegel relaskop

  • an optical device to calculate - upper stem diameter, basal area, tree height, horizontal distance, basal area factor, slope angle

Procedure - look through hole in instrument

Wheeler’s Pentaprism

  • optical device - has 2 pentaprism - maintains parallelism in line of sight
    • left prism is fixed
    • right prism is movable
  • no need to measure baseline distance from tree

Height measurement

midpoint - mid point between crown point and lowest green branch

Methods to measure height

  • ocular method
  • non-instrumental
    • shadow
    • single pole
    • pencil
  • instrumental
    • based on geometric triangle similarity
      • Christen hypsometer
      • Smythies hypsometer
      • Improvised caliper
    • based on trigonometry
      • Brandi’s hypsometer
      • Abney level
      • Spiegel relaskop
      • Suunto clinometer
      • Electric clinometer

Shadow method

Single pole method

  • Observer holds 1.5m long pole vertically such that length of pole above hand = distance of pole from the observer’s eye

move forward and backward till line of sight to the tip of tree passes through tip of pole

Pencil or stick rotation method

  • Observer holds scale in his hands, in front of eyes such that tip of scale coincides with top of tree
  • tilt scale 90° to horizontal
  • ask a staff to go in other direction till he reaches tip of scale

Issues with the three methods

  • Tree must be vertical
  • Ground must be flat
  • Applied only on clear sunny day
  • Cannot do between 11 AM - 2 PM because of too long shadow
  • Difficult to do in fully stocked forest or densely packed Forest

Christen Hypsometer

  • strip of metal / wood
  • l=33 cm,w=2.5 cml=\pu{33cm}, w=\pu{2.5cm}l=33 cm,w=2.5 cm﻿
  • Each end has hole to allow it to suspend in air
  • helper → hold a 4 m staff parallel to the trunk of tree
  • Observer → hold the instrument vertical in air, adjust it with the tree by moves slowly forward and backward till the line of sight to the tip of the tree and base of the tree passes through the scale.
  • Advantage
    • Lightweight
    • Direct reading
    • Quicker

  • Disadvantages
    • After 30 m reading, division on scale are to close
    • Hypsometer - vertical but - shaking of hand, fatigue, swinging by wind
    • Based on assumption that tree is vertical
    • Two people are needed

Smythies Hypsometer

  • Advantages
    • Easy to construct and carry
    • Avoid measurement of horizontal distance
    • Can read heights up to 30 m
  • Disadvantages
    • Rain can wash chart paper
    • Wind can disturb plumb line

Improvised caliper

  • caliper with scale marking on the movable arm and a plumb-bob mounted at the edge of the fixed arm.
  • Fixed scale aligns with the tree tip
  • Movable scale aligns with the bottom
  • ∠CAB=∠CLM=∠LMN\angle{CAB}=\angle{CLM}=\angle{LMN}∠CAB=∠CLM=∠LMN﻿

Instrument based on trigonometry principles

  • used in past
    • Brandis hypsometer
    • Abney’s level
  • Presently used
    • Haga altimeter
    • Blume-leiss hypsometer
    • Tele-Relaskop
    • Spiegel Relaskop
    • Barr & Stroud dendrometer
  • Modern tools - replacing present ones
    • Suunto clinometer
    • Electric clinometer

Brandis hypsometer

  • Method
    • Point metal tube to top of three
    • Find degree reading on the wheel
    • use Brandi’s table → height of tree
  • Advantages
    • Easy to use - table gives height directly
    • Up to 60° above and below
  • Disadvantages
    • Change in observer position shakes wheel
    • Only 60° limit

Abney level

Slight modification of Brandi’s

Advantage

  • Up to 90° up or down
  • Can take despite shifting observer position

Disadvantage

  • Skill
  • shaking of hand

Use

  • Tree height
  • Contour survey
  • Road alignment

Suunto clinometer

  • Hold it at your eyes, like camera
  • Point at tree top, look at crosshair reading

Case studies

β\betaβ﻿: angle with root of tree

EBEBEB﻿: ground distance

Stem form

  • Tapering — rate of decrease in diameter of tree
  • Stem form — shape of stem

Shapes

yyy﻿: radius of cross section

xxx﻿: distance from apex

bbb﻿: shape

kkk﻿: rate of tapering

Shapebbb﻿yyy﻿
Cylinder0y=ky=ky=k﻿
Paraboloid1y=kxy=k\sqrt{x}y=kx​﻿
Conical2y=kxy=kxy=kx﻿
Neiloid3y=kx3y=k\sqrt{x^3}y=kx3​﻿

Hojer’s formula

lll﻿: distance from apex

ddd﻿: diameter at lll﻿

C,c′C,c'C,c′﻿: shape specific constants

Behre’s formula

Direct measurement of diameter at different heights

Need to study stem form

  • Estimate tree volume
  • Understand tree growth behaviour
  • Estimate site quality

Why trees have different stem form?

Rejected theories

  1. Nutritional theory
    • lower part of stem gets more food from root
    • so becomes wider - Neiloid shape
  1. Water conductive theory
    • lower part gets more water from root
  1. Hormonal theory
    • growth regulators play role

Mechanical (or Metzger or Beam or Girder) Theory

  • verified on conifer
  • stem: cantilever beam of uniform resistance against bending force of the wind
  • Wind pressure exerts strain that increases towards base
  • To counter this, the tree reinforces the base. Crown has less stress – less growth material – taper
  • Trees in isolation – larger crown → subjected to most lateral wind pressure → wider base short height. Dense condition → long and nearly cylindrical boles.

Significance

  • Explains: trees growing in isolation or hilltop grow slowly and show high taper; whereas trees in intense plantings are tall, cylindrical and show excellent growth.
  • Shows relationship between stemmed diameter and tree height d3=b0+b1hd^3=b_0+b_1hd3=b0​+b1​h﻿
  • Trunks are adapted to resistance to lateral force, but roots are embedded in weak material → weak trees, rupture, snap or uproot at the base during storm

Methods for studying stem forms

Comparing form ratio’s - form factor, form height, form quotient

Form factor

Ratio of volume of tree or its part to the volume of cylinder, having same length and cross-section as the tree

SSS﻿: basal area at breast height

Artificial form factor, or breast height form factor

  • basal area at breast height is considered
  • Height: both above and below breast height

Importance of form factor

  • Estimate volume of standing tree
  • Understand competition
  • Site quality

Pressler’s normal or true form factor

  • basal area is calculated at specific proportion of total height - 110th\frac{1}{10}^\text{th}101​th﻿, 120th\frac{1}{20}^\text{th}201​th﻿,130th\frac{1}{30}^\text{th}301​th﻿
  • whole height

Absolute form factor

  • basal area: at a convenient point
  • Height: above the point

Form height

Product of form factor, and the total height of the tree

Form quotient

Ratio between mid diameter and the DBH

classifying the stem forms on the basis of form class, form ratios

  • Form class — Intervals in which range of form quotients of trees is divided for classification
  • Form point — Point in the crown at which the wind pressure is estimated to be cantered.
  • Form point ratio

Compilation of taper tables

  • Taper table — Tabular arrangement of information about the diameter of the bole at fixed distances from the base of tree.
  • Utility
    • Tells diameter of bole at fixed height
    • Comparing stem profile of different species
    • Volume estimation
  • Types

    Ordinary TT

    Give taper directly for DBH without relating to tree form

    Form class TT

    For various form classes and DBH

  • Method of construction
    • Select representative tree
    • Fell
    • Measure height, dbh, stem diameter at 5%, 10%… 95% of tree height
    • Find regression equation
      • target variable : d%d\%d%﻿
      • predictor: d10%d_{10}\%d10​%﻿
    • Prepare taper table based on this data
Volume measurement

Volume of felled tree

Smalian’s formula

paraboloid shape

only end diameters needed

Huber’s formula

paraboloid shape

difficult to measure SmS_mSm​﻿ in stock condition

Newton’s formula or Prismoidal formula

Neiloid, conical, paraboloidal, cylindrical

most accurate method

Small end diameter

cylinder

only one diameters needed

Quarter girth formula

ggg﻿: girth at overbark

  • Gives volume 21.5% less than actual volume, but this much volume of wood is anyway lost in conversion process.
  • Thus, this formula use meaningful volume.

volume of standing tree

Ocular estimation - based on experience

  • Direct methods

Standard section method

  • Divide stem into various sections
  • Measure volume of each section individually
  • Applicable to all types of trees

Gray’s taperline method

  • Pick 5–7 representative points on tree
  • Plot height versus sectional area on graph
  • Area under graph shows volume
    • Top crown and butt swell volume excluded → merchantable volume

Graphical method

  • Similar to taperline
  • h1,h2,h3h_1,h_2,h_3h1​,h2​,h3​﻿ etc are fixed at short interval → 1m, 2m et
  • Indirect method
    • Non-instrumental
      • Volume table → use height, diameter for given species
      • Volume equation → e.g. V=a1+a2d2hV=a_1+a_2d^2hV=a1​+a2​d2h﻿
    • Instrumental
      • Spiegel relaskop
      • Wheeler’s pentaprism
      • → Major upper stem diameter → volume

Volume of stacked wood

Billet

Unit for wood stack in India

Dimension: 12 ft x 3 ft (height) x 5 ft

Xylometric method

  • Immerse wood logs into water tube
  • Volume of water displaced by logs tells volume of wood

Specific gravity method

  • Calculate specific gravity of wood
  • Find weight of wood
  • V=WρgV=\frac{W}{\rho g}V=ρgW​﻿

Photographic method

  • Take photo of woodstack
  • Camera pixels under wood is used to find volume

Volume table

A table showing average volume of tree log for given species based on DBH, height, tapering

Information available

  • Volume based on diameter and height
  • Method for volume computation
  • Species name, locality, distribution
  • Table for
    • Bark %
    • Diameter growth table
    • Commercial volume table

Preparation

Graphical method

Select species → take measurement → arrange data in tabular format → draw graph → prepare volume table

Regression method

Select species → take measurement → established the relationship between volume, height, diameter via regression analysis

e.g. Tectona grandis (Teak) V=−0.0645+0.2322D2HV=-0.0645+0.2322D^2HV=−0.0645+0.2322D2H﻿

Classification

  • Based on number of variables
    • Single variable
      • Diameter alone
      • Easy to prepare
      • Can be used locally only
      • Local volume table
    • Two variable
      • Diameter and height
      • General volume table
      • Applicable to very large area
      • Types
        • Commercial volume table
        • Standard volume table
        • Sawn outturn volume table
        • Assortment volume table
    • Three variable
      • Diameter height form class
      • Form class volume table
      • Most accurate
      • Tough to prepare
  • Scope of application
    • Local volume table
    • General volume table
    • Regional volume table
      • For a limited regional → less coverage than general volume table
  • Outturn result
    • Commercial volume table
      • Input
        • Diameter of thin end
        • length
      • Output
        • Volume
        • varies with industry
    • Standard volume table
      • Gives volume for standard size of timber - from ground to 20cm diameter over bark
    • Sawn outturn table
      • Sawn timber is timber cut from log into different shapes and sizes
      • This table shows volume of sawn timber

Weight and biomass

Forest biomass estimation

  • Direct method (for individual tree)
    • Destructor sampling
  • Indirect method (for stand)
    • Regression method
  • Modern method
    • Remote sensing
    • LiDAR

Destructive sampling

regression method

  • For single stem tree
  • Four multiple stem tree

NsN_sNs​﻿: Number of shoots

LiDAR

  • laser scanning
  • Users near infrared spectrum
  • 3-D point cloud data → information on tree structure and height
  • Issues - expensive

Microwave remote sensing

  • Deep penetration of tree canopy → detailed information on tree structure
  • An active sensor
    • No day night impact
    • No weather impact
  • Images earth surface from different polarization → better understanding of earth’s features

Age of tree

Method

  • For felled trees → counting annual rings
  • For standing trees
    • Existing record
    • Number of annual shoots
    • Taking three periodic measurement
    • General appearance
    • Pressler’s increment borer
    • Diameter – age curve
  • Challenges with tree ring
    • Rings are too closely formed
    • Sometimes delay in ring formation
    • More than one annual ring in a year
    • Some plants don't form annual rings

General appearance

  • Based on size, shape of crown, stem size, taper rate

Existing records

Counting number of annual shoots

  • Conifer produce annual shoots

Pressler’s increment borer

  • Bore is made
    • large tree → breast height
    • small tree → 30 cm above ground

Diameter age curve

  • Annually, measuring tree diameter, with age of hundreds of trees of same species
  • Using this data prepare diameter-age curve
  • In future, major diameter of any tree → refer this curve to know age

Taking three periodic measurements

(t1,d1),(t2,d2),(t2,d2)(t_1,d_1),(t_2,d_2),(t_2,d_2)(t1​,d1​),(t2​,d2​),(t2​,d2​)﻿

Growth per unit diameter in first period

Tree’s growth determination

  • Determining growth
    • Annual rings present
      • Stump analysis
      • Stem analysis
      • Increment boring
    • No annual rings
      • Periodic measurement

Increment and increment percentage

method to calculate increment percentage

Stump analysis

  • Stump analysis — Analysis of cross-section of stump - by measuring rings - to understand age, past growth rate, growth of basal area
  • Fieldwork
    • Select old and sound stumps
    • make surface smooth and clear so that annual rings look clear
    • measure data about
      • stump height
      • Diameter (OB)
      • Girth (OB)
      • Bark thickness
      • Annual ring - number and thickness
      • Fire scars
  • Tells us about
    • Age-diameter curve
    • Rotation age
    • Impact of forest fire, rot area, windshake damage
  • Limitations
    • Cannot prepare age – height curve
    • Cannot prepare age – volume relation
Stem analysis
  • Stem analysis

    Analysis of a complete stem - by measuring annual rings - on different cross sections - at different heights - to determine its part rate of growth.

  • Methodology
    • Select dominant/co-dominant tree of rotation size
    • Measure its DBH, height, crown length, crown width
    • fell
    • Break stem into sections
    • Measure for each section
      • Diameter (OB) at mid section
      • Diameter (UB) at mid section
      • Count annual rings at both ends
    • Prepare - data table, curve
  • Curve
  • Advantage
    • Data from entire tree
    • Information on diameter age length bio mass
    • Helps to prepare volume table
    • No skilled labor required
  • Disadvantage
    • Destructive sampling
    • need a lot of permissions for tree felling
    • Cost and labor required

Increment boring

By Pressler’s increment borer

  • Objective
    • To determine the age and diameter increment
    • Time required to reach exploitable diameter
  • Method
    • Boring of tree stem with Pressler’s borer
  • Advantage
    • Segment of stage is extracted to count tree rings
    • No need for tree felling
    • If tree doesn't show annual ring → get results by periodic measurement
  • Issues
    • Many Tropical trees, diffuse porous hardwood - have indistinguishable annual rings
    • Need to treat hole after core removal
      • Black hole
      • If possible, returned core to hole after studies
      • Otherwise, fingi infection in hole
  • How (stump analysis, stem analysis, increment borer) help determine forest health and pest growth?
    • Tells average time needed to reach particular diameter class
    • Determining exploitable age and rotation age
    • Comparing increment under different ages
    • Comparing diameter and crown classes
    • Understand external impact on diameter increment

Forest inventory/enumeration

Systemic collection, evaluation, presentation of specific information on forest area - sides and shape of area, quantity, and quality of growing stock, species composition

Objective

  • Long term planning for industry supply
  • taking forest management decision
  • Working plan like a map of growing stock, age class, basal area, etc.
  • Determine health and viability of forest ecosystem
  • Determine MAI, CAI
  • Assess environmental, socio-economical, intangible services provided by tree
  • Biological diversity of tree species, and wild animals
  • Estimate the impact of pollution on growth of trees

Enumeration methods

  • Total
  • Partial or sampling
    • Random sampling
      • Simple (unrestricted)
      • Stratified
      • Multi stage
      • Multi phase
    • Non-random sampling
      • Selective
      • Systematic
      • Sequential

Random sampling

  • All units have equal chance of being chosen

Simple (unrestricted) random sampling

  • An individual sample is chosen entirely by chance.

Stratified random sampling

  • Forest is divided into blocks of homogenous composition called strata
  • Sample chosen as per relative size of strata
  • For example if mountain makes 20% of a forest area → 20% quota to mountain

Multi stage random sampling

  • Forest area is divided into groups → few are selected randomly
  • Further subdivided into sub groups - and few are selected

Multi phase random sampling

  • Same sampling unit is used in multiple phases

Example - double phase sampling for bamboo forest inventory

  • First phase - find number of clumps per ha via large, systematic survey
  • Second phase - find number of culms, per clump via small enumeration survey

non random sampling

samples are chosen as per subjective judgment of observer on the basis of specific rules/guidelines, indicating what samples should be chosen

Selective sampling

based on subjective judgment of observer

Systematic sampling

Based on a predetermined pattern

Sequential sampling

  • Non-probabilistic
  • Researcher picks a single group of subjects in a given time interval

sample plot

Sample plot

A small piece of land chosen as representative of larger forest area

  • Objective
    • Surveying, enumeration
    • studying growth behave
    • Study Impact of silvicultural treatment
    • Estimate forest condition - health and biodiversity
    • Site quality
  • Types
    • on the basis of shape - strip, circular, rectangular, polygon, square
    • Based on time - temporary, permanent
    • based on size - small medium large

Preservation plot

Preservation plot

These are miniature nature resource to represent ecological model of different forest types

  • Objective
    • Ecological studies
    • Growth rate of species
    • Carbon sequestration studies
    • Succession pattern

Artificial intelligence for forest sampling

Software supports forest inventory

  • By digitising structure of forest mass
  • Qualifying renewable resources of forest

Methodology

Point cloud ( set of data points in space) → integrated by a software → generates algorithm for dendrometric variables

Benefit

  • know current state
  • Find possible future changes
  • Time saving in measurement
  • Greater control and monitoring

Survey and assessment of forest sources

  • This includes assessment of
    • Conservation of biodiversity
    • Enhancement of Forest health
    • Conservation of soil and water
    • Enhance forest productivity
    • Maintenance of social, economic, spiritual value → JFM, FRA, sacred groves
  • Growing stock estimation
  • NTFP estimation
  • Regeneration survey

Regeneration survey

It is part of field exercise that tells about

  • Status of natural regeneration
  • Preparation of stock map → so that correct silvicultural practice can be recommended
  • Basis for comparing regeneration at the end of working plan

When it is done

  • During revision of working plan

Methodology

  • Total enumeration is not possible so only 2–4% in enumeration is done
  • For plain area areas : done in strips
  • for mountains: done in topographic units

Regeneration categories

category value
Established regeneration5.00
Woody shoots, not established4.00
Woody shoots browsed4.00
Whippy unestablished seedling (height > 50cm)2.00
Whippy unestablished seedling (height < 50 cm)1.00
Sub-whippy unestablished seedling (height > 50 cm)0.50
Sub-whippy unestablished seedling (height > 50 cm)0.25
Current year seedling0.00
blank0.00
total volume of regeneration categoryDescription
81–100 excellent
61–80 good
41–60 moderate
21–40fair
0–20 deficient

Point sampling

Method of quickly estimating basal area per hector - directly by standing at a point - to selecting trees on the basis of their size rather than by the frequency of occurrence - using angle-gauge or wedge prism of known basal area factor (BAF)

Concept

  • Series of sampling points are chosen over selected forest area
  • Go to the point
  • View all trees 360° around the point at breast height, via wedge prism
  • Tree forming an angle bigger than critical angle of instrument are counted

Principal

The ratio of tree diameter: plot radius remains constant

Instruments used

  • Simple Angle Gauge

wedge prism

Basal Area Factor (BAF) of Prism =10001+4(LD)2m2/ha=\frac{1000}{1+4\left(\frac{L}{D}\right)^2}\pu{m2/ha}=1+4(DL​)21000​m2/ha﻿

Tally typevalue
full tally1
border tally0.5
no tally0

Uses

  • Calculate basal area per hectare = BAF x n (number of tally trees)

    F=basal area of treearea of circular plot=π(d2)2πR2=d24R2=K24×10,0000=2500K2F=\frac{\text{basal area of tree}}{\text{area of circular plot}}=\frac{\pi \left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^2}{\pi R^2}=\frac{d^2}{4R^2}=\frac{K^2}{4}\times 10,0000=2500K^2F=area of circular plotbasal area of tree​=πR2π(2d​)2​=4R2d2​=4K2​×10,0000=2500K2﻿

  • Calculate number of stems per hectare
  • Volume per hectare = basal area x stand form weight

Horizontal point sampling versus plot sampling

horizontal point sampling plot sampling
sample trees are selected proportional to their basal area all trees have the same chance of being selected
basal area obtained by just counting trees → no need for diameter measure need to measure diameter to find basal area
Quick survey time taking
skilled labor no skill
useful in hilly and difficult
difficult to do in dense tropical forest

Yield table

Table statement that summarises data on per unit area basis for fully stocked regularly thinned and even aged crop

Contents of the yield table

main crop

  • Average diameter
  • Average height
  • Total basal area
  • Number of trees
  • Standing volume

Thinning

  • volume stem timber
  • Total volume
  • Volume total small wood

Final Yield

  • volume stem timber
  • Total volume
  • Volume total small wood

Total Yield

  • volume stem timber
  • Total volume
  • Volume total small wood

Mean annual increment

  • Volume stem timber
  • Total volume

Current annual increment

  • Volume stem timber
  • Total volume

Other information

  • top height
  • spacement table
  • number of trees per unit area
  • normal growing stock
  • stand table

Types

  • Based on thinning grade numbers
    • Single yield table
      • Data for any one grade of thinning
    • Multiple yield table
      • data for different grades of thinning
  • based on given volume
    • volume YT
      • shows outturn in terms of volume
    • money YT
      • constructed from volume YT → outturn expressed in terms of money

Procedure to prepare yield table

  • construct top height - top age curve based on site quality
  • sample plots assigned as per quality class
  • cop age, basal area is separately grouped and average calculated
  • for each quality class, calculate -
    • basal area per ha
    • number of trees per ha
    • average crop diameter
    • average crop height
    • stem timber volume per ha
    • top age
  • average value of each age decade is read from curve
  • finally data is tabulated

Applications of yield table

  • to determine
    • site quality
    • total yield
    • growing stock
    • increment
    • rotation
  • prepare → stock map
  • guide silvicultural thinning
  • find - number of stems corresponding to age

Stand table

A table showing distribution of stem by diameter class for each series of crop diameter

  • 10 cm diameter class
  • Number of trees per Hector
  • Percentage of trees over given diameter limits

3. Forest Mensuration and Remote Sensing :

Methods of measuring - diameter, girth, height and volume of trees; form-factor; volume

estimation of stand, current annual increment; mean annual increment. Sampling methods

and sample plots. Yield calculation; yield and stand tables, forest cover monitoring through

remote

sensing; Geographic Information Systems for management and modelling.

Surveying

  • surveying — determining relative position between objects → horizontal distance
  • levelling — determining relative position between objects → vertical distance

Need, objectives, use in forestry

  • to prepare topographic map - showing hill, river, forest, village
  • to prepare cadastral map - boundaries of compartment, block
  • prepare plantation map, stock map
  • direction and distance between - office, plantation site, river
  • mapping of fire areas
  • detect encroachment

Classification

  • based on shape of earth (Primary classification)
    • plane surveying
      • for area <250 km2<\pu{250km2}<250 km2﻿
      • does not consider curvature of earth
    • geodesic surveying
      • area of survey >250 km2>\pu{250km2}>250 km2﻿
      • considers curvature of earth
  • nature of field survey
    • land surveying
    • marine surveying
    • astronomical surveying
  • instrument
    • chain surveying
    • compass surveying
    • plain table surveying
  • method
    • triangulation surveying - divide area into triangles of various size
    • traverse surveying - open and closed

topographic vs cadastral survey

topographic Surveycadastral survey (ownership)
process of contouring large area. Provide provides information for Topographic/ contour mapFor physical delineation of property boundaries, determined dimension → to create legal properties
Photographic featuresBoundaries of compartments, blocks
GradientCorridor boundary for - rail, road, transmission lines, canals, wildlife corridor
Alignment for road, contour, trenchIdentifies forest village, khasra
Site selection for plantationDigitation of forest land → FAST 3.0, GIS
Plant fire lines, irrigation channels, stocking map, enumeration, wildlife census

Linear measurement

Methods

  • ocular estimation
  • pacing, stepping
  • chaining
  • odometer - attached to wheel of vehicle
  • modern tools
    • RADAR
    • SONAR
    • LiDAR

Instruments needed

ranging rod

  • of bamboo
  • to straighten ranging line
  • to mark boundaries

  • tape
    • cloth / linen / metallic / steel tape

  • arrow

    a steel wire used to count number of chains

  • chain
    • metric chain
      • 20-30m long

      divided into 100 links

    • steel band - 20-30 m long
    • Gunter’s chain
      • 66 ft long, 100 links
    • Engineer’s chain
      • 100 ft long, 100 links
    • revenue chain
      • 33 ft long, 16 links

  • Ranging: process to establish intermediate points on a straight line bewteen two points

ranging types

  • direct
    • when both ends are visible
    • to establish intermediate points
      • surveyor remains at one end
      • assistant goes ahead with rod
      • assistant aligns himself roughly with chain line
      • surveyor tells him to move left/right so that all rods align
  • indirect
    • when both ends are not visible

Chain Survey

  • Chain survey : method of land survey using only linear instruments - chains, no angular measurements are recorder
  • When it can be done?
    • Ground surface is level
    • Area is small
    • Can easily form well-conditioned triangles - that is no angle less than 30° or more than 120°.
    • When constructing small scale map
  • Principle of triangulation
    • Area divided into small triangles
    • Offsets - lateral measurement from main chain line to locate reference object

Equipment used

  • Metric chain
  • Arrow
  • Ranging road
  • Offset
  • Wooden peg
  • Field book → field measurement
  • Cross staff
    • Instrument to set right angles
    • Open bar cross staff
      • 4 brass arms
      • At 90° to each other
      • Mounted on 1.5 m pole

Benefits

  • Simple method
  • No costly equipment needed
  • High accuracy
  • Simple computation
  • Few people needed
  • Equipment can be easily replaced

Factors to consider before initiating chain survey

  • Preliminary reconnaissance
    • Surveyors examine area
    • Determines possible location to establish main station
  • Index sketch
    • A Sketch drawing showing arrangement, area, position of wood peg, etc.
  • Marking stations on ground
  • chaining and offset
  • Field book recording
  • Plotting chain survey
  • Inking → pencil work + colours + conventional signs

Obstruction to chaining

  1. A forest area (or dense plantation) comes across chaining line - i.e. chaining is possible, but vision is obstructed
    • Problem: presence of forest, Hill, etc. → end stations are not visible.
    • Method: cross obstacle, using a “random line”
    • Representation
  1. River interrupt chain line - i.e. chaining is obstructed, but vision is free
    • AB is chain line
    • but river interrupts
    • Select point C, D on opposite ends of river
    • From C, draw a perpendicular line → CE
    • For CE, create a midpoint F
    • Create a perpendicular from E
      • Find a point G on this line so that D – F – G lie on the same line
    • △DCF≅△GEF  ⟹  CD=EG\triangle{DCF}\cong\triangle{GEF}\implies CD=EG△DCF≅△GEF⟹CD=EG﻿
    • Measure EG

Compass survey, Prismatic compass

  • Limits of chain survey - cannot be done if - area is large, uneven terrain, river or coastline is followed → here traversing is done
  • Compass survey — Surveying done when direction of lines is determined by compass and length is measured by tape or chain.
  • Principle of compass survey → traversing
  • Terms

True meridian

  • A.k.a. Geographical meridian.
  • A line passing through geographical North Pole, and geographical South Pole
  • True bearing - an angle any line makes with true meridian

Magnetic meridian

  • When a magnetic needle is suspended freely, it indicates direction of magnetic Meridian.
  • This is imaginary line connecting magnetic Northpole to magnetic South Pole.
  • Magnetic bearing - an angle any line makes with magnetic meridian

Magnetic declination

  • Horizontal angle between magnetic meridian and true meridian
  • isogonic line - line made by points of equal declination
  • agonic line - line made by points of zero declination

Magnetic inclination (dip of magnetic needle)

  • It is inclination of needle with horizontal
  • North end of needle defects downwards in north hemisphere

  • Local attraction

    If needle comes near some magnetic substance it defects from its true direction.

  • Whole Circle bearing
    • Magnetic bearing of a line measured clockwise from North Pole.
    • Readings: 0° –360°
    • Via prismatic compass
  • Quadrant bearing a.k.a. reduced bearing
    • Bearing of a line
      • Either clockwise or anti-clockwise
      • Either from North Pole or South Pole, whichever is nearer
      • Either east or west
    • Trading: 0° – 90° - in four quadrants NE, NW, SE, SW
    • Via surveyors compass
  • Fore bearing - bearing observed along forward direction i.e. direction of survey
  • Back bearing - bearing observed along reverse direction
  • Types of Compass

    prismatic compass

    • Consists of
      • A circular non-magnetic metallic box
      • A magnetized iron bar needle
      • Reading: 0° to 360° clockwise
      • Sight and prism

    Surveyor compass

    • Similar to prismatic, except
      • No prism → reading with naked eye
      • eye vane replace prism
      • Reading: 0° – 90° across four quadrants

  • Field Method of compass survey
    • Reconnaissance - survey walks and examines area
    • Index sketching - sketch of arrangements
    • Mark drivers station on ground - via wooden pegs
    • Start traveling
      • Open or close
      • Distance via a chain, angle via compass
      • Observation tabulated
      • Correction applied
    • Plot map
  • Advantages of compass survey
    • undulating hilly topography
    • Crowded areas
    • Course of river and coastal plane
    • Large area
    • Area areas that cannot be divided into triangles - e.g. dense forest
  • Limitation
    • Unsuitable for magnetic area
    • Local attraction by pipes, bridges, etc.
    • Less accurate than chain survey
  • Use in forestry
    • Locating position of boundary pillars of forest land
    • Detecting encroachment
    • Find position of in accessible areas - e.g. animal habitat
    • Laying out forest coupe, beat, compartment
    • Chain survey, not possible in dense forest, hilly slopes

Plane table survey

  • Graphical method of surveying
    • Field observation and plotting done simultaneously
    • No use of field book
    • Suitable to fill interior detail details when traversing is done by Theodolite
  • Principal - parallelism: The rays drawn station to objects on the paper are parallel to the lines from the stations to objects on the ground.
  • Accessories

    Plane table

    Wooden drawing table

    75 cm x 60 cm

    Alidade (telescope)

    Telescope for inclined sight

    Trough compass

    To fix direction of table

    U-fork with plumb bob

    For centring in the table

  • Procedure

    Reconnaissance → index sketching → fix table on tripod → table levelling → table cantering → marking north line → chaining → plotting details

Scope and advantage

  • For survey of broken, uneven & undulating area
  • Survey of open area
  • When speed is more important than precision, e.g. preliminary survey
  • Fair accuracy for small scale plans
  • Most rapid method
  • No need for field book
  • plotted work can be compared with actual objects
  • Irregular objects can be represented
  • Suitable for magnetic objects
  • Easily prepared
  • Error can be checked by check lines
  • Inaccessible area located by intersection

Disadvantage

  • Low accuracy
  • Cannot work in rain, fog → paper can get wet, no visibility
  • Lots of accessories needed
  • No field book → maps cannot be replotted on different scale

Use in forestry

  • To mark a straight line - fire line, compartment boundary
  • Layout of forest coupe
  • When map is not available as per requirement - JFM boundary
  • Survey of fire burnt area - traversing and radiation to fill inside details
  • To reestablish missing forest boundary pillars

Methods

  • traversing method
  • Radiation method
  • Intersection method
  • resection method

Radiation method or method of angle and distance

  • For locating object from single station
  • Rays are drawn from station to object - distance is plotted with suitable rays on a scale
  • Procedure
  • Application
    • Restricted to small area

Intersection method (triangulation)

  • Utility → for locating in accessible points by intersection of rays drawn from two instruments station

Traversing method or progression method

  • connecting traverse station, fielding and plotting are done simultaneously
  • method
  • Use
    • For establishing skeleton’s main survey line
    • Suitable for linear survey like Road

Forest roads

Types

Main motor-able road branch jeep-ablebridle path inspection path
Connect headquarters to forest block, guesthouse, etc. feeder Road - connects main road with interiorProvides direct route for timber transport by animalsNarrow path around sub-compartment
metalled, well-drainedUsually earth road
3.5m width3m width2-2.5m width0.6-1m width
camber: 12−125\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{25}21​−251​﻿camber: 15−120\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{20}51​−201​﻿

Reconnaissance survey

Preliminary report

  • Rough map
  • Points through which road must pass
  • Contour map
  • alignment, and design
  • Construction cost
  • Effect on environment, forest, wildlife

Locality issues

  • Obstacles e.g. Valley, river
  • Elevation, e.g. Hill, pass
  • Number of routes
  • Climate
  • Rainfall
  • Environmental impact
  • Social impact

Road Issue

  • Gradient
  • Alignment
  • Width
  • Cut and fill slope
  • Soil type
  • Labour cost

Usage issue

  • Use of road
  • Season of use
  • Temporary or permanent
  • How can road help to prevent soil erosion and forest fire

Road design

  • Shoulder
    • Part of road - lying between edge of actual road and side drainage
    • Provides structural support to pavement + traffic can be diverted
  • Camber
    • Raising of road at center to drain rainwater
    • camber of 120\frac{1}{20}201​﻿ ⇒ center of road is raised 120th\frac{1}{20}^\text{th}201​th﻿ of half width of road
  • Breast wall — On the upslope side of road - to prevent lateral pressure of earth
  • Retaining wall — Downslope - resist pressure from earth filling of the pavement due to traffic load and other loads
  • Parapet wall — Protect traffic from falling down the valley

Drainage in hill roads

  • Surface drainage → water on road surface goes to side drain
  • Sub surface drainage — seepage flow weakens roadbed → weep holes to drain them

Importance of forest road

  • Makes forest accessible
  • Transport of timber, fuelwood, etc
  • Tribal connectivity
  • Blockade for runoff, soil erosion
  • wildlife corridor

Challenges

  • Can facilitate illegal felling
  • Can aid illegal wildlife trade
  • Tourist disturb wildlife
  • Outsiders disturb tribal life
  • Erosion of sine due to construction

Maintenance

Standards

  • Water drainage management
  • Pavement repair
  • Retaining wall repair
  • Clean clay sediment
  • Summer and winter maintenance
    • Clean snow, dry grass
  • Landslide remedy

Ensure that it does not

  • Endanger water source
  • Cause erosion
  • Damage forest
  • Threaten habitat of wildlife
  • Destabilize soil

Bridges

Ford or drift

  • Shallow crossing across river with good footing
  • to cross dry and low river flow
  • river bank slope is cut to provide gentle slope
  • natural pre-existing material is used, sometimes complemented with concrete or asphalt

Irish bridge or paved ford

  • A paved dip surface - made of stone, bricks - when water level is low, span more than 7m
  • uses local material

Suspension bridge

  • over large opening, where intermediate piers can’t be erected - e.g. due to strong water current
  • Bridge footing remains suspended in air by cable

Cantilever Bridge

  • Has system of two counterpoised beams - cantilevers supporting the load bearer in middle.
  • Cantilevers - structures that project horizontally into space, supported on only one end
  • Stability depends on - beam length, beam size, centre of gravity, counterweight
  • issues - difficult construction, material wastage, high engineering expertise

Road dam

Across shallow stream crossing - a small dam is constructed

Timber Bridge (a.k.a. simple wooden Bridge)

  • Timber poles strengthened by iron cables
  • Maximum length = 6m
  • Types
    • beam
    • cantilever
    • arch bridge
    • suspended bridge
    • truss bridge

Culverts

  • small bridges - span < 4m
  • usually single span
  • economical
  • types

Building material

Stone

  • Derived from rocks
  • Types
    • Igneous
    • Sedimentary
    • Metamorphic
  • Desirable properties
    • Withstand crushing force
    • Durability
    • Hardness
    • Easy availability and cheap
    • Polishable
    • Fire resistant
  • Example - granite, basalt, marble, sandstone

Bricks

  • An artificially burnt clay block used for construction
  • standard size 19cm x 9 cm x 9 cm

Chemical composition

ComponentRoleProportion (by weight)
Alumina (or clay)gives plasticity20-30%
silica, or sandprevents cracking, and shrinking35-50%
Iron oxideenables sand to melt and bind particle + red colour1-2%
limeenables sand to melt and bind particle1-2%
magnesiaprevents shrinking1-2%
silt20-25%

Good brick characteristics

  • Well burnt, Perfect edge, uniformly red, plain surface, rigging sound when stuck
  • No breaking when dropped from 1 m, no void, water absorption <20% by weight
  • Minimum crushing strength 3.5 N/mm2\pu{3.5N/mm2}3.5 N/mm2﻿
  • poor thermal conductivity

Type

Based on quality

Sun dried

inferior quality → for temporary work

Burnt

For civil engineering work

  • 1st class
    • Standard dimension, uniform
    • For architectural work
  • 2nd class
    • Slight irregularity in size, shape, colour
    • Some cracks
    • Interior and plastered wall
  • 3rd class
    • Not fully burnt, irregular edges
    • Temporary work
  • 4th class
    • Used as aggregates for road, floor and foundation construction

Based on shape

  • Bull-nosed - moulded with rounded angle
  • Circular - meets wall radius, specially made
  • coping - suit wall thickness
    • coping is a covering or capping that's built on top of walls to protect them from the elements and prevent water seepage
  • perforated - light weight, easy to dry
  • paving - burnt at very high temperature - resist traffic abration
  • plinth - for plinth at door, window
  • suint - special edge

Cement

Calcareous substance, similar to hydraulic lime

Ingredients

CaO (63 %),   SiOX2(21 %),  AlX2OX3(6 %),  FeX2OX3(4 %),  MgO(2 %),  SOX3(1 %)\ce{CaO (63\%),\, SiO2(21\%),\,Al2O3(6\%),\,Fe2O3(4\%),\,MgO(2\%),\,SO3(1\%)}CaO (63%), SiOX2​(21%),AlX2​OX3​(6%),FeX2​OX3​(4%),MgO(2%),SOX3​(1%)﻿

Ideal properties

  • greenish-gray color
  • no lump formation
  • cool in temperature
LimeCement
white color grey color
more time taken for settling definite settling time
slack immediately in water contentno immediate slacking
one typedifferent types for different environment
Low strength higher strength
More flexibleRigid

Mortar

  • Mix of lime/cement with sand/surkhi
  • Types - mud mortar, lime, cement, surkhi
  • Function - binds bricks, provide strength

Concrete

  • A paste of binding material - binds fine and coarse aggregate - hardens via chemical reaction
  • Ingredient
    • Cement
    • Fine Aggregate
    • Coarse aggregate
    • Water
  • Ideal properties
    • High compress strength, weak in tension
    • Hardens with time due to water loss
    • No corrosion, no abrasion, fire resistant
  • Types
    • Plain cement concrete
    • RCC - use of steel reinforcement (beam, column)
    • Pre-Stressed CC - use high tensile steel wire
    • Precast CC

Lime

CaCOX3\ce{CaCO3}CaCOX3​﻿ → binding material for mortar preparation - less strength than cement

Sand

  • Find aggregate
  • bulking - up to 10% moisture

Building construction

Site selection

  • Location
  • Accessibility
