  • Good water supply
  • Elevation - keep building slightly raised
  • drainage

Orientation

  • hot climate
    • Face north or north east
    • To avoid hot afternoon
  • Also depends on
    • Sun’s path
    • Prevailing wind
  • Result
    • Building is energy efficient
    • Easier to live
    • comfortable

Foundation

  • Transfers superstructure load to subsoil
  • Objective of foundation
    • Even distribution of load to prevent an equal settlement of substratum
    • provides level and hard surface for building construction
    • Increases lateral stability and overturning of building against wind, earthquake, water force
    • Protection against soil movement and minimizing cracks in superstructure due to expansion and contraction of sub-soil so because of moisture movement
  • Load bearing capacity
    • Black cotton soil : 5 tonne/m2\pu{5 tonne/m2}5 tonne/m2﻿
    • Rock: 250 tonne/m2\pu{250 tonne/m2}250 tonne/m2﻿
  • Load type
    • Dead load
    • Live load - weight of people and household objects
    • Wind load
  • Footing

shallow

  • Spread
  • Strap - 2 independent footing joined by a beam
  • Combined
  • Mat

Deep

  • pile
    • Long cylinder driven deep inside
    • Load transfer via friction and bearing
  • pier
    • Same as pile
    • But load transfer only by bearing
  • well foundation
    • for river bridge
    • box like structure sunk deep

Foundation failure

  • Unequal settlement
  • Soft soil
  • Drainage
  • Wind pressure
  • Sloping ground

Arches

  • A mechanical arrangement of wedge shaped blocks of stone/brick, that mutually support each other - supported by piers at end
  • Stability by - friction between blocks, mortar cohesion, support by end piers

Lintel

Horizontal structure - across span of door window corridor

Need → transfer load of wall above the structure → to below wall

Type - wooden, brick, steel, RCC

Roof

  • TO-DO

Maps

Prepared by WPO

Types

Management map

  • 1:50,000 scale
  • Shows division, range, block, compartment with boundaries
  • Shown in colour → working area, felling series, coupe number
  • Also shows → road, rail line, electricity transmission line

Working plan map

  • 1:12,500 scale
  • Shows management, administrative, physiographic features
  • Also show working circle, felling series, etc.

Stock map

  • 1:15,000 scale
  • Shows distribution of - forest type, species, non-forest area
  • Marked in colour - age class, quality class, crop density

Regeneration survey map

  • 1:5,000 scale
  • After regeneration survey is done

Enumeration map

  • 1:50,000 scale
  • In case of partial enumeration
  • Shows plot, strip, compartment that are actually enumerated

Forest type map

  • 1:50,000 scale
  • Forest type, as per colour

Reference map

  • 1:1,25,000 scale
  • Included inside working plan
  • Mix of working map + management map
  • Shows road, canal, Rest-house, villages, etc.

Soil map

  • Convenient scale
  • At divisional level
  • Type and distribution

Importance

  • Record of boundary, encroachment
  • Management → fires, felling, regeneration, progress of silviculture operations
  • Topography, features, direction, and distance
  • Locating position, guide bearing

Color code for forest type

  • Tropical wet evergreen → violet
  • Tropical semi Evergreen → purple
  • Tropical thorn → red

4. Surveying and Forest Engineering :

Forest surveying - different methods of surveying, maps and map reading. Basic principles of

forest engineering. Building materials and construction. Roads and Bridges; General

principles, objects, types, simple design and construction of timber bridges.

Section B

ecology

Study of interaction among organism and their environment

Levels of organization

organismIndividual plant or animal
PopulationSimilar individuals in a common area
SpeciesAbility to interbreed
communitye.g. plant community
EcosystemBiotic and abiotics in the area
BiomeGroup of ecosystem in a specific climate
BiosphereLife support zone of earth

Environment → all biotic and biotic factors that influence an organism

Abiotic factors of environment

Climatic

Water

  • Euryhaline - tolerate wide range of salinity
  • Stenohaline - tolerate narrow range of salinity

Light

  • Heliophytes - light demander (Etiolation - yellowing of leaves due to absence of light)
  • Sciophytes - shade demander

Temperature

  • Thermo-periodicity - phenomenon of temperature change between - day and night, different seasons
  • Classification of plants
    MegathermsVegetation at 30° – 40°C tropical rainforest
    Mesotherms Subtropical leaves fall → deciduous
    Microtherm low temperature at 10° – 20°C conifers
    Hekistotherm< 10°C alpine, tundra
  • Animal classification
    • Eurythermal - warm blooded - tolerate wide range of temperature
    • Stenothermal - cold blooded - tolerate only a small range of temperature
  • Effect on body
    • Allen’s rule - animals adapted to cold climates have shorter and thicker limbs - low surface area:volume - species of larger size are found in colder environments
    • Bergman rule - populations and species of larger size are found in colder environments

Edaphic

Soil water

Humus

4 types of soil microorganisms

  • Microflora – bacteria, fungi, algae, etc.
  • Microfauna – protozoa e.g. amoeba
  • macro flora – roots of higher plants
  • macro fauna – insect, spider, earthworm, snail

Response to a abiotic factor

Adaptation

  • To do
  • Shelford’s law of tolerance
    • Organism - tolerance limits (ecological amplitude) with respect to environmental factors - temperature, sunlight, nutrient concentration
    • central optimum value → abundant number of organisms = optimum zone of tolerance
  • Regulator - organisms that can maintain homeostasis by physiological means like transpiration, sweating
  • Partial regulator - can regulate up to limit
  • Conformers - do not regulate - internal body condition changes with change in external environment
  • hibernation - winter sleep
  • aestivation - summer sleep
  • diapause - development suspended
  • migration
  • Leibig law of minimum - growth depends on the consuming factor that is available in least quantity
  • Blackman law of limiting factor -
    • when a process → governed by a number of factors → slowest factor → determines rate of process

Biotic factors of environment

Biotic factors

Forest community

  • Community – group of several species living together in an area
  • Ecological amplitude
    • Range of change in environment within which a species can do its normal vital activities
  • Dominance - few species that dominate community
  • Community composition
    • Large community - Kanha national Park
    • Small community - Okhla forest reserve in Delhi
  • Zonation of Forest community
    • Horizontal
    • Vertical

Community character

analytical characters

quantitative

  • Frequency
  • Density
  • Basal area
  • Forest cover

qualitative

  • Phenology
  • Stratification or zonation
  • Climatic adaptation

synthetic character

(derived after computing qualitative and quantitative data)

  • Presence and constance - extent of occurrence
  • Fidelity - extent to which a species is restricted to one kind of community
  • Dominance index
  • Association index
  • Index of similarity
  • Species diversity
  • Diversity index

Species identification

  • Taxonomy - science of - identification, description, classification, and naming of species
  • Plant identification with the help of keys

    Punched card keys

    • Cards having name of all taxa

    Dichotomous keys

    • Choice between contradictory statements → statements have contradictory characteristics
    • e.g. 
    flowchart TD
  Vertebrates --> A{Have Fur?}
  A -- Yes --> Mammal
  A -- No --> B{Have Feathers?}
  B -- Yes --> Bird
  B -- No --> ?

Conservation of forest ecosystem

Issues

  • Forest failing to regenerate naturally
  • loss of food and fodder
  • Shrinking capacity to absorb COX2\ce{CO2}COX2​﻿, pollution

Conservation practices

Manage biotic pressure

lopping, illegal felling, shifting cultivation

Policy

  • Draft forest policy 2012 → grazing based on carrying capacity
  • National bamboo mission → reduce timber demand from other trees

Enrichment plantation

Climate resilient species

Watershed management

  • Increase water availability

Declaration of national Park and wildlife sanctuaries

Ecotourism

  • Increases awareness about importance of ecosystem

Clonal Park

Utility

  • Production of quality planting stock
  • Propagation of problem trees
  • Maintenance of genetic uniformity
  • Production of disease free plants
  • Early flower induction — precocious — reduce the rotation
  • Clonal repository
  • Maintenance of genetic gain

Clonal forestry

  • Large scale deployment of relatively few (10–50) known superior clones that have been proven superior in clonal test
  • Benefits -
    • Tree improvement
    • Uniformity
    • Reliable genotype

Clonal Parks

  • Enclosed plantation of large number of clones of - a particular species, or a mix of many species - for genetic conservation

features

  • Checks performance of clones, exotics, etc.
  • Plantation pattern
    • One species in one row
    • One species in one block
    • Mixed pattern

importance

  • ex-situ conservation
  • Source of high-grade seeds
  • Can do clonal testing
  • Test test the effects of various silvicultural treatments

Dendrology

Taxonomy

  • Taxonomy - science of - identification, description, classification, and naming of species
  • Dendrology - branch of forestry - studies taxonomy of trees, woody plants
  • Systematics - branch of taxonomy - studies - organism diversity; establish comparative and evolutionary relationship
  • New systematics or bio systematics or modern taxonomy
    • Collect large quantity of evidence from all possible fails like – genetics, cytology, biochemistry

Bentham and Hooker system

  • Natural system of classification classified seed plants
graph TD
  A[flowering plant]
  C["Cryptogamia 
  (unicellular spores)"]
  P["Phanerogamia 
  (seed bearing)"]
  A --> C
  A --> P
  C --> Tallophyta
  C --> Bryophyta
  C --> Pteridophyta
  P --> Monocotyledonae
  P --> Dicotyledonae
  P --> Gymnosperma
MeritsDemerit
Based on natural affinitiesDoes not consider evolutionary characters
Supported by personal studiesSome unrelated plants are grouped together

Herbarium

  • Collection of dried specimen - arranged in sequence as per classification system
  • Method of classification – phylogenetic system of plant classification

Importance

  • Conservatory of plant data - specimen collection
  • source of taxonomical information - source of identification
  • Ex-situ genotype conservation - dry specimen available all time
  • Information on name, habitat, color of flower, etc.
  • Chance to develop computer database

Herbarium sheet

  • mount dried specimen
  • Mention their name, habitat, flower color, date of collection, etc.

Types of herbarium sheet

Holotype

  • A herbarium sheet that has —
  • A single specimen of a newly discovered species and its description
  • Placed in major museums

Allotype

  • Specimen of opposite six of holotype

Paratype

  • Additional specimen sheet apart from holotype
  • Tells feature features of holotype

Lactotype

  • If holotype is lost
  • Second sheet is prepared from same original plant

Isotype

  • Duplicate holotype - in presence of holotype
  • Same original plant

Neotype

  • Both holotype and original plant lost
  • Prepared from another plant of same species

Syntype

  • Neotype - but - many sheets prepared from the same species

Steps to establish herbarium

Collection

  • Plant should have grown leaves, flowers, fruit
  • not diseased plant
  • Should have 4 to 6 specimen in same area
  • Note – habitat, colour, locality, etc.

Drying and poisoning

  • Preserve specimen at blotting paper
  • Press via field press
  • Dry the specimen
  • Poison poisoning via mercury chloride → keeps infection away

Mounting, stitching, labeling

  • Specimen glued to herbarium sheet
  • Labeled
    • Name, locality, botanical name
    • Local name
    • Time of collection

Identification and nomenclature of plant

  • For specimen whose name is not recognized

Ethnobotany

  • study of how natives of culture/region use indigenous plant knowledge

Role of ethnobotany

Integrated tribal development

  • Tribals are rewarded for information on traditional use of plant. Ex- Kani tribe (Kerala) - got 5 lakh + 2% royalty - for Jivani drug

New product development

  • Tells about unknown useful plant and new use of known plant

New drug development

  • Of the 2.65 lakh plant species, only 0.5% analysed chemically for medical properties

Reduce time taken to develop new medicine

  • Ethnobotany has more targeted approach based on traditional knowledge

Natural treatment of various diseases

Benefits

  • Helps to protect IPR of traditional medicine
  • Benefit sharing of genetic resources under CBD 1992 article 9
  • Jobs for locals
  • Cheaper for corporates - instead of R&D to develop new synthetic drug

Challenges

  • Insufficient legal provisions
  • Requires multidisciplinary approach - botany, anthropology, pharmacology
  • Lack of policy support - leads to bio piracy
  • Degradation of forest resources
  • Unfair benefit sharing
  • Loss of traditional knowledge with time
  • IPR law protect only “active component”, not the plant

Government steps

  • Traditional knowledge digital library by CSIR and Ayush
  • IPR policy 2016 – promotes bioprospecting

Traditional origin of current modern medicine

Willow barkAspirin - Headache
Rauvolfia serpentina (Indian snake root - Sarpagandha)Reserpine - Hypertension
Abutilon theophrasti (Velvet leaf)D-tubocuranin - Muscle relaxation
Euryturoxylon coca (Coca plant)Cocaine
Papaver somniferum (Opium poppy)Morphine - pain relief
Coffee beansCaffeine

Why traditional knowledge must be protected

  • 80% of world depends on 700 plant species as source of primary medicine
  • To prevent biopiracy
  • Loss of traditional knowledge
    • Loss of traditional life
    • Adopting modern medicine
    • Death of knowledge holders
  • Tribal development
  • Fair Benefit sharing – CBD

How to protect

  • ITR law should protect plant species
  • Germ plasm collection of threatened species
  • Botanical garden
  • Biosphere reserve
  • Sacred groves
  • JFM

Indian traditional system of medicine

  • Ayurveda - like Siddha
  • Yoga
  • Naturopathy
    • Vital curative forces are within body
    • e.g. diet therapy, fasting therapy, acupuncture, magnet therapy
  • Siddha
    • at South India - similar to Ayurveda
    • Body composed of - earth, water, fire, air and sky
    • Doshas - vata, pitta, kapha
    • Diseases when equilibrium between these is disturbed
  • Unani
    • At Greece by Hippocrates → India by Arabs, Persia
    • 4 humor theory - blood, phelgam, yellow bile, black bile
Medicinal and aromatic plants

Medicinal plants

Belladonna leavesAtropa belladonnaSedative
Quinine stem barkCinchona officinalisCardiac depressant, anti malaria
OpiumPapaver SomniferumSedative
Sarpagandha root barkRouvolfia serpentinaHigh blood pressure
Ashvagandha rootWithania somniferaRheumatism
TulsiUcimum sanctumMany
Guggal stem bank (oleo-resin)Commiphora wightiiArthritis, obesity, cholesterol, blood pressure
Neem - leaf, bark, seed oilAzadirachta indicaMany
Amla fruitEmblica officinalis
Bael fruitAegle marmelos

Aromatic plants

HeengFerula asafoetida
CloveSyzygium aromaticum
KesarCrocus sativus
CorianderCoriandrum sativum
JeeraCumini cyminum
SounfFoeniculum vulgare

1. Forest Ecology and Ethnobotany :

Forest ecology - Biotic and aboitic components, forest eco-systems; forest community

concepts; vegetation concepts, ecological succession and climax, primary productivity, nutrient

cycling and water relations; physiology in stress environments (drought, water logging salinity

and alkalinity). Forest types in India, identification of species, composition and associations;

dendrology, taxonomic classification, principles and establishment of herbaria and arboreta.

Conservation of forest ecosystems. Clonal parks, Role of Ethnobotany in Indian Systems of

Medicine; Ayurveda and Unani - Introduction, nomenclature, habitat, distribution and

botanical features of medicinal and aromatic plants. Factors affecting action and toxicity of

drug plants and their chemical constituents.

Felling and conversion

Felling

Objects of felling

Mechanisation of felling

  • Cheap, less time
  • More efficient than non-powered
  • light weight

Benefit

  • Less shattering of pole
  • Greater precision
  • Sawing both horizontal and vertical

Issues

  • Skilled labor
  • Difficult to repair in remote areas

Felling rules

Aim

  • Produce maximum amount of sound timber
  • Avoid damage to nearby vegetation

Rules

  • Felling as near to the ground as possible
  • Failing direction → least damage
  • Hilly area → start from top of slope
  • Easy extraction possible
  • Strong wind → no felling

Ways of felling

  • Felling with axe only
  • Axe + saw
  • Saw only
  • Felling by root

    When underground portion is very valuable - e.g. Santalum album (Sandalwood)

logging a.k.a. log making

  • Series of operations → Tree felling, limbing (branch trimming), bucking, conversion (sawing of clean bole) → into sections of required size → transport it out of forest
  • Length of log

    Standard size → 3m

    Truck transport → maximum 5 m

Conversion

  • Felled timber is converted to usable form of various size e.g. Rail sleeper, Poles, etc
  • Character
    • Done at manual or mechanised sawmill
    • Done Inside or outside forest facilities
    • Goal: keep wastage to minimum

Reduced impact logging (RIL)

about

Well planned and controlled timber harvesting to minimize environmental impact

  • Mapping of pre-harvest inventory
  • Mapping of pre-harvest individual trees
  • Cutting of heavy vines connected to the tree crown
  • Construction of road, skid rails (temporary Road)
  • Cutting
    • Directional
    • Cutting stumps low
    • Optimal cross cutting
  • Post harvest assessment and feedback

Benefits

  • environmental benefits
  • reduce the percentage of “lost” logs
  • increasing revenue

issues

  • Logging operations don't get proper professional attention
  • Environmental angle is overlooked
  • It is believed that taking RIL precaution will increase cost
  • Lack of professionals with RIL skills
  • Aerial extraction of timber - too expensive developing nations

Timber grading

Defects

Insect attack

  • Holes

Fungal attack

Decay (rot) - both hardwood and softwood - e.g. White rot, red rot

Stain

  • Fungi feeds sapwood where food is stored
  • Heartwood is not impacted
  • No Impact on strength
  • Only colour change changes

Natural defect

  • Fluted stem → deformation in circular periphery of tree, which results in the loss of wood → often, irregular vertical ridges and furrows
  • Tapering
  • Inbark → patch of bark → enclosed the inside wood
  • Knot → oval or circular portion of branch embedded into wood

Seasoning defect

  • Crack
    • Separation of fibre along the grain
    • Usually at one end, doesn't extend to other end

  • Splits - extends from one end to other
  • Honeycombing - “internal checks” due to drying stress
  • Shakes - crack due to fibre separation

Grading of timber

class A class B class C
qualityBest quality logmedium qualityPoor quality
defect sound from all aspects + free from any defectFree From major defectsunsound log + many / all major defects
tapering per 3 m< 20 cm20-25 cm>25 cm
curvature< 7 cm7-15 cm>15 cm
Flutes (depth)< 4cm 4-7 cm> 7 cm

Properties of wood

Gross structure or macro structure

  • Bark : outermost part, usually dead, species identification
  • Sapwood : younger and lighter, middle portion, food storage
  • Heartwood: heavy and dark, central portion, deposition of gum, resin, etc.
  • Pith: small and soft central portion

Anatomical structure or micro structure

  • Pore (vessel)
  • Fibre - spindle shape elongated cell - mechanical support
  • Tracheids - also elongated cell - but ends connected
  • Ray parenchyma - storage and transport of water, nutrients, carbohydrates
  • Gummy deposits - contain chemicals in pores - decide color and smell of wood
  • Xylem tissue - consists of vessels scattered through ring → formation of - ring pores, semi-ring porus, diffused pores

Mechanical property of wood

  • Durability
    • service life of wood
    • Resistance against disease, decay, etc.
    • Teak is standard
  • Strength - Withstanding stress
  • Hardness – resistance to penetration
  • Elasticity – ability to regain shape after external forces removed – male bamboo (Dendrocalamu strictus) shows great elasticity
  • Flexibility – bend to any shape without a rupture – softwood is more flexible
  • Fissibility – splitting along the fibre by axe, wedge, etc. – industry of matchstick and pencils – Yew (Taxus beccata)

Use of wood or timber

Agricultural implement

  • Only strongest, toughest, hardest wood
  • Bullock cart, plough, handles
  • Acacia nilotica (Babool)
  • Xylia xylocarpa

Battery separator

  • Free from resin, tannin, volatile acids
  • Light, strong, straight grain
  • Conifer - Deodar, Fir, Spruce

Boat and ship

  • Lightweight, corrosion resistant
  • Strong, elastic, durable, defect free
  • Teak

Furniture

  • No crack, wrap, split
  • Teak

Matchwood

  • fissility, straight grain, no knots
  • Salai
  • Populus tremula

Musical instruments

  • Teak

Packaging industry

  • Straight fiber, no knots
  • Conifer - deodar, fir, spruce

Pencil

  • Straight grain, light, no knots
  • Juniperus virginia (American cedar)

Plywood

  • Teal, Sal

Sports

  • Salix alba

Railway Sleeper

  • Teak, Sal

Walking stick

  • Bamboo, canes

Sale of forest produce

System of sales

Lump sum sale

  • A fixed sum is paid
  • Permission to extract product from specific area of forest
  • Exact amount of product to be extracted is unknown at the time of agreement
  • Involves Sale of
    • whole coupe / area
    • Standing trees
    • Few selected trees
    • License / permit

Royalty

  • Amount depends upon product sold or extracted - could be wasted on volume, weight or quantity

Method of sale

private bargain

Owner deal with single purchasers based on past sale, market trends

Circumstances

  • Small quantity
  • Limited demand
  • To popularise a new exotic

Advantage

  • Getting fair price in low demand
  • Creates future market
  • Breaks auction ring
  • When market is done or overstocked
  • Saves auction expenses
graph TD
  Bidding --> A[Public Auction]
  Bidding --> Tender
  Tender --> B[Open Tender]
  Tender --> C[Sealed Tender]

Wood Seasoning

Seasoning

  • Remove of moisture from timber – present in its green State

Objective

  • To reduce → fungal infection, weight, transportation cost, seasoning defects
  • Make timber fit for - application of preservatives

Seasoning defects

Shrink, swell

Due to moisture

Cracking, splitting

Due to rapid drying

Warping

  • Unusual shrinkage or expansion
  • Cupping → curvature across width
  • Bowing → curvature across length
  • Crook → wrap along length’s edge

Seasoning behaviour

non-refractory wood

  • No crack, split, …
  • Withstand seasoning
  • Mango
  • Abies pinedrew (Silver fir)
  • Pinux roxburghii (Chir)
  • Cedrus deodara (Deodar)

moderately refractory wood

  • Moderate crack, split, … during seasoning
  • Dalbergia sissoo
  • Tectona grandis

highly refractory

  • Easily crack, split, warp during seasoning
  • Syzygium cumini (Jamun)
  • Shorea robusta (Sal)

Pre-seasoning preparation

green conversion

Freshly cut timber with moisture – converted into plants

water submerge

water leaches out sap like sugar, gum, tannis →

  • Makes drying easy
  • Reduces split and crack

Land storage

Placed in shelter house → remove bark if threat of insect attack

Method of seasoning

Air seasoning

  • Air carries heat and removes moisture
  • Horizontal stacking
    • Most common
    • Suitable for all wood

  • Vertical stacking
    • For rapid drying - prevent fungi growth
    • Only non-refractory wood

  • Protection of stack
    • Refractory wood → High roof + vent ventilation window
    • Moderately refractory → medium protection

Kiln Seasoning

  • steam is used as source of heat + artificial humidity
  • Advantage
    • Set any temperature, humidity, air circulation
    • Quick Drying
  • Recommended when
    • Timber needed for special work
    • Need very less moisture content
    • Timber susceptible to fungus
    • Cost not an issue

Furnace kiln

  • When steam is not available or too expensive
  • This has its own furnace
  • Direct type - Combustion gases come into direct contact of wood
  • Indirect type - gases pass through iron ducts – air heated inside dryer

Salt seasoning

  • Highly refractory species - soaked into NaCl\ce{NaCl}NaCl﻿ - then air seasoning
  • Surface of timber absorbs salt
    • Maintain relative humidity
    • Ensures diffusion of moisture from interior
    • Prevents unequal shrinkage

Chemical seasoning

  • Replace NaCl\ce{NaCl}NaCl﻿ with hygroscopic substances - CaClX2\ce{CaCl2}CaClX2​﻿, molasses

Wood preservation

  • Improving wood’s natural durability – chemical treatment — that are toxic to insects, etc.

Need

  • Increase life
  • Increase workability
  • Avoid frequent wood replacement

Preservatives

  • Chemicals used in preservation - usually for insect, pest
  • Ideal property
    • Toxic for insect
    • Not toxic to humans
    • No leaching by water
    • Impregnate wood easily
    • High chemical stability
    • Cheap

types

oil type

Creosote

  • Brown – black oil distilled from coal
  • Effective against termite, borer
  • No leaching, no corrosion
  • But
    • Bad smell
    • Poor look to wood
    • Makes inflammable

Coal tar

water soluble

(all – effective to fungi)

CuSOX4\ce{CuSO4}CuSOX4​﻿

  • But easily leached by water

ZnClX2\ce{ZnCl2}ZnClX2​﻿

  • But easily leached by water

HgClX2 (Mercury chloride)\ce{HgCl2 (Mercury chloride)}HgClX2​ (Mercury chloride)﻿

  • But – toxic to humans

ASCU\ce{ASCU}ASCU﻿

  • Most famous, widely used
  • Stable, Less poisonous to humans
  • Arsenic pentoxide (1): CuSOX4\ce{CuSO4}CuSOX4​﻿ (3) : potassium (4)

Benefit of water soluble

  • Cheap, effective, wood remains clean
  • Easy to paint
  • Easy combination with fire retardant

organic solvent

Copper, zinc organic acid → dissolved in organic solvent then applied → when timber dries → solvent evaporates, preservative remains

e.g. hardi-proof, cuprinol

Advantages

  • Wood remains clean
  • Deep penetration
  • No leaching
  • Easy to paint
  • No swell

Issues

  • Expensive
  • Reduces inflammability of wood

Process

Superficial

  • Surface treatment by brush
  • But - surface coating can be broken, cannot use water soluble types

Soaking and diffusion

  • Submerge dry timber to solution of preservative
  • Slow absorption

Hot and cold

  • wood + preservative submerged → heat to 100°C by steam coil for 2–4 hours → for oil type preservatives

Pressure process

  • Cylindrical container → wood inserted → door closed → maintain maximum pressure

Bouchore’s process (sap displacement)

  • Forcefully enter preservative at one end of Bamboo culm – till it comes out of the other end
  • sap displaced by natural capillary

application

  • sapwood treatment
  • Hardwood of some species

advantage

  • Increase life
  • Low cost
  • Reaches all parts of bamboo
  • Create jobs

Composite wood and improved wood

  • Built up product – consisting either – wholly of natural mood -or- wood combined with plastic and metal

Composite wood

Plywood

  • Thin layer of wood veneers → glued with adjacent layers → grains of each veneer at 90° to each other
  • Outer layer = FACES
  • Inner layer = CORES
  • Number of veneer = odd

Manufacturing Process

Logs cut to block → veneer peeled → veneer drying → apply glue → cold press → hot press → sanding → trimming → grading → storage

laminated wood

A thin board of veneer - glued over solid core on both sides - grains are parallel

Core board

Solid core is made of several strips of food - glued to farm lab - thin veneers on both faces

Particle board

  • Solid core made of - wood chips - glued with synthetic resin - thin veneer on both faces
  • Single layer plastic board - wood particle of same size, water resistant - not waterproof
  • Three layer particleboard - large wood particles - sandwiched between two layers of small and very dense particles
  • Greater density particle board - coarse particle - sandwich difference between two layer fine particles - e.g. Computer cabinet.
  • Cement bonded particle board
    • cement: wood: water = 60:20:20
    • Resistant to fire, moisture, termite
    • e.g. false ceiling use
  • Laminated particleboard - thin laminated sheet at surface

Advantage of composite wood

  • Uniform density
  • Smooth surface
  • Low wood wastage
  • No knots, twist, air pocket
  • Any dimension can be created
  • As per need, can be - water resistant, fireproof, chemical proof

Improved wood or modified wood

  • Wood that has been specially treated to
    • Reduce susceptibility against adverse factors
    • Introduce strength and stability

Types

  • Impregnated wood - use wax, paraffin, resin as impregnants
  • Heat stabilized wood - wood passed under surface of molten metal at 260–315° C
  • Compressed wood
    • wood only compressed, no impregnation
    • Increases specific gravity and strength
  • compregnated wood - impregnation + compressed
  • Chemically modified wood -
    • OH\ce{OH}OH﻿ group of cellular is replaced
    • Chemicals used - urea, HX2SOX4\ce{H2SO4}HX2​SOX4​﻿
    • Reduces hygroscopicity - more dimensional stability

NTFP

  • All forest produce other than timber, small wood and fuelwood

Fibers

  • Are sclerenchyma cells (elongated cells + thick wall), that are component of both, xylem, and phloem
    • Soft fiber → if source is phloem
    • Hard fiber → xylem
  • Retting - method of extracting fiber

Types

Fiber from stem

  • Hardiwickia binata (Anjan) → rope
  • Acacia leucophloea → fishing nets
  • Colotropis gigantea → durable even under saltwater, cannot be rettled, so separate fiber by hand

Fibre from leave

  • Caryota urens - Kittul fibre → fishing nets
  • Musa textilis - indigenous to Philippines - called “Manila hemp”
  • Agave american - Sisal fibre obtained
  • Agave sisalana - Sisal fiber obtained

Flosses

  • Bombax ceiba - floss is called “Indian Kapok”
  • Salix daphnoides
  • Populus ciliata

Grass

  • Saccharum munja - at River bed - all India → thatching roof + ropes
  • Saccharum spontaneoum - West Bengal - mud walls plaster over this grass
  • Eucalilopsis binata - Bhabhar region - paper + ropes

Gums

Hydrophilic carbohydrate polymer, with high molecular weight, composed of monosaccharides

  • Water soluble
  • Alcohol insoluble
  • Completely decompose on heating
  • Dries on contact with air to form translucent substance

Types

  • Soluble gums - dissolve in water (Indian gum Arabic)
  • Insoluble gums -
  • Partially soluble gum - (Morocco gum)

Obtained by

  • From woody plant - cracked in branch, damaged by insect

Trees giving gum

Acacia gummiferaMorocco gum
Acacia niloticaIndian gum ArabicDyeing, paper manufacture
Acacia senegalTrue gum ArabicMedicine, textile, confectionery
Butea monospermaBengal kinoMedicine
Bombax ceiba Indian taragacanth medicine, cosmetics
Moringa oleiferaMoringa gumMedicine

Other uses

cough suppress, binding tablet, stabilise syrup, sweets, thickening agent for petroleum drilling mud

Resin

Sticky flammable substance, originating through polymerization of carbohydrates, ooze out through bark, protect plant from injuries and insects

  • Water insoluble
  • Alcohol soluble
  • Burns with flame on heating
  • Brittle and transparent

Types

  • Hard resin - solid, no oil - Amber
  • Oleo resin - lots of oil, viscous like honey - turpentine
  • Gum resin - contains both gum and resin
  • Oleo gum resin - gum + oleo resin

Obtained by

Plant secrete resin to respond to injury or protect from insect

Trees giving resin

  • Pinux roxburghii - pine resin
  • Pinus walichiana - Pine resin
  • Shorea robusta - Sal - disinfectant, fumigant
  • Commiphora mukul - Indian belladium - perfume, medicine

Uses

  • adhesive
  • Paint
  • Medicine
  • Disinfectant
  • Jewellery
  • Car parts repairing

Tannins

  • Natural phenolic product - that precipitate protein from their aqueous solution
  • Used to convert skin and hides into leather
obtained from plant
woodAcacia catechu
barkAcacia nilotica
Shore robusta
fruitAcacia nilotica
leafEmblica officinalis

Dyes

  • Substances used for staining and coloring
obtained from plant common name
rootRubia cordifolia red dye
leafIndigofera spp. Indigo
woodAcacia catechuCutch
barkRubia cordifolia red dye
flower and fruitButea monospermaDhak

Oils

Odoriferous liquid in many plants – vaporise on air contact

obtained from plant common name
grassCymbopogon flexosus lemon grass oil
wood- Santalum album
- Pinus spp.
- Sandalwood oil
- Pine oil
Leaf eucalyptus globulus eucalyptus oil
rootSaussuria lappa Costus oil
seed-
- Shorea robusta
- Azadirachta indica
- Mahua butter
- sal butter
- neem oil

Bamboo

  • Tall perennial grass
  • woody stem - culms - arise from rhizome
  • 150 species
  • Dendrocalamus strictus (Male bamboo)
    • Most common in peninsula
    • At tropical dry deciduous
  • Dendrocalamus hamiltonii (Kagaji bans)
    • Northeast Himalayas
    • Altitude: 600–1200 m
    • Paper manufacturing
  • Bamboosa bamboo (thorny bamboo)
    • Gangetic plains
    • Paper manufacturing

Utility

  • Food
    1. Seed and shoot our eaten – pickle
    1. In Sikkim, people make beer from seed
    1. Edible Bamboo species - B. multiplex, B. polymorpha, P. nuda.
  • Fodder

    Leaves – rich in vitamin, mineral – eaten by elephant, panda

  • Medicine
    • Stem and leaves of B. bambos – treat leukoderma, blood purifier
    • Silicious material from stem → treat asthma, cough
  • Industrial
    • Paper and pulp
    • Plywood
    • Agricultural implements
    • House construction - timber
    • Furniture
  • Artefacts
    • Baskets
    • Walking stick
  • Firewood
    • Calorie value > 7000 cal/kg
  • Environmental utility
    • Releases 35% more OX2\ce{O2}OX2​﻿
    • 1 L of bamboo sequesters 12 ton COX2\ce{CO2}COX2​﻿
    • Cleans Sewage water
    • Decontaminates heavy metal pollution

Rattan i.e. canes

  • Stems of climbing palms of genus Calamus
    • Up to 100 m long, uniform thickness, cylindrical
  • Species
    • Calamus guruba
    • C. tennis
    • C. rotang

Beedi leaves

  • Thin cigarette - filled with tobacco - wrapped in Tendu (Diospyros melanoxylon) leave

Lac

  • Resinous substance of animal origin
  • India – 70% – 80% of world production
  • Two types of insects

    Kusumi

    • on Schleichera oleosa (Kusum tree)
    • Less output, but superior quality

    Rangini

    • Butea monosperma (Palash)
    • Acacia catechu (Khair)
    • Acacia nilotica (Babool)
    • 80–90% of lac output
  • Shellac - refining crude lac - produce bangles, polishes, wax, etc.

Cutch and Kattha

  • Boiling heartwood of Acacia catechu (Khair)
  • Found at tropical deciduous and thorn forest

Animal product

  • Honey bee - Apis indica
  • Silk - Bombyx mori
  • Gunas - bird excreta - rich in phosphorus - manure
  • Ivory - elephant

Sal seed as NTFP

  • Sal is found in central Indian states → Odisha, CG, Madhya Pradesh have Sal as 45% of their forest area.
  • Sal Seed
    • Harvested during six week between May-June.
      • Hence, employment between end of Tendu lead season (-April) → Sal Seed (May-June) → Start of Agri season (July-)
    • Used as
      • Food - Coca equivalent in chocolate
      • Cosmetic - oil, soap
      • De-oiled cake as cattle feed

2. Forest Resources and Utilization

: Environmentally sound forest harvesting practices;

logging and extraction techniques and principles, transportation system, storage and sale;

Non-Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) definition and scope; gums, resins, oleoresins, fibres, oil

seeds nuts, rubber, canes, bamboos, medicinal plants, charcoal, lac and shellac, Katha and

Bidi leaves, collection; processing and disposal.

Need and importance of wood seasoning and preservation; general principles of seasoning, air

and kiln seasoning, solar dehumidification, steam heated and electrical kilns. Composite wood;

adhesives-manufacture, properties, uses, plywood manufacture-properties, uses, fibre boards-

manufacture properties, uses; particle boards manufacture; properties uses. Present status of

composite wood industry in India in future expansion plans. Pulp-paper and rayon; present

position of supply of raw material to industry, wood substitution, utilization of plantation

wood; problems and possibilities.

Anatomical structure of wood, defects and abnormalities of wood, timber identification -

general principles.

Man damage to forest

  • Deforestation, shifting cultivation, illegal felling, forest fire, encroachment, defective management, environmental pollution

Deforestation

Tree removal with no intention of reforestation

Cause

  • Forest diversion for non-forest
    • Chamba-Mussoorie fruit-belt of UP established in 1960s by clearing Deodar-Oak forest of Shivalik
    • Since independence, India has diverted 7.5 million ha of forest land
  • Forest fire - 2016 Uttarakhand - 45,000 ha burnt
  • Shifting cultivation
  • Climate change
  • Over exploitation of forest resource
  • Naxals
  • Department – neglect and corruption
  • Defective forest policy

prevention

  • Remote sensing
    • Forest alarm fire system (FAST 3.0)
  • e-green watch portal
  • Forest certification
  • Timber certification
  • Public participation in management
  • No shifting cultivation

remedy

  • PPP model of afforestation
  • CAMPA plantation
  • Taungya to replace shifting cultivation
  • Agroforestry
  • Social forestry
  • LPG to replace fuelwood
  • Improve forest productivity
  • Educate people on benefits of forest

Shifting cultivation

  • 2% of geographical area → 40% in Northeast – called “Jhum”

Impact

Advantage

How to control?

  • Home garden → cultivate seasonal local crop
  • Credit facility
  • Agroforestry model
  • Alternatives → oil palm plantation in Manipur under Taungya system
  • PM Van Dhan scheme
  • Land classification based on land capability

Forest fire

Controlled Fire

  • Reduce hazardous fuels
  • Dispose of logging debris
  • Prepare sites for seeding or planting
  • Improve wildlife habitat
  • Manage competing vegetation
  • Control insects and disease
  • Improve forage for grazing
  • Enhance appearance
  • Improve access
  • Perpetuate fire-dependent species

Causes

natural

  • Lightning strike
  • Rubbing of dry leaves
  • Rubbing of dry bamboo culms
  • Volcanic eruption

human - accidental

  • Bidi, cigarette
  • Illegal honey collector
  • Electricity spark
  • Forest Village accidental fire
  • Crackers to scare animals
  • Firearm used by forest officials

human – deliberate

  • Fire of shifting cultivation
  • Controlled fire by department - to check weed - becomes uncontrolled
  • Fire by tribals - to induce better flush for Tendu leaves
  • Smugglers burning grass to find horn and bones
  • Fire to trap animals

Classification

  • Ground fire - burns ground cover only, no flame, only black smoke
  • Creeping fire - slow spread over ground, low flow
  • Surface fire - ground fire + under growth (seedling)
  • Crown fire - at conifers

Examples

  • Australia, 2019
    • 25 mn ha
    • 3 bn vertebrates
    • Lightning + draught + high temperature + poor management
  • Amazon 2019
    • Shifting cultivation
    • Deforestation
    • Long dry Period
  • Uttarakhand 2019
    • 4500 ha

Importance

  • Removes weed and debris
  • Improve site quality
  • Kills insects and fungi
  • Introduction of new species
  • Fire by tribals → induce better flush for Tendu leaves
  • Control burning or early burning
    • Deliberate early burning of inflammables like leaf, etc.
    • Before onset of dry season
    • Reduces chances of forest fire
  • Kaziranga grassland controlled burning
    • Old grass have less nutrition
    • Easy to locate poachers
    • Easy for tourists

Prevention

  • Silviculture → cleaning and weeding
  • Plant evergreen trees
  • Avoid pure plantation
  • Planned grazing to check undergrowth
  • 2,4 D herbicide → clean weed
  • Maintain firelines
    • A permanently clear felled strip, burnt every year
    • To ensure discontinuity of fire
    • With: 6–30 m
  • FAST 3.0
  • Patrolling and watchtower
  • Educate people in forest

Remedy

  • Eliminate heat
    • Water spray
    • Heat retarding chemical - DAP
  • If small area fire
    • “beating up” by broom
  • Counter firing → deliberately burn flammable material in direction opposite to wind
  • Mopping up → post fire suppression

Tools

McLeod Fire rake, Pulaski, Fire Broom

Mining

  • Destroys entire vegetation

Encroachment

Remedy

  • Demarcate Forest land
  • Alternative employment to people

Illegal felling

  • Cause → Corrupt contractor

Remedy

  • Right price of MFP
  • Steady timber supply

Lopping

Cutting of branch, twigs, leaves → by local people for → cattle feed, fuel wood, fencing material

impact on tree

(if done regularly)

  • weakens tree
  • Vulnerable to disease
  • Productivity falls
  • Reduced tree crown – soil erosion
  • Impacts flowering and seed production
  • Impact natural regeneration

preventive

  • Allow lopping once in four years
  • No lopping on trees with diameter <30 cm
  • No lopping on upper third of the crown
  • Not by axes or other heavy tools
  • Don't feed it to cattle directly under tree → take it home and feed cattle at stall

remedial step

  • Where some trees have been killed → plant fodder species to reduce pressure on other existing trees
  • Where extreme damage → close area for lopping for 10 years; take up plantation

Animal harm to forest

Damage – grazing, browsing, trampling → wild animal / domestic animal

Grazing

  • Feeding of leaves and twigs of grass and herbs

Significance

  • Provides milk, food, meat → backbone of rural economy
  • 25% of agriculture GDP

Grazing pattern

migratory G

Animal moves to low altitude in winter - Bakarwal in Himachal Pradesh

24 hour G

Animal inside forest during designated period → recaptured letter for domestic use

Day G

animals allowed only daytime

stall feeding

Human collect fodder from forest → field to cattle at stall

Animals cannot enter forest

Grazing system

Continuous grazing

  • No control → allowed grazing year around
  • Impact
    • Decrease palatable crops
    • Increase weed
    • Low input - low output system

Controlled grazing

  • Animals stays in area for a long time
  • But size of grazing area is adjusted by moving fences

Rotational grazing

  • Grazing land divided into unit units “Paddocks”
  • Only one part is allowed at a time
  • Ensure regeneration + enough palatable species

Strip grazing

  • Grassland divided into strips
  • Allow fixed number of animals for fixed time
  • Gives high-quality graze, least wastage

Deferred grazing

  • Particular part of grassland is closed for a season → allows regeneration

(name each paddock with seasons)

Unitary grazing

  • only one kind of animal allowed - e.g. Pollarding area → buffalo but not camel

Forward grazing

  • Only two kind allowed
    • 1: high nutrient need
    • 2: low nutrient need

Mixed grazing

  • All animal types allowed → forage is uniformly used

Damage by grazing

  • Animals eat only a particular species → creates a regeneration problem
  • Mechanical injury to plant and root
  • Disturb Plant physiology
  • Impact forest flora’s composition
  • Leads to → retrogressive succession - e.g. in UP, forest become Savannah
  • Soil aggregate breakdown
  • Soil erosion – land degradation

Management: prevention

  • Allow based on carrying capacity
  • Planned – e.g. rotational, strip, etc.
  • Tree fodder based protein bank - e.g. Hardiwickia
  • Promote stall feeding
  • Established grasses like Sorghum → supplements fodder requirement

Grasslands, a.k.a. Rand land, a.k.a. pasture land

  • Vegetation predominated by graminoids - grass, grass like plants
  • Why not much found at tropics?
    • Harsh climate - drought
    • Tree and shrub suppress its growth
  • Types in India
  • Grassland species
    • Pennisetum pelicellatum (Deenanath grass)
    • P. purpurcum (elephant grass)
  • Threat to grassland
    • Cattle pressure
    • Invasive species → Parthenium grass
    • Climate change
    • Fragmentation of grassland
  • Ecology and tribes

Live fencing

  • Non-eatable and obnoxious plants around plantation → Jatropha, Agave, Euphorbia

Damage by insects

Termite

  • Microtermis mycophagus
  • More in arid and semi-arid region
  • Positive role – nutrient recycling
  • Chemical control – Aldrin

Leaf defoliator

  • Hyblaea purea
  • Teak
  • Attack – pre-monsoon (April – June)
  • Control – NPV virus
  • Other defoliator
    • Gamelia tree → Calopepla leayana
    • Poplar tree → Pygeara fulgurita

Root borer

  • Celostema scabrator
  • Acacia spp.

Control measures

silvicultural control

  • Resistant species
  • Mix cropping
  • Thinning of weak and diseased trees
  • Larger plantation area is more susceptible
  • Artificial regeneration is more susceptible
  • Forest fire – kills insects

Biological control

  • Cotton ballworm → NPV virus

mechanical control

  • Destroying egg masses
  • Flooding burrows
  • Use grease band to prohibit insect from climbing tree

Chemical control

  • Aldrin, DDT
  • Male/female hormone insecticide → damages, reproductive system of female insect

Nursery disease

Damping off

  • Most widespread problem
  • Attacks mostly → Conifer seedling

Three stages

  • Pre-emergence blight → seedling killed even before the emerge from ground
  • Post-emergence blight → rolling tissue at base; rolling of root ⇒ seedling death
  • Root rot → fungi (Rhizoctonia solani) attacks root

Factors affecting

  • Anaerobic condition in root
  • High temperature
  • Alkaline or neutral pH soil
  • Low sunlight
  • Dense sowing
  • Use of nitrogen fertilizer

prevention and control

  • Light texture, well-drained soil
  • Acidic soil
  • Less watering during germination
  • Acid forming fertilizer
  • Sterilisation of poly-bag and nursery bed
    • chemicals: Kaptan, formalin, methyl bromide
  • Proper sunlight

Seedling wilt

  • Pathogen: Fusarium solani
  • Affects roots → blocks xylem → yellowing of leaf → seedling dies within 48 hours if nothing is done
  • Impacts
    • Acacia nilotica
    • Acacia tortilis
    • Azadirachta indica
  • Control
    • Soil drenching → adding chemical directly to base (Dithane M-45)

Charcoal root rot

  • Pathogen: Rhizoctonia bataticola
  • Collar region becomes dark → death of seedling
  • During – dry and hot climate
  • Control – Dithane M-45
  • species
    • Eucalyptus
    • Acacia nilotica
    • Prosopis juliflora

Leaf spot

Fungus – Alternaria alternate → impact Albizzia

Leaf rust

Olivea tectonae → impacts Teak

Powdery mildrew

White powder on leaf → Uncinula spp. → impacts Teak, Neem

Control

Chemical

  • Pesticide - sodium nitrate

Mechanical

  • Soil humidity
  • Air and temperature condition

Silvicultural

  • Resistant varieties
  • Mixed cropping

3. Forest Protection & Wildlife Biology :

Injuries to forest - abiotic and biotic, destructive agencies, insect-pests and disease, effects of

air pollution on forests and forest die back. Susceptibility of forests to damage, nature of

damage, cause, prevention, protective measures and benefits due to chemical and biological

control. General forest protection against fire, equipment and methods, controlled use of fire,

economic and environmental costs; timber salvage operations after natural disasters. Role of

afforestation and forest regeneration in absorption of CO2. Rotational and controlled grazing,

different methods of control against grazing and browsing animals; effect of wild animals on

forest regeneration, human impacts; encroachment, poaching, grazing, live fencing, theft,

shifting cultivation and control.

forest policies

Forest policy 1894

  • Classified forest as
    • First class - forest on Hills slope, etc., here, vegetation preservation is essential to protect Hill
    • Second class - forest supplies Teak, Sal, Deodar - commercial angle - Limited grazing rights
    • Third class - forest patch - inferior vegetation - meet demand of fuel, fodder of locals
    • Fourth class - pasture and grazing - no strict conservation
  • Also provides for
    • permanent cultivation gets precedence over forestry
    • Fulfill forest needs of locals
    • Maximize revenue
  • criticism
    • Did not provide for
      • Sustainable productivity management
      • Tribal rights, grazing rights
      • Regulation of ecological resources
    • Government benefit as sole issue
    • No wildlife provision
    • nothing to regular shifting cultivation
    • Nothing to prevent diversion of forest land for agriculture

Forest policy 1952

Background

  • Increasing food and fodder demand
  • Need to regulate private forest
  • Growth of cottage, cooperative industry
  • Need for sustainable yield

Provisions

  • Classification
    • National Forest - industrial and other needs
    • Protection forest - preserved to protect environment
    • Village forest - firewood, manure, cattle grazing
    • Tree land - outside conventional forest area
  • To fulfill needs
    • Balanced use of forest land
    • check mountain denundation
    • Established tree land
    • Sustained timber supply
  • Goals
    • 33% country area under forest
    • 60% area of hills and mountains

Criticism

  • Development of industry, infrastructure, etc. between 1950–80 led to decline in forest cover
  • Prioritized production over conservation
  • Did not include peoples participation in forest management
  • Did not consider right and concession of forest dwellers
  • No forest education, R&D outside forest department

National forest policy 1988

background

  • No more issue of food security
  • Climate change issue
  • Focus on conservation
  • New industries – require specific input
  • India's international commitment – e.g. our common future report
  • Tribal rights
  • Project tiger, etc.
  • CAMPA

objective

  • Restore ecological balance
  • Preserve flora, and fauna
  • prevent flood and drought
  • fuel, fodder, MFP
  • Increase productivity
  • Area under forest
    • 33% nationally
    • 66% at Hills and mountains

significance

  • Sustainable forest management
  • Focus on ecological balance - away from revenue generation

Provisions

  • afforestation
  • Extension forestry
  • Social forestry
  • Farm forestry
  • Management of state forest
    • “working plan” approval must for any forest work
    • No exotic without scientific trial
    • Restrict schemes that interfere with forest ecology
  • Shifting cultivation
    • Restrict it
    • Rehabilitation of damaged area via plantation
  • Right and concession
    • Bona fide community use
    • Grazing right as per carrying capacity
    • Replace fuel wood by LPG and bio gas
  • Diversion of forest land for non-forest purpose
    • Should provide for CAMPA
    • mining lease should have “mine management plan”
  • Wild life - Wild life corridor
  • Forest extension - people awareness on value of the forest
  • Tribals
    • Reason for forest decline is illegal cutting by contractors
    • Replace contractors with tribal cooperative
  • encroachment and grazing
    • Don't legalize (regularise) existing encroachment
    • Levy grazing fee to discourage grazing
  • Forest based industry
    • should raise its own around material availability
    • Encourage small and marginal farmers to grow woody species

Draft national forest policy 2018

need

  • International commitments of India
  • Low productivity of our forest
  • Climate change impact
  • Man, wildlife conflict

goals, and objectives

  • Sustainable use of environment
  • 33%, 66%
  • Achieve INDCs
  • Mitigation via REDD+
  • Rehabilitation of degrade land
  • Restrict diversion for non-forestry
  • Promote - agroforestry and farm forestry

Strategy

  • Community participation
    • National community forest management mission to be launched
    • Reduce illegal felling, encroachment, forest fire
  • Forest fire - early warning system, remote sensing
  • Locally suitable indigenous species
  • Increase productivity of commercial trees
    • Scientific approach
    • PPP model
  • Legal measures to prevent bio – piracy
  • Forest management as per working plan
  • NTFP – supplement livelihood of forest community
  • Promote agroforestry and farm forestry - certification system, PPP model, price assurance, technical assistance
  • Human wildlife conflict – quick reaction team
  • Funding – budget to state via finance commission and CAMPA fund
  • Institutional mechanism – national Board of forestry, state board of forestry

Criticism

  • PPP – privatisation of natural resources
  • More on conservation – less focus on regeneration
  • Doesn't discuss issue of diversion of forest land for mining

Forest laws

law policy
for regulation guiding principles
by legislature by executive

Indian forest act 1927

  • Chapter 1 section 2 : tree definition - tree include Palms, stumps, brush wood, canes. [2017 amendment removed bamboo from definition.]
  • Chapter 2, section 3–27: reserve forest
    • State government can declare any government forest land as a reserve forest
    • Forest settlement officer to be appointed
      • power to survey and demarcate land
      • Power of civil court
    • State government can also de-reserve
  • Chapter 3, section 28 – village forest – state can assign and make rules to manage it
  • Chapter 4 section 29, 39 - protected forest - state issue notification
  • Chapter 5, section 35–38 – state control non-government forest land

    State can regulate

    • clearing land for cultivation
    • Pasture for cattle
    • Preserving peoples health

  • Chapter 6, section 39 – can impose duty on timber and other forest produce
  • Chapter 7, section 41 – control of timber transport via land and river
  • Chapter 9, section 52 – penalty + seizure of property
  • Chapter 11 section 74 – indemnity to forest officers – act done in good faith

Draft Indian forest amendment bill 2019

  • Power to forest officers
    • Issues search warrant
    • Enter and investigate land
    • Use arms – prevent wildlife crime + Naxal
    • Indemnity
  • FRA 2006 – states can end rights of person under FRA – if state government feels such rights hamper conservation
  • New category - “production forest” - timber, pulp, etc.
  • Forest development cess at 10% - on mining activity in forest area – to be used for reforestation + forest protection

Forest conservation act 1980

  • Section 2 - state government cannot do without prior approval of central government:
    • De-reservation of forest
    • Use of forest land for non-forest purpose
  • Section 3 – central government can create advisory committee
    • Make recommendations under section 2
    • Any other matter referred
  • Section 3A – penalty for violation of provisions – simple imprisonment up to 15 days
  • Section 3B – offences by authorities and government department

Wildlife protection act 1972

  • chapter 1 – definitions
    • “protected area” – national Park, wildlife sanctuary, conservation reserve, community reserve
    • Schedule V - vermin
    • Schedule VI - specified plant
  • Chapter 2 – authorities
    • Central government – director of wildlife preservation
    • State government – chief wildlife warden
    • National board for wildlife
      • Via WPA amendment act 2002
      • Prime Minister in chair person, minister is vice chair person, 3 MPs, 5 NGOs, director and secretaries
      • Take measures for wildlife protection
      • Advice central government
    • State board for wildlife
      • Chief Ministry chairperson, minister chairperson, chief wildlife warden
      • Selects area to be declared for protection
  • Chapter 3 – hunting of wild animals
    • Bans hunting of animal – schedule I, II, III, IV
    • Chief wildlife warden allow hunting - threat to human life; diseased beyond recovery
    • Chief wild life warden allow hunting for special purpose - Education. Scientific research, sample collection, drugs collection
  • Chapter 3A -
    • Protection of specific plants
      • Bans picking, uprooting
      • chief warden can allow picking, uprooting - education, research, ex-situ preservation
      • Cannot cultivate specific plants without license – chief warden gives license
    • Declare an area as sanctuary
  • Chapter 4 – protected areas
    • CWW allows someone to enter or reside in sanctuary
    • Immunization of livestock
    • State government can declare such area as – national Park, conservation reserve, community reserve
    • Central government may also declare an area as national Park, wildlife reserve
  • Chapter 4A – central zoo authority
    • Chair: environment minister
    • Up to 10 members
    • Recognizing or de-recognise zoos
    • Identify endangered species for captive breeding
  • Chapter 4B – national Tiger conservation authority
    • chair: environment minister, voice chair: minister of state environment, ministry
    • Recommends state government to notify an area as tiger reserve
  • Chapter 4C – wildlife crime control bureau – by central government
  • Chapter 5, 5A – prohibition on trade and commerce – wild animals, animal articles, etc.

Salient features

  • Established - national Park, wildlife sanctuary
  • Plans – third national wildlife action plan 2017–31
  • wildlife sanctuary – restricted grazing allowed; National park – no grazing
  • cannot collect NTFP that harms ecosystem
  • Comprehensive List of endangered species
    • Schedule I to IV - specific animals
    • Schedule V - vermin
    • Schedule VI - specific plants

WPA amendment act

  • Gives effect to India's obligations under CITES
  • illegal wildlife trade – enhanced punishment
  • Allows bona fide activities in protected areas - grazing of livestock, drinking water need of household
  • Appendix reorganized into four categories
  • Government can regulate / prevent invasive species
  • Enhance penalty for “general violation” from 25,000 to 1 lakh

Forest conservation amendment act 2023

provisions

  • New name – Vana sanrakshan evam sanvardhan adhiniyam (1980)
  • Streamlines application
    • Old: recorded forest + notified forest + revenue forest
    • Now: recorded Forest + private forest + plantation
  • Exemptions
    • To encourage afforestation outside the forest
    • To provide connectivity for habitation and establishment on side of road and rail
    • 10 ha land for security related infrastructure
    • 5 ha land for LWE affected area
    • Strategic project within 100 km of international border, LoC, LAC
  • New forestry activities list added
    • Infrastructure for forest staff
    • Eco tourism, zoo, Safari
    • Survey inside forest area
  • Fighting climate change - ensure effort to meet India's INDC goal of climate change
  • Empowered local people – zoo, Safari, eco tourism ⇒ livelihood for locals

Issues

  • Hindi name
  • 100 km water exemption
    • Hurts eco-sensitive areas of Himalaya and north Northeast
    • right of indigenous communities at Northeast will be impacted
  • Applicable, only to areas recorded as forest after October 1980 – so many green areas unprotected

Forest economics

  • Application of principles of economics to forestry management
  • Need - demand – supply, budget allocation, management of human resources, infrastructure, value addition

Production function

  • Technological relationship between quantities of physical input and quantities of physical output

    e.g. if technology improves – more output from same input

Features of production function

  • Substitutability : factors of production are substitute of one another (labour - capital investment machinery)
  • Complementarity: factors of production compliment each other – no output if any component is made zero
  • specificity: factors of production are specific to production of a particular product – machinery, specialized workers

Utility

Marginal utility

  • Satisfaction from consuming one additional quantity
  • Law of diminishing marginal utility – marginal utility declines with each successive consumption

Demand

Demand – supply curve

Cost benefit analysis in commercial forestry

Cost

  • Buying land, Site preparation, nursery establishment, plantation work, weeding and cleaning, tending operations, transportation, protection cost

Benefits

  • Tangible
  • Intangible

Inflation

Division of labour

Marginal cost

  • Increasing cost of product due to rising production cost

Market structure

  • Organizational characteristics of a market – its size, design, manner of operation - that affects - nature of competition, pricing, operation of business firms
monopoly single supplier
monopsony single buyer
oligopoly fuel suppliers
oligopsonyFew buyers

Components of market structure

  • Concentration of market power
  • product differentiation
  • Entry condition for firms
  • Flow of information of market
  • Degree of integration

Market function

  • Primary function - Procurement, Processing, distribution
  • Secondary function – packaging, transporting, grading, financing, market information
  • Tertiary function – banking, insurance

Market channels

  • Routes through which forest products move from producer to consumer
  • Depends on – commodity, quantity, demand, regional specialisation
  • Types
    • Direct - no middleman
      flowchart LR
  A[forest department] --wood harvesting --> B[Forest depot] --> consumer
    • Indirect – middleman
      • e.g. sale of timber: forest department → wood harvesting → forest depot → → consumer
      flowchart LR
  A[forest department] --wood harvesting --> B[Forest depot] --auction --> industry --> wholesaler --> retailer --> consumer

Market integration

Vertical integration

link between: Raw material supplier, manufacturer, distributor, wholesaler, etc.

Horizontal integration

When a firm acquires another firm doing same function at same market level

Marketing efficiency

Whether it fulfills its assigned objective at minimum possible cost

Role of government, private sector, cooperative in marketing forest produce

Role of government

  • Legal protection - e.g. FRA 2006 allowed MFP collection.
  • Skill development – e.g. Vanabandhu Kalyan Yojana
  • Marketing – e.g. TRIFED
  • Protection of income and strengthening supply chain - e.g. MSP for MFP, GI tag, bio – prospecting

Role of private sector, cooperatives, NGOs

  • Skill development
  • Training and financing - e.g. CSR funds.
  • Technology transfer
  • Value addition
  • Direct procurement

Socio economic impact

  • Poverty alleviation
  • Health
  • Education
  • Sustainable economy

PM Van Dhan Yojana

  • Aim: capacity building of MFP gatherers – by organising them into SHG

Plan

Van Dhan SHG

1 SHG for 20 gatherers

Van Dhan Vikas Kendra

  • Group of 15 SHG
  • Cost of 1.5 lakh - 1 lakh for training and equipment, 0.5 lakh for working capital via loan, own fund

Significance

Present value chain

  • Tribal get 20%
  • Middleman, traders, market gets 80%

New value chain

  • Tribal gatherers → tribal SHG → SHG Federation → market
  • Tribals get 70%

Forest valuation

  • Estimating value of – tangible and intangible – goods and services – provided by forest

Objective

  • Assessing value of forest – when being transferred to other department
  • State acquiring a private forest
  • Estimate of capital formation – helps in investment

Traditional method of valuation

cost value

Cost of land + expenditure in raising trees

income value

Based on future return at an acceptable r%r\%r%﻿

market value

Based on parameters -

  • Site quality, productivity
  • Composition, age, density
  • Climate, topography, biotic pressure
  • Water availability

Modern method of valuation

evaluation using market prices

Relies on market price of timber, NTFP, crops, etc. - that are commercially traded

Advantage

  • Simple
  • No expertise is needed

Disadvantage

  • Does not include intangible benefits
  • Focus only on commercially traded goods

surrogate market approach

Travel cost method

  • For developed nation
  • People visit far away forest sites as they value the experience

    Forest value = total travel cost + opportunity cost

Hedonic pricing

Price of property (real estate) based on its location near Forest, Stream, etc.

  • Considers air pollution, etc.
  • Not suitable for developing nations – whose land is unaccompanied, poor regulations

Substitute good approach

  • Value of Non-marketed for good = cost of its substitute
  • e.g. cost of LPG cylinder → value of fuelwood

cost based valuation

Replacement cost method

Estimate cost of replacing benefits with alternatives

e.g. Forest reduces runoff - cost of flood control ⇒ value

Preventative expenditure

e.g. Forest protect soil ⇒ find cost of restoring degraded soil

Opportunity cost

Employment opportunity for gone to secure a particular non-market benefit

e.g. NTFP collection.

Importance of wildlife and biodiversity

  • Ecological value - maintain food chain, balance of ecosystem

    e.g. if snakes are killed → rodent population will rise → damage crops

  • economic value - horn, ivory, fur, etc
  • Sports and enjoyment - hunting, fishing, bull fight, bird watching, wildlife photography
  • Life saving drugs
    • Rhesus monkey → understanding of Rh-group
    • Bird feather → tells heavy metal pollution in the air
  • Genetic resources
    • Genetic diversity
    • Genetic engineering

Threat to wildlife

  • Habitat fragmentation → mining, trawling, logging
  • Habitat degradation → climate change, acid rain
  • Invasive species
  • Climate change and pollution → e.g. oil spill
  • Disease
  • Excessive tourism

Terms

  • Juxtaposition - measure of proximity of different habitats
  • Interspersion - symbol of territorial position of these habitats
  • pinch period - when sufficient food is not available
  • Dispersal – some individuals of a population leave habitat and permanently move to another place
  • natality - rate of birth
  • Mortality
  • Gregarious - many species have tendency to live together
  • Cruising radius – distance an animal may move from a point in a day
  • biotic potential - maximum growth rate of a population under ideal conditions
  • Extinction threshold – minimum number of individuals required to ensure survival of a population or species
  • Environmental resistance - environmental factors that resist biological expansion of species

Census of animals

Direct count

total count

Direct method

  • Animals are driven from their hidden place to area of census
  • Includes – driving persons, enumerators

Visual method

  • For open area where animals come collectively at some time
  • e.g. at Kanha - swamp deer gather during March-April
  • So they can be counted repeatedly to get a final number

Aerial method

  • Area is open, and animals are found in group
  • Airplane can take photo
  • Numbers maybe counted via photos

sample count

only small sample is counted, not the entire population

Block count

  • Area → parts (based on - nature of habitat, species density)
  • Parts → stratum (based on - forest density, dominating species)
  • Stratum → parks
  • Some parks are randomly chosen representing 10% area → head count

Road Transect count

  • To find trend of population growth
  • Also, to compare species population
  • Species are counted in same area, same ecological situation, at different times

Indirect count

Pug mark count

  • Every individual has a distinct pug mark
  • Every species has a distinct pug mark
  • Used for – lion, tiger, leopard

Dung / pellet count

  • Count of pellet, dropping, fecal material
  • Tells presence and abundance in a particular habitat
  • for mostly mammals
  • Most used – deer

Call index count

  • Sound of animal is used
  • Indicates abundance in a particular habitat

Miscellaneous count

Waterhole count

  • In summer less waterhole available
  • Animals come to drink water - count

Kill evidence

Camera trap

Wildlife telemetry

  • measurement from remote distance

VHF (Very High Frequency) transmitter attached to animal

  • VHF antenna
  • homing
  • Triangulation

UHF satellite transmitter

  • Transmitter attached to animal sends UHF to satellite

GPS tracking

  • Find migratory routes of animals

Project tiger

  • Launch - 1973

    St. Petersburg declaration 2010

    • Head of 13 tiger range country
    • Two double population by 2022
  • Sex differentiation in pug mark of tiger
  • Importance of pug mark
    • Identify species
    • Identify age, health
    • Hunting habit
    • Health status
    • Population growth

tiger census

  • Once 4 years
  • Census 2018
    • Population: 2967 (70% of world’s tiger)
    • Maximum: MP

Method

Pug mark method

Each pug mark is unique

Camera trap

Poop method

  • Poop analyzed by DNA sampling
  • Accurate method

Radio collar method

M-stripes

  • Tigers outside forest area
  • Android app

Animal disease

viral

Rabies - Lyssavirus

Canine distemper

  • canine distemper virus
  • Carnivorous animals
  • Lung infection

FMD

  • Picornavirus
  • Grazing cattle - cheetal, sambar, gaur
  • Mouth ulcer, body temperature
  • Spreads to other via salivation
  • Vaccine available

Bacterial

anthrax - Bacillus anthasis

Botulism - Clostridium botulinum

4. Forest Economics and Legislation :

Forest economics: fundamental principles, cost-benefit analyses; estimation of demand and

supply; analysis of trends in the national and international market and changes in production

and consumption patterns; assessment and projection of market structures; role of private

sector and co-operatives; role of corporate financing. Socio-economic analyses of forest

productivity and attitudes; valuation of forest goods and service.

Legislation-History of forest development; Indian Forest Policy of 1894, 1952 and 1990.

National Forest Policy, 1988 of People's involvement, Joint Forest Management, Involvement of

women; Forestry Policies and issues related to land use, timber and non-timber products,

sustainable forest management; industrialization policies; institutional and structural

changes. Decentralization and Forestry Public Administration. Forest laws, necessity; general

principles, Indian Forest Act 1927; Forest Conservation Act, 1980; Wildlife Protection Act 1972

and their amendments; Application of Indian Penal Code to Forestry. Scope and objectives of

Forest nventory.

Soil composition
